Blog |date=June 24, 2014 |access-date=May 12, 2015}} * 2019 Green Car Reports Car of the Decade.{{cite web|url=https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1126516_green-car-reports-car-of-the-decade-tesla-model-s|title=Green car reports car of the decade|date=December 30, 2019|accessdate=January 2, 2020}} === Distance records === A distance record of {{cvt|670|mi}} in a P100D was set on August 5, 2017 by Italian drivers, making the Model S the first production electric car to exceed {{cvt|1000|km|order=flip}} on a single charge.{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/8/6/16104628/tesla-drivers-italy-distance-record-model-s |title=Italian Tesla drivers set distance record after driving Model S 670 miles on a single charge |first=Andrew |last=Liptak |work=The Verge |date=August 6, 2017 |access-date=August 30, 2017}} Previously the record of {{convert|560|mi|abbr=out|+1}} in a P100D was set on June 20, 2017 by Belgian drivers.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-model-s-sets-new-hypermiling-record-560-miles-2017-6|title=Two Tesla fanatics just drove a Model S for a record 560 miles on a single charge -- here's how |first=Danielle |last=Muoio |work=Business Insider |location=Australia |date=June 22, 2017 |access-date=August 30, 2017}} Before that the distance record was {{convert|452.8|mi|abbr=out|+1}} in a Model S. It was made by Norwegian Bjørn Nyland and Morgan Tørvolt on a flat stretch with low traffic around the supercharger in [[Rødekro]], Denmark. All of these records used [[Energy-efficient driving|hypermiling]] techniques such as front motor only, low speed {{cvt|24|mph|km/h|0}}, no air conditioning and minimal use of the brakes.{{cite news |last=Andersen |first=Ina |url=http://www.tu.no/industri/2015/08/26/norske-bjorn-kjorte-728-kilometer-i-en-tesla--pa-en-lading |title=Norske Bjørn kjørte 728 kilometer i en Tesla – på én lading |trans-title=Norwegian Bjorn ran 728 kilometers in a Tesla - on a single charge |work=[[Teknisk Ukeblad]] |language=Norwegian |date=August 26, 2015 |access-date=June 22, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.worldrecordacademy.com/transport/longest_trip_in_a_production_electric_car_Tesla_Model_S_P85D_breaks_Guinness_World_Records_record_215435.html |title=Longest Trip In A Production Electric Car: Tesla Model S P85D breaks Guinness World Records record |work=World Record Academy |date=August 27, 2015 |access-date=June 22, 2016}} The first record of {{convert|423.5|mi|abbr=out|+1}} was set during November 2012 by David and Adam Metcalf.{{cite press release |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/customers/story-david-adam-metcalf |title=World Record Father-Son Drive |first1=David |last1=Metcalf |first2=Adam |last2=Metcalf |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=December 13, 2012 |access-date=June 22, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/12/father-and-son-drive-423-miles-on-one-charge-in-tesla-model-s |title=Father and Son Drive 423 Miles on One Charge in Tesla Model S |first=Jim |last=Motavalli |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 12, 2012 |access-date=June 22, 2016}} These attempts were inspired by a blog written by Elon Musk about the planned range and efficiency of the Tesla Model S, offering a prize for anyone exceeding {{convert|400|mi|abbr=out|+1}} on a single charge, where it was estimated the 85 kwh model could do it by driving at a constant {{cvt|36|mph|km/h|0}} under ideal conditions.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/model-s-efficiency-and-range |title=Model S Efficiency and Range |first=Elon |last=Musk |authorlink=Elon Musk |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=May 9, 2012 |access-date=October 11, 2014}} ===Lap records=== In early-September 2019, a prototype Tesla Model S went faster than the official record for the fastest "four-door electric sports car" at the [[Laguna Seca Raceway]], beating a previous time held by the [[Tesla Model 3|Tesla {{nowrap|Model 3}}]] Performance.{{cite news|url=https://jalopnik.com/elon-musk-claims-tesla-model-s-sets-new-record-at-lagun-1838037694 |title=Elon Musk Claims Tesla Model S Sets New Record At Laguna Seca, Which Is Not The Nürburgring|first=Justin T.|last=Westbrook |work=[[Jalopnik]]|date=September 11, 2019}}{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6hmdmYRYt9A |title=Tesla Model S Fastest Lap at Laguna Seca|date=September 12, 2019|quote=We lapped [[Laguna Seca Raceway|Laguna Seca]] in 1:36.555 during advanced R&D testing of our Model S Plaid powertrain and chassis prototype — a second faster than the record for a four-door sedan.|via=Youtube|author=Tesla, Inc.|authorlink=Tesla, Inc.}} Shortly after the release of the [[Porsche Taycan]] {{nowrap|Turbo S}}, Tesla had booked exclusive testing time at the [[Nürburgring Nordschleife]] on 18, {{nowrap|21 & 25}} September 2019.{{cite news|url=https://www.auto-motor-und-sport.de/elektroauto/porsche-taycan-tesla-model-s-nordschleife-rekord-2019/ |title=Tesla entert die Nordschleife|trans-title=Tesla enters the Nordschleife|first=Gregor|last=Hebermehl |date=September 11, 2019|work=[[Auto motor und sport]]|language=de|quote=Test- und Abstimmungsfahrten sollen jeden Tag stattfinden, für Mittwoch den 18. September 2019 ist eine größere Fahrt geplant. Am Samstag dem 21. September [2019] sind dann für zwei Stunden sämtliche Touristen- und Ringtaxi-Fahrten abgesagt, damit Tesla freie Bahn hat. Am Mittwoch dem 25. September [2019] ist in der Zeit von 17:00 bis 17:45 Uhr wieder die Strecke für Tesla reserviert.}}{{cite web|department=Spy shots|url= https://www.autoblog.com/2019/09/11/tesla-model-s-p100d-spied-near-nurburgring/#slide-endcap |work=Autoblog|title=This might be the Tesla Model S that will challenge the Porsche Taycan's Nurburgring time: Asterisk: It's not stock|first=Joel|last=Stocksdale |date=September 11, 2019|quote=isn't a stock Model S P100D, … lower grille opening has been enlarged, probably to improve cooling for the motors and batteries. It has subtle fender flares at each corner to house much wider wheels and tires. … Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2 R tires, … lip spoiler.}} == Controversies == === Range limitation === On February 8, 2013, ''[[The New York Times]]'' published a review by John M. Broder about a trip between Washington, D.C., and Boston using Tesla's Supercharger network. At the time it included only two stations on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]]. Broder made a variety of critical claims about the battery's performance in cold weather and the distance between charging stations. The trip ended with the Model S carried by a [[flatbed truck]] to the [[Milford, Connecticut]], station.{{cite news |last=Broder |first=John |title=Stalled Out on Tesla's Electric Highway |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/10/automobiles/stalled-on-the-ev-highway.html?ref=automobiles&_r=0 |access-date=February 16, 2013 |date=February 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}} Tesla responded by publishing logs of the vehicle's charge levels and driving speed that contradicted Broder's account on several factual details.{{cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |title=A Most Peculiar Test Drive |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/most-peculiar-test-drive |date=February 13, 2013 |access-date=February 16, 2013 |publisher=Tesla Motors}} Tesla implied that Broder's behavior forced the car to fail. Broder replied to the criticism in a blog post and suggested that the speed discrepancies may have been because the car had been equipped with [[Dub (wheel)|19-inch wheels rather than the specified 21-inch wheels]].{{cite web |last=Broder |first=John |title=That Tesla Data: What It Says and What It Doesn't |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/14/that-tesla-data-what-it-says-and-what-it-doesnt/ |access-date=February 16, 2013 |date=February 14, 2013 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}} In the midst of the controversy, a [[CNN]] reporter recreated Broder's trip without exhausting the battery. However, two key differences distinguished the two journeys. The weather was about {{cvt|10|F-change|0}} warmer and CNN did the trip in one day; the ''Times'' let the car sit overnight without being plugged in.{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/02/15/autos/tesla-model-s/index.html |title=Test drive: DC to Boston in a Tesla Model S |author=Peter Valdes-Dapena |work=[[CNN]] Money |date=February 15, 2013 |access-date=February 16, 2013}} A reporter from [[CNBC]] also recreated the trip in one day without incidents.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/100464893/page/1 |title=Behind the Wheel, Putting the Tesla to the Test |author=Philip LeBeau |publisher=[[CNBC]] |date=February 19, 2013 |access-date=February 22, 2013}} One week later, a group of Tesla owners recreated Broder's trip without problems. One owner was delayed because his car failed to charge and required two [[firmware]] updates.{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1082401_tesla-model-s-road-trip-electric-cars-make-it-from-dc-to-ct |title=Tesla Model S Road Trip: Electric Cars Make It From DC To CT |author=Elvia Thompson |publisher=Green Car Reports |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=February 20, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2013/02/18/tesla-model-s-road-trip-drivers-have-no-problem-video/ |title=Tesla Model S road trip drivers find success along NYT's failed drive route [w/video] |author=Sebastian Blanco |publisher=Autoblog Green |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=February 20, 2013}} On February 18, 2013, ''[[The New York Times]]'' [[Public Editor]] Margaret Sullivan published an editorial stating that Broder took "casual and imprecise notes" of his test drive and did not use good judgment, but she maintained that the article was written in good faith. She also admitted that Broder's vehicle logs were "sometimes quite misleading."{{cite news |url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/18/problems-with-precision-and-judgment-but-not-integrity-in-tesla-test/ |title=Problems With Precision and Judgment, but Not Integrity, in Tesla Test |author=Margaret Sullivan |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=February 20, 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2136866,00.html |title=Charged Debate |author=James Poniewozik |authorlink=James Poniewozik |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=March 4, 2013 |access-date=February 22, 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/24/automobiles/after-a-charging-system-test-a-debate-erupts-online.html?ref=automobiles&_r=1& |title=After a Charging System Test, a Debate Erupts Online |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 22, 2013 |access-date=February 22, 2013}} In July and September 2014 tests performed by an independent German car magazine in cooperation with the TÜV (German Association for Technical Inspection) and Tesla owners seemed to reveal issues with the battery's performance. According to the magazine, Tesla did not take up the invitation to repeat the test, and also seemed to refuse to offer vehicles for a second test.{{cite news |url=http://www.auto-motor-und-sport.de/news/e-auto-haertetest-auto-motor-und-sport-unterstreicht-harte-testmethoden-8563278.html |title=E-Auto-Härtetest auto motor und sport unterstreicht harte Testmethoden|trans-title=car auto motor und sport emphasizes hard test methods |work=Auto motor und Sport |access-date=November 12, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.auto-motor-und-sport.de/news/tesla-s-im-nachtest-258-km-reichweite-bei-120-km-h-und-13-grad-8612751.html |title=Tesla S im Nachtest 258 km Reichweite bei 120 km/h und 13 Grad |trans-title=Tesla S at posttest reaches 258 km at 120 km / h, 13 degrees |work=Auto motor und Sport |date=September 12, 2014 |access-date=November 12, 2014}} A test performed by another German publication ("[[Die Welt]]") supported the findings.{{cite news |url=https://www.welt.de/motor/article131669893/Beim-dritten-Gasstoss-faengt-der-Tesla-an-zu-schwaecheln.html |title=Beim dritten Gasstoß fängt der Tesla an zu schwächeln |trans-title=By the third step on the pedal the Tesla starts to weaken |first=Jens |last=Meiners |newspaper=[[Die Welt]] |date=August 28, 2014 |access-date=November 12, 2014}} === Production delay === In 2007, Tesla announced plans to build 10,000 Model S sedans annually starting in 2009.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Production was delayed, and Tesla's website later stated that deliveries would start in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/models/index.php |title=Tesla Model S Homepage |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114015912/http://www.teslamotors.com/models/index.php |archivedate=January 14, 2010 |url-status=dead |access-date=April 18, 2017}} However, in January 2010, Musk stated that he expected to launch the Model S sedan "within two and a half years", translating to Q3 2012.{{cite news |title=Yet Another Delay for Telsa Motors – Model S Coming in 850 Days or So, Maybe |url=http://sfcitizen.com/blog/2010/01/15/yet-another-delay-for-telsa-motors-model-s-coming-in-850-days-or-so-maybe |date=January 15, 2010 |access-date=April 18, 2017}} === Power dissipation when not in use === Older versions of the system software suffered from power drain issues when the car wasn't being used, with the batteries losing 4.5 kWh overnight (known commonly as "vampire drain").{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1088648_life-with-tesla-model-s-even-after-update-vampire-draw-remains |title=Life With Tesla Model S: Even After Update, Vampire Draw Remains |first=David |last=Nolan |work=Green Car Reports |date=November 25, 2013 |access-date=November 25, 2013}} System software v5.8 (v1.49.30), released December 12, 2013, reduced overnight energy loss substantially, to 1.1 kWh per night, or around 3 miles. === Consumer Reports' recommendation === In October 2015, two months after naming the Tesla 'the best car ever tested,' Consumer Reports declined to give the Tesla Model S a "recommended" designation, citing too many complaints from owners. Complaints ranged from minor, such as misaligned doors and squeaky body, to severe - things like total drive train replacement and inoperable door handles. Tesla's shares dropped 15%, both because of the magazine's cut and because of concerns over the Tesla Model X luxury SUV.{{cite web |title=Consumer Reports Cuts Tesla From Its Recommended List Over Reliability |url=https://www.yahoo.com/autos/teslas-reliability-doesnt-match-its-high-170529595.html |publisher=Yahoo! |access-date=October 27, 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cars/tesla-reliability-doesnt-match-its-high-performance |title=Tesla Reliability Doesn't Match Its High Performance |first=Mark |last=Rechtin |magazine=[[Consumer Reports]] |date=October 20, 2015 |access-date=November 24, 2015}} Similarly, Edmunds.com found quality and safety issues in their long-term road test and "amassed quite the repair résumé during the last 17 months."{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/tesla/model-s/2013/long-term-road-test/wrap-up.html|title=2013 Tesla Model S Long-Term Wrap-Up {{!}} Edmunds.com|website=Edmunds|access-date=April 5, 2016}} Both Edmunds and Consumer Reports reported issues, including the vehicle stalling while driving.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-model-s-critical-backlash-five-main-problems-electric-car-identified-recent-1656144|title=Tesla Model S Critical Backlash: Five Main Problems With Electric Car Identified In Recent Reviews|website=International Business Times|access-date=April 5, 2016}} In their 2016 Annual Auto Reliability Survey, Consumer Reports improved the Model S rating to average reliability, while reporting that the Model X has had significant malfunction issues. The magazine also raised "serious concerns about how some automakers, including Tesla, have designed, deployed, and marketed semi-autonomous technology."{{cite web|url=http://www.consumerreports.org/car-reliability/car-reliability-survey-2016/ |title=Consumer Reports Car Reliability Survey 2016|magazine=[[Consumer Reports]]|date=October 24, 2016 |access-date=October 24, 2016}} By 2017, in the [[Consumer Reports]] Car Reliability Survey, Tesla's position on the list had moved up four spots; the predicted reliability rating for Model S reached "above average" for the first time. In 2018 the annual consumer reports reliability survey found Tesla cars amongst the worst with the brand falling 6 spots from 2017 and third worst amongst the brands surveyed.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/24/tesla-reliability-slips-to-third-worst-in-us-consumer-reports-says.html|title=Tesla slips several spots in Consumer Reports reliability ranking|last=LeBeau|first=Phil|date=2018-10-24|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2019-10-03}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeanbaptiste/2018/10/26/tesla-cars-may-be-the-safest-in-america-but-fail-in-reliability-consumer-reports/|title=Tesla Cars May Be The Safest In America, But Fail In Reliability: Consumer Reports|last=Su|first=Jean Baptiste|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2019-10-03}} The Model S dropped "below average" in reliability with suspension problems and other issues that included the extending door handle. In 2019 the model S was given a Consumer Reports "recommended" designation{{cite web|url=https://www.consumerreports.org/car-reliability-owner-satisfaction/tesla-model-3-model-s-regain-consumer-reports-recommendation/|title=Tesla Model 3 and Model S Regain a Consumer Reports Recommendation|date=November 14, 2019|accessdate=December 15, 2019}} due to improved reliability, with the Model S being the second-most reliable out of four ultra-luxury cars tested. === Power discrepancy === The P85D "Insane" was widely reported to have 691 horsepower,{{cite web |url=http://beta.motortrend.com/news/2015-tesla-model-s-p90d-ludicrous-upgrade-first-test-review/ |title=2015 Tesla Model S P90D w/Ludicrous Upgrade First Test |author=Christian Seabaugh |date=October 28, 2015 |magazine=[[Motor Trend]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/models |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311143217/http://www.teslamotors.com/models |title=Model S - Tesla Motors |archivedate=March 11, 2015 |publisher=teslamotors.com}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2015-tesla-model-s-p85d-first-drive-review |first=Tony |last=Quiroga |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160523153631/http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2015-tesla-model-s-p85d-first-drive-review |title=2015 Tesla Model S P85D|date=January 30, 2015 |archivedate=May 23, 2016 |magazine=[[Car and Driver]] |access-date=December 12, 2016 |url-status=live}} but some owners reported 20% less power on [[dynamometer]] in various circumstances.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/owners-question-tesla-p85d-power-output-news-letter-2/ |title=Owners Question Tesla P85D Power Output |date=September 29, 2015 |author=Ronan Glon |work=[[Digital Trends]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/what-is-the-actual-overall-horsepower-rating-for-the-tesla-p85d/ |title=What Is The Actual Overall Horsepower Rating for the Tesla P85D? |date=September 29, 2015 |author=Sarah Shelton |publisher=HybridCars.com}} Manufacturers are required by EU law to display power "at full setting of the power controller" (from an external DC source when performing laboratory vehicle approval), but not necessarily to show power limited by battery. Other equipment must be removed, or their power added to the measurement.[[JB Straubel]]. "[http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/tesla-all-wheel-drive-dual-motor-power-and-torque-specifications Tesla All Wheel Drive (Dual Motor) Power and Torque Specifications]" ''Tesla'', September 21, 2015. Quote: "only this (single or combined) motor shaft horsepower rating that is legally required to be posted in the European Union.""[http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/trans/main/wp29/wp29regs/updates/R085r1e.pdf Uniform provisions concerning the approval of internal combustion engines or electric drive trains intended for the propulsion of motor vehicles of categories M and N with regard to the measurement of net power and the maximum 30 minutes power of electric drive trains]" pages 9+41. ''[[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe]]'', August 21, 2013. Quote: "5.3.1.2. The net power test shall consist of a run at full setting of the power controller." "Note: If the battery limits the maximum 30 minutes power, the maximum 30 minutes power of an electric vehicle can be less than the maximum 30 minutes power of the drive train of the vehicle according to this test." Actual power available depends on circumstances, as it does for piston cars{{cite web |url=http://www.tuneruniversity.com/blog/2011/05/keep-your-engine-alive-the-importance-of-oil-temperature/ |title=Keep Your Engine Alive: The Importance of Oil Temperature |author=Nathan Morris |publisher=Tuner University}} which until 1972 could be 25–30% less than given.{{cite web |url=https://www.hagerty.com/articles-videos/articles/2013/08/13/Horsepower |title=Engine Horsepower – Muscle Car Horsepower |author=Jim Koscs |work=[[Hagerty Insurance Agency]]}}{{cite web |url=http://ateupwithmotor.com/terms-technology-definitions/gross-versus-net-horsepower/ |title=Understanding Gross Versus Net Horsepower Ratings |author=Aaron Severson |date=April 15, 2008 |work=Ate Up With Motor}} {{asof|2015|November}}, Tesla website showed battery-limited combined 463 hp for P85D (532 hp for "Ludicrous").{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/models |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151102121720/http://www.teslamotors.com/models |title=Model S – Tesla Motors |archivedate=November 2, 2015 |publisher=teslamotors.com}} A lawsuit by 126 owners in Norway{{cite web|url=http://www.tu.no/artikler/tesla-mener-p85d-kjoperne-tok-en-risiko-for-skuffelse-som-de-selv-ma-baere/365855 |title=Tesla mener P85D-kjøperne tok "en risiko for skuffelse, som de selv må bære" |first=Roald |last=Ramsdal |work=[[Teknisk Ukeblad]] |access-date=December 12, 2016 |date=December 6, 2016 }} was settled in December 2016.{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/tesla-settles-norway-lawsuit-over-123303743.html |title=Tesla settles Norway lawsuit over car's performance|work=Reuters |date=December 12, 2016 |access-date=December 12, 2016 }} === Power consumption === In early March 2016, a report by [[Stuff (magazine)|''Stuff'' magazine]] revealed that test performed by VICOM, Ltd on behalf of Singapore's Land Transport Authority had found a 2014 Tesla Model S to be consuming {{cvt|444|Wh/km|kWh/mi}},{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.tv/sg/features/be-prepared-these-roadblocks-if-you-want-drive-tesla-in-singapore/page-3|title=Be prepared for these roadblocks if you want to drive a Tesla in Singapore {{!}} Stuff|website=[[Stuff (magazine)|Stuff]] |access-date=June 1, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/lta-on-tesla-car-test-all/2572062.html|title=LTA on Tesla: CO2 emissions for electric cars start at power grid|website=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=June 1, 2016}} which was greater than the {{cvt|0.38|kWh/mi|Wh/km|order=flip}} reported by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA){{cite web|url=https://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/bymodel/2014_Tesla_Model_S.shtml|title=Gas Mileage of 2014 Tesla Model S|website=www.fueleconomy.gov|access-date=June 1, 2016}} and the {{cvt|181|Wh/km|kWh/mi}} reported by Tesla. As a result, a carbon surcharge was imposed on the Model S, making Singapore the only country in the world to impose an environmental surcharge on a fully electric car.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/transport/electric-car-tesla-slapped-with-15000-tax-surcharge|title=Electric car Tesla slapped with $15,000 tax surcharge|last=hermes|date=March 4, 2016|website=The Straits Times|access-date=June 1, 2016}} The Land Transport Authority justified this by stating that it had to "account for {{CO2}} emissions during the electricity generation process" and therefore "a grid emission factor of 0.5 g/watt-hour was also applied to the electric energy consumption",{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/lta-on-tesla-co2/2572062.html|title=LTA on Tesla: CO2 emissions for electric cars start at power grid|website=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=June 1, 2016}} however Tesla countered that when the energy used to extract, refine, and distribute gasoline was taken into account, the Model S produces approximately one-third the {{CO2}} of an equivalent gasoline-powered vehicle.{{cite web|title=Here's how clean a Model S is in Singapore (and elsewhere)|url=https://www.teslamotors.com/support/heres-how-clean-model-s-singapore-and-elsewhere|website=Tesla Motors|access-date=June 1, 2016}} Later that month, the Land Transport Authority released a statement stating that they and the VICOM Emission Test Laboratory will be working with Tesla engineers to determine if there was a flaw in the test,{{cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/singapores-lta-tesla-model-tested-car-efficiency|title=Singapore's LTA says the Tesla Model S it tested was a used car, hence its low efficiency|website=Tech in Asia|date=March 10, 2016|access-date=June 1, 2016}} and a Tesla statement indicated that the discussions were "positive" and that they were confident of a quick resolution. == See also == Loveday |publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=January 23, 2014 |access-date=January 23, 2014}} {{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/models/options |title=Model S/Options and pricing |publisher=Tesla {{cvt|325|mi}} (EPA) | related = {{plainlist| * [[Tesla Model S]] * [[Tesla Model Y]] }} | designer = [[Franz von Holzhausen]]{{cite web|title=Franz von Holzhausen Joins Tesla Motors as Chief Designer|url= https://www.tesla.com/blog/franz-von-holzhausen-joins-tesla-motors-chief-designer?redirect=no |website=TESLA|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} | sp = USA |doors=Conventional doors (front)
[[Gull-wing doors|Falcon wing doors]] (rear)}} The '''Tesla Model X''' is a [[mid-size]] [[electric car|all-electric]] [[luxury car|luxury]] [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] made by [[Tesla, Inc.]]. The vehicle is unique in the concept that it uses [[falcon wing doors]] instead of traditional automotive doors. The Model X was developed from the [[full-size car|full-sized sedan]] platform of the [[Tesla Model S]]. The Model X has an EPA Size Class as an [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=36979&id=36980|title=2016 Tesla Model X AWD – 90D and P90D, Fuel economy and specs|author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=September 26, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015}} and shares ~30% of its content with the Model S, half of the originally planned ~60%, and weighs about 10 percent more. Both the Model X and Model S are being produced at the [[Tesla Factory]] in [[Fremont, California]]. The [[concept car|prototype]] was unveiled at Tesla's design studios in [[Hawthorne, California]] on February 9, 2012.{{cite news|last=Garrett|first=Jerry|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/09/tesla-unveils-model-x-at-its-design-studios/|title=Tesla Unveils Model X at Its Southern California Design Studios|date=February 9, 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=February 10, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Evans|first=Huw|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/tesla-reveals-model-x-prototype-36391/|title=Tesla Reveals Model X Prototype|date=February 10, 2012|accessdate=February 10, 2012|website=HybridCars.com}} First deliveries of the Model X began in September 2015. After one full year on the market, in 2016, the Model X ranked seventh among the world's best-selling plug-in cars. As of February 14, 2020, the Model X is only available as the Long Range Plus with an estimated EPA range of {{Convert|351|miles|km|abbr=}} and the Performance model with an estimated EPA range of {{Convert|305|miles|km|abbr=}}.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modelx/design|title=Design Your Model X {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|language=en|access-date=2020-03-25}}{{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2020/02/14/tesla-releases-long-range-plus-model-s-x-with-390-351-mile-range-new-wheels/|title=Tesla releases 'Long Range Plus' Model S/X with 390/351 mile range, new wheels|last=Dow|first=Jameson|date=2020-02-15|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-25}} ==History== Initially, Tesla planned for deliveries to commence in early 2014.{{cite web|title=Geneva show: Tesla Model X |url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/www.autocar.co.uk/News/NewsArticle/AllCars/261282/ |website=Autocar |accessdate=March 14, 2013}} However, in February 2013, the company announced that deliveries had been rescheduled to begin by late 2014 in order to achieve its production target of 20,000 [[Tesla Model S|Model S]] cars in 2013.{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-tesla-to-repay-federal-loans-five-years-early-20130308,0,5843577.story|title=Tesla plans to repay loans early, delays Model X|author=Ronald D. White|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=March 8, 2013|accessdate=March 10, 2013}} In November 2013, Tesla said it expected to begin Model X high volume production the second quarter of 2015.{{cite news |last=Young|first=Angelo|title=Tesla Model X Release Date: Superficial Production Next Year; Deliveries To Customers In Full Effect Later|url= http://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-model-x-release-date-superficial-production-next-year-deliveries-customers-full-effect-later |newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=November 6, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2014}} In November 2014, Tesla again delayed and announced that Model X deliveries would begin in the third quarter of 2015.{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2014/11/05/tesla-model-x-delayed-again/|title=Tesla Model X delayed, again, but Musk says Model S demand remains high |author=Sebastian Blanco|publisher=Autoblog Green |date=November 5, 2014|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} Deliveries began on September 29, 2015. Among the reasons for delay were problems with the falcon-wing doors and cooling the motors when hauling trailers.{{cite news |first=John |last=Voelcker |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1096685_why-tesla-model-x-electric-suv-is-late-range-towing-falcon-doors/page-2 |title=Why Tesla Model X Electric SUV Is Late: Range, Towing, 'Falcon Doors' |website=Green Car Reports |date=February 9, 2015|accessdate=April 8, 2015}} In 2016, the company filed a lawsuit against Swiss hydraulics firm Hoerbiger Holding for not producing satisfactory [[Gull-wing door|falcon-wing]] doors for the Model X. Tesla claimed the doors suffered from oil leakage and overheating. Many believe this is one of the reasons for the delay of the Model X.{{cite news |title=Tesla sues Model X falcon wing door supplier |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/01/25/tesla-model-x-falcon-wing-supplier-lawsuit/ |website=Autoblog |date=January 26, 2016 |accessdate=February 13, 2016 }} The lawsuit was settled in September 2016.{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/09/27/tesla-settles-in-court-with-supplier-over-the-development-of-the-model-xs-falcon-wing-doors/ |title=Tesla settles court case with supplier over the development of the Model X's Falcon Wing doors|website=Electrek|accessdate=September 27, 2016}} On July 29, 2015, Tesla announced a [[Referral marketing|referral program]] though October 31, 2015 wherein owners of a Model S who refer 10 new buyers gain the option to buy a Founder Series Model X for the price of a base model. The first person (in each of three regions; Americas, Europe, Asia-Pacific) to reach this 10 referral point would be given this model for free.{{cite web|url= https://www.theverge.com/2015/7/29/9068871/tesla-referral-program-free-model-x |title=Want a free Tesla Model X? Convince ten people to buy a Model S right now|author=Chris Ziegler|date= July 29, 2015 |accessdate=September 11, 2015 |website=theverge.com }}[http://www.teslamotors.com/support/referral-program Referral Program] [https://web.archive.org/web/20150826182322/http://www.teslamotors.com/support/referral-program Different archive, from 26 August 2015] ''Tesla''. Retrieved September 13, 2015. On July 13, 2016, Tesla introduced its Model X 60D, which is slightly lower priced than the Model X's starting price. The Model X 60D has a {{cvt|200|mi|km}} range and can accelerate from {{cvt|0|to|60|mph}} in 6 seconds, with a top speed of {{cvt|130|mph}}.{{Citation |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/lowercase-x-tesla-launches-lower-priced-model-x-60d |title= Lowercase x: Tesla Launches Lower-Priced Model X 60D |date=July 13, 2016 |first=Bengt |last=Halvorson |magazine=[[Car and Driver]] }} The battery capacity in the Model X 60D is 75kWh but has been software restricted to 60kWh. Post purchase, owners have the option to unlock the additional 15kWh bringing the 60D to 75D range specifications.Mark Lelinwalla, TechCrunch. "[https://techcrunch.com/2016/07/13/tesla-introduces-a-more-affordable-model-x/ Tesla introduces a more affordable Model X]." July 13, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://insideevs.com/tesla-model-x-60d-upgrade-75d-now-just-4500/|title=Tesla Model X 60D Upgrade To 75D Now Just $4,500|date=2017-04-27|website=Inside EVs|language=en-US|access-date=2019-01-28}} Tesla plans to use the Model X platform for the Tesla Minibus.{{cite web|url= http://electrek.co/2016/07/29/tesla-minibus-model-x-chassis-elon-musk/ |title=Tesla will leverage the Model X chassis to build its 'Minibus', says Elon Musk|website=Electrek |date=July 27, 2016 |accessdate=July 29, 2016}} Global sales passed the 10,000 unit mark in August 2016, with most cars delivered in the United States. In August 2016, Tesla introduced the P100D with Ludicrous Mode to be the new top Model X. The P100D has a 100 kWh battery, accelerate from {{cvt|0|to|60|mph}} in 2.9 seconds ({{cvt|0|to|100|kph}} in 3.1 seconds) and {{cvt|289|mi}} of range.[https://electrek.co/2016/08/23/tesla-100-kwh-battery-pack-quickest-car-ever/ Tesla claims 'Quickest Production Car in the World' title with new 100 kWh battery pack: 0–60 in 2.5s & 315 mile range] Electrek, August 23, 2016. In October 2016 Tesla discontinued the 60D version and made the "Smart Air Suspension" standard instead of coil springs, increasing the base price to $85,000.{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/10/07/tesla-increases-base-price-model-x-smart-air-suspension-standard/ |title=Tesla increases base price of the Model X by making the 'Smart Air Suspension' standard|date= October 7, 2016 |website=Electrek |accessdate=October 7, 2016}}{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/10/08/tesla-discontinues-model-x-60d/ |title=Tesla discontinues the Model X 60D with software-limited 75 kWh battery pack|date= October 8, 2016 |website=Electrek |accessdate=October 8, 2016}} In June 2017, the 90D version was discontinued. Global cumulative sales since inception totaled 106,689 units through September 2018. In January 2019, Tesla discontinued the 75D version, making the 100D the base version of the Model X. The base price of the Model X 100D is $97,000 as of Jan 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/|title=Electric Cars, Solar Panels & Clean Energy Storage {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|access-date=2019-01-28}} In July 2019, Tesla added a Long Range model of the Model X with a 325-mile EPA range priced at $84,500{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modelx|title=Model X {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|access-date=2019-07-16}}{{multiple image | align = left | total_width = 360 | image1=Tesla Model X Geneva 2012 trimmed.jpg | alt1= | caption1= Tesla Model X concept in Tesla design studio in [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]], California, February 9, 2012 | image2=Tesla Model X prototype at the Texas Capitol, Austin, 15th of January 2015 04.jpg | caption2= Early prototype Tesla Model X steering wheel with main dashboard {{convert|12.3|in|cm|adj=on}} digital display (left) and central {{convert|17|in|cm|adj=on}} [[touchscreen]] control panel (right) | alt2= }} {{-}} In March 2018 it was announced that Tesla upgraded the MCU to version 2.{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-s-x-mcu-upgrade-faster-display/|title=Tesla Model S/X gets updated MCU for faster, more responsive touchscreen display|last=Alvarez|first=Simon|date=2018-03-14|website=TESLARATI|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-21}} MCU 2 improved the performance of the 17 inch center console screen. ==Design== {{multiple image | total_width = 475 | align = right | caption_align = center | image1 = 2016 Tesla Model X in Lantana Florida 1of2.jpg | caption1 = Side | image2 = 2017 Tesla Model X 100D Rear.jpg | caption2 = Rear | footer_background = | footer_align = center | footer = | direction = | alt1 = }} A series production vehicle was unveiled on September 29, 2015. It has a panoramic [[windshield]]. According to Tesla CEO [[Elon Musk]], it is the safest SUV in terms of frontal and side impact crash, being more than twice as safe as the next closest SUV in [[Vehicle rollover|rollover]] tests as well. The Model X does come with Autopilot as standard, and has an optional [[Tesla Autopilot#Hardware 3|Full Self Driving]] chip. The Model X has standard a [[collision avoidance system]] that uses radar-based autonomous emergency braking (AEB) and side-directed ultrasound detection that steers the car away from threats. Tesla uses a wide-band radar system to help prevent the falcon wing doors from hitting nearby objects when opening or closing. The Model X has double-hinged falcon wing doors which open upwards, allowing the leading edge of the door to remain tucked close to the body, unlike traditional gull-wing doors. Tesla claims the falcon-wing (modified gull-wing) doors ease access to the vehicle by having the door raise up vertically, rather than swinging out hinged at the front, which tremendously reduces accessibility. The Model X offers room for seven adults and their luggage in three rows of seating and front and rear trunks. ==Specifications== [[File:FoS20162016 0625 104642AA (27867778826).jpg|thumb|The Model X has double-hinged [[gullwing doors|falcon doors]]]] [[File:Tesla Model S & X side by side at the Gilroy Supercharger.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|The [[Tesla Model S]] (left) and Model X (right) share the same platform and 30% of their parts]] The Model X weighs about 8% more than the Model S and shares about 30% of its parts content – down from around 60% expected when development began. The cargo space is 87.8 ft³.{{cite web |last1=Lambert |first1=Fred |title=Tesla updates Model X with new front seats for more space and seat pockets |url=https://electrek.co/2019/10/29/tesla-updates-model-x-front-seats/ |website=Electrek |date=October 29, 2019}} Over the years, the Model X has been available with four [[lithium-ion battery]] packs, rated at either 60, 75, 90, or 100 [[kilowatt hour|kW·h]]. The highest performance version of the model P100D goes from [[0 to 60 mph]] (0 to 97 km/h) in 2.7 seconds{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modelx |title=Model X {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com |access-date=March 13, 2017}} and the {{convert|1/4|mi|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} in 11.4 seconds,[http://www.dragtimes.com/Tesla-Model-X-Timeslip-28976.html Tesla Model X Timeslip] – DragTimes outperforming the fastest SUVs and most sports cars.{{cite web|title=Model X |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/modelx |publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=August 23, 2012}}{{cite web|url= http://gas2.org/2015/09/04/tesla-model-x-acceleration-vs-competing-suvs-more-spy-pics/ |title=Tesla Model X Acceleration vs Competing SUVs (+ More Spy Pics)|website=Gas 2}} The Model X's [[four-wheel drive|all-wheel-drive]] system uses two motors (one for the front and the other for the rear wheels), unlike conventional AWD systems that have a single source of power. The Tesla Model X 100D{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2017/07/01/tesla-new-performance-enhancements-model-s-model-x/ |title=Tesla introduces new performance enhancements to Model S and Model X |first=Fred |last=Lambert |website=Electrek |date=2017-07-01 |access-date=2017-07-01}} has an official EPA rated range of up to {{cvt|325|mi}}.{{Cite news|url= http://www.autoguide.com/auto-news/2017/01/tesla-model-s-model-x-lineups-bolstered-by-new-variant.html |title=Tesla Model S, Model X Get 100D Variant with World's Best Range » AutoGuide.com News|date=January 20, 2017|website=AutoGuide.com News|access-date=March 13, 2017|language=en-US}} The company planned to offer [[rear-wheel drive|rear-wheel-drive]] models, but instead all models use [[all wheel drive|all-wheel drive]]. The standard AWD has {{convert|259|hp|kW|abbr=off}} on both the front and rear motors, while the performance edition has {{cvt|259|hp|kW}} front and {{cvt|503|hp|kW}} rear.{{cite web|title = Model X – Tesla Motors|url = http://www.teslamotors.com/modelx|website = www.teslamotors.com |accessdate = September 30, 2015}}{{cite web |url= https://cleantechnica.com/2015/09/23/jb-straubel-burns-trolls-tesla-horsepower-critics/ |title= JB Straubel Answers (Trolls?) Tesla Horsepower Critics |date=September 23, 2015|publisher= Clean Technica |author= Zachary Shahan }} With an optional [[towbar]], the Model X has a towing capacity of up to 5000 lb{{cite web|last1=Woodyard|first1=Chris |title=First drive: Tesla Model X is an awesome way to spend $132,000|url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2015/09/30/tesla-model-x-first-drive/73089304/ |website=usatoday.com|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=September 30, 2015}} or 2250 kg.{{cite web |title=Model X Owners Manual (2019.36.1 United Kingdom) |url=https://www.tesla.com/sites/default/files/model_x_owners_manual_europe_en_gb.pdf |accessdate=December 30, 2019}} At the [[Speed limits in the United States by jurisdiction#California|{{cvt|55|mph}} towing speed limit in California]],{{cite web|url= http://www.edmunds.com/tesla/model-x/2016/long-term-road-test/2016-tesla-model-x-range-and-charging-while-towing-a-trailer.html |title=Range and Charging While Towing a Trailer – 2016 Tesla Model X Long-Term Road Test|date=June 29, 2010|website=Edmunds|accessdate=September 9, 2016}} a Model X may have 70% of the {{cvt|257|mi}} EPA-registered range when pulling a {{cvt|2,300|lb}} [[travel trailer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/04/07/with-trailer-tesla-model-x-keeps-70-of-ev-range/ |title=With trailer, Tesla Model X keeps 70% of EV range|date=April 7, 2016|website=Autoblog |accessdate=September 9, 2016}} ===Energy consumption=== [[File:Tesla-type-1-inlet-tesla02-outlet-iec-type-2-outlet-cropped.jpg|thumb|[[SAE J1772]] inlet (North America; left); Tesla02 outlet (North America; centre). IEC [[Type 2 connector]] female outlet (Europe/Rest of World; right). Charge speed is up to 200kW.{{cite web |last1=Dow |first1=Jameson |title=Tesla releases "Long Range Plus" Model S/X with 390/351 mile range, new wheels |url=https://electrek.co/2020/02/14/tesla-releases-long-range-plus-model-s-x-with-390-351-mile-range-new-wheels/ |website=Electrek |date=February 15, 2020}}]] The following table shows the EPA's official ratings for fuel economy in [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPGe) for the variants of the Model X rated {{as of|2015|09|30|lc=y}} and as displayed in the [[Monroney label]]. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto; text-align: center; style="float: left;" |+ 2016 Tesla Model X fuel economy and operating costs |- ! rowspan=2 | Model ! rowspan=2 | Model
year ! colspan=3 | Fuel efficiency (MPGe) |- ! Combined ! City ! Highway |- | AWD 90D

Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date= September 2015 |accessdate= August 23, 2016}}{{cite web|url= https://www.teslacentral.com/p90d-tesla-cars-can-be-upgraded-p100d-price |title=P90D Tesla cars can be upgraded to P100D — for a price |website=Tesla Central|date=August 23, 2016|accessdate=August 23, 2016}} | 2016 | 89; 38 kWh/100 mi

or 24 kWh/100 km |} {{-}} ==Production and sales== [[File:Receiving Tesla Model X (VIN 2).jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|[[Elon Musk]] delivering one of the first six Model X (VIN 0002) Founders Series models to Tesla board member [[Steve Jurvetson]]]] Tesla started taking reservations for the Model X in February 2012 without announcing prices.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/tesla-model-x-reservations-hit-500-24-hours-38538/|title=Tesla Model X Reservations Hit 500 in 24 Hours|website=HybridCars.com}} The standard Model X required a {{USD|5,000}} deposit, while the limited time production Signature model required a {{USD|40,000}} deposit in 2013.{{cite news|url= http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/12/tesla-model-x-production-wont-start-until-late-2014/?ref=automobiles |title=Tesla Model X Production Won't Start Until Late 2014|author=Bradley Berman|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 12, 2013 |accessdate=March 12, 2013}} More than 20,000 Model Xs had been reserved by September 2014.{{cite web|url= http://green.autoblog.com/2014/09/11/tesla-model-x-reservations-20000-strong-and-counting/ |title=Tesla Model X reservations 20,000 strong and counting|author=Danny King|website=Autoblog}} In August 2015, user groups estimated around 30,000 Model X [[pre-order]]s had been received, compared to 12,000 for the Model S.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessfinancenews.com/23587-tesla-motors-inc-model-x-preorders-cross-30000-units/|title=Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Model X Pre-Orders Cross 30,000 Units|website=businessfinancenews.com|quote=The table formed by TMC reveals that the electric vehicle (EV) company has received 30,027 Model X reservations worldwide. – The sedan was able to receive only 12,000 pre-orders ahead of its launch.|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926151030/http://www.businessfinancenews.com/23587-tesla-motors-inc-model-x-preorders-cross-30000-units/|archivedate=September 26, 2015|df=mdy-all}} The first six Founders Series models were delivered at a market launch event in the Fremont factory on September 29, 2015.{{cite web|url= http://www.greencarcongress.com/2015/09/20140930-modelx.html |title=Tesla CEO Musk launches Model X electric SUV: "safest SUV ever"|author=Mike Millikin|publisher=Green Car Congress|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015}} The first Signature edition was delivered on December 18, 2015.{{cite web |url= http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/showthread.php/59174-Signature-1-delivered-today |date=December 18, 2015 |accessdate=December 19, 2015 |title=Signature #1 delivered today |website=Tesla Motors Club}} Pricing for the limited edition Signature version of the Model X varies between {{USD|132,000}} and {{USD|144,000}},{{cite news|url= https://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/03/tesla-signature-series-model-x-to-begin-delivery-september-29.html |title=Tesla Signature series Model X to begin delivery September 29|agency=[[Reuters]] |publisher=CNBC |date=September 3, 2015 |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} while the standard production version of the Model X will be priced at {{USD|5,000}} more than a comparably equipped AWD Model S that is priced at {{USD|75,000}} for the base Model 70D.{{cite web|title = Tesla's long-delayed Model X SUV hits the road as sales of luxury SUVs are booming|url = https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2015/09/29/teslas-first-suv-the-model-x-is-finally-hitting-the-road |accessdate = September 30, 2015}} After the first quarter of 2016 all Tesla Model X deliveries had gone to US customers. Nevertheless, in January 2016 a Tesla car other than the Model S was registered in Germany and a Tesla Model X was sighted driving there with a license plate from [[Ingolstadt]]. Since the [[Audi]] headquarters are located in Ingolstadt, this led to speculation that Audi has acquired a Tesla Model X as part of its effort to develop its own battery-electric SUV.{{cite news|url= http://teslamag.de/news/erstes-tesla-model-x-deutschland-6849 |title= Erstes Tesla Model X in Deutschland gesichtet |website= teslamag.de |date= January 31, 2016 |accessdate= April 10, 2016 |trans-title= First Tesla Model X sighted in Germany |language=de}}{{cite news|url= http://teslamag.de/news/tesla-fahrzeugzulassungen-in-deutschland-fuer-januar-2016-6911 |title= Tesla: Fahrzeugzulassungen in Deutschland für Januar 2016 |website= teslamag.de |date= February 5, 2016 |accessdate= April 10, 2016 |trans-title= Tesla: Vehicle registrations in Germany for January 2016 |language=de}}{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/04/19/audi-charge-tesla-model-x-reverse-engineering/ |title=Audi is reverse-engineering/benchmarking a Tesla Model X but doesn't know how to charge it|first=Fred |last=Lambert|date= April 19, 2016 |website=Electrek |accessdate=December 26, 2016 }} Tesla produced 507 Model X in the fourth quarter of 2015, of which 206 were delivered to customers.{{cite web| url= http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/456867397x0x874449/945B9CF5-86DA-4C35-B03C-4892824F058D/Q4_15_Tesla_Update_Letter.pdf | title=Tesla Fourth Quarter & Full Year 2015 Update | author= Tesla Motors|publisher=Tesla Motors|date=February 10, 2016|accessdate=August 4, 2016}} ''A total of 17,478 units were delivered globally during the fourth quarter of 2015, including 206 Model X vehicles. Model S sales in the United States totaled 16,689 units in 2014 and 25,202 in 2015.'' Model X sales totaled 2,400 units during the first quarter of 2016.{{cite press release |url= http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tesla-delivers-14820-vehicles-in-q1-2016-on-track-for-full-year-delivery-guidance-nasdaq-tsla-2111728.htm | title=Tesla Delivers 14,820 Vehicles in Q1 2016; On Track for Full-Year Delivery Guidance |publisher=Market Wired |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 4, 2016}} According to Tesla Motors, deliveries were lower than expected because production was impacted by severe Model X supplier parts shortages in the first two months of 2016, and because Tesla had been too ambitious in wanting advanced features (committed "[[hubris]]"). The first Model X that didn't need corrections was made in April 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/05/05/tesla-model-3-manufacturing-process/ |title=With Model 3, Tesla will approach manufacturing in a new way |first=Sebastion |last=Blanco |website=Autoblog |date=May 5, 2016 |access-date=July 25, 2016}} {{Bar chart | float = left | title = Tesla Model X global sales by quarter | bar_width = 25 | width_units = em | label_type = Quarter | label1 = Q3 2015 | label2 = Q4 2015 | label3 = Q1 2016 | label4 = Q2 2016 | label5 = Q3 2016 | label6 = Q4 2016{{cite press release |url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tesla-q4-2016-production-and-deliveries-nasdaq-tsla-2186031.htm | title=Tesla Q4 2016 Production and Deliveries |publisher=Market Wired |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=January 3, 2017 |accessdate=January 4, 2017|quote=''Tesla delivered approximately 22,200 vehicles in Q4, of which 12,700 were Model S and 9,500 were Model X.''}} | label7 = Q1 2017{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=1019685 | title=Tesla Q1 2017 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |publisher=Market Wired |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=April 2, 2017 |accessdate=April 4, 2017 |quote=''Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) delivered just over 25,000 vehicles in Q1, of which approx 13,450 were Model S and approx 11,550 were Model X. ''}} | label8=Q2 2017 | label9=Q3 2017 | label10=Q4 2017{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=1053245 | title=Tesla Q4 2017 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |publisher=Market Wired |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=January 3, 2018 |accessdate=January 19, 2018 |quote=''Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) delivered 29,870 vehicles, of which 15,200 were Model S, 13,120 were Model X, and 1,550 were Model 3''}} | label11=Q1 2018{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q1-2018-vehicle-production-and-deliveries | title=Tesla Q1 2018 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=April 3, 2018|accessdate=October 2, 2018 |quote=''Q1 deliveries totaled 29,980 vehicles, of which 11,730 were Model S, 10,070 were Model X, and 8,180 were Model 3.''}} | label12=Q2 2018{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q2-2018-vehicle-production-and-deliveries | title=Tesla Q2 2018 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=July 2, 2018|accessdate=October 2, 2018 |quote=''Q2 deliveries totaled 40,740 vehicles, of which 18,440 were Model 3, 10,930 were Model S, and 11,370 were Model X.''}} | label13=Q3 2018{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q3-2018-vehicle-production-and-deliveries | title=Tesla Q3 2018 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=October 2, 2018|accessdate=October 2, 2018| quote=''Q2 deliveries totaled 40,740 vehicles, of which 18,440 were Model 3, 10,930 were Model S, and 11,370 were Model X.''}} | label14=Q4 2018{{cite press release |url=https://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q4-2018-vehicle-production-deliveries-also-announcing-2000 | title=Tesla Q4 2018 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=January 2, 2019|accessdate=June 22, 2019 |quote=''This included 63,150 Model 3 (13% growth over Q3), 13,500 Model S, and 14,050 Model X vehicles.''}} | data_type = Units sold | data_max = 14000 | data1 = 6 | data2 = 206 | data3 = 2400 | data4 = 4638 | data5 = 8774 | data6 = 9500 | data7 = 11,550 | data8=10,000 | data9=11,865 | data10=13,120 | data11=10,070 | data12=11,370 | data13=13,190 | data14=14,050 }} Sales during the second quarter of 2016 totaled 4,638 units. Although production was up 20% from the previous quarter, the number of vehicles in transit at the end of June 2016 was much higher than expected (5,150 including Model S cars), representing 35.8% of the number of cars delivered in the quarter (14,402 vehicles including the Model S).{{cite press release | url=http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/2563692152x0x903036/562D56A1-5426-4D79-8B99-3408D1B60226/Q2_16_Update_Letter_-_final.pdf | title=Tesla Second Quarter 2016 Update |publisher=[[Tesla Motors]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] | date=August 3, 2016 |accessdate=August 3, 2016}} ''During the second quarter of 2016 Tesla Motors delivered 14,402 new vehicles consisting of 9,764 Model S and 4,638 Model X. Production during 2Q 2016 totaled 18,345 vehicles.''{{cite press release |url=http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=978031 | title=Tesla Q2 2016 Vehicle Production and Deliveries |publisher=[[Tesla Motors]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] | date=July 3, 2016 |accessdate=July 3, 2016}} Global sales passed the 10,000 unit mark in August 2016.{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/tesla-model-x-crosses-the-10000-sold-mark/ |title=Tesla Model X Crosses The 10,000 Sold Mark | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=September 14, 2016 | accessdate=September 15, 2016}} A total of 8,774 units were delivered in the third quarter of 2016, totaling 15,812 Model X cars sold during the first nine months of 2016.{{cite web |url=http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/3100729770x0x913801/F9E5C36A-AFDD-4FF2-A375-ED9B0F912622/Q3_16_Update_Letter_-_final.pdf | title=Tesla Third Quarter 2016 Update |author=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |location=[[Palo Alto]] |date=October 26, 2016 |accessdate=October 27, 2016}} The Model X ranked as the top-selling [[plug-in electric car]] in Norway in September 2016.{{cite news | url=http://www.dinside.no/937121/elbil-eller-ladbar-hybrid | title=Bilsalget september 2016 - Full fart forover! |language=Norwegian |trans-title=Car sales in September 2016 - Full speed ahead! | author= Fred Magne Skillebæk | website=Dinside.no | date=October 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 11, 2016}} However, when [[Volkswagen Golf Mk7|Volkswagen Golf]] nameplate registrations are broken down by each variant's [[powertrain]], the all-electric [[Volkswagen e-Golf|e-Golf]] registered 392 units, the [[Volkswagen Golf GTE|Golf GTE]] plug-in hybrid 358, and the internal combustion-powered Golf only 242 units. Therefore, the Model X also ranked as the top-selling new car model in September 2016.{{cite web |url=http://ev-sales.blogspot.com.br/2016/10/norway-september-2016.html | title=Norway September 2016 | last=Jose | first=Pontes | publisher=EVSales.com| date=October 12, 2016 | accessdate=October 12, 2016}} Norway was the world's first country to have all-electric cars topping the new car sales monthly ranking. Previously, the Model S had been the top-selling new car four times, and the [[Nissan Leaf]] twice.{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/almost-half-the-cars-bought-in-norway-last-month-were-electrified/ | title=Almost Half The Cars Bought In Norway Last Month Were Electrified | first=Jeff | last=Cobb| website=HybridCars.com| date=October 11, 2016| accessdate=October 11, 2016}} [[File:Tesla Model X SUVs York, Virginia.jpg|thumb|Multiple Model X cars parked]] According to Tesla, with 5,428 units sold in the U.S. in the third quarter of 2016, the Model X captured a 6% [[market share]] of the luxury SUV market segment, outselling Porsche and Land Rover, but behind seven SUV models manufactured by Mercedes, BMW, Cadillac, Volvo, Audi, and Lexus.{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-12/tesla-dominates-u-s-luxury-sedan-sales | title=Tesla Dominates U.S. Luxury Sedan Sales | first=Tom | last=Randall | website=Bloomberg | date=October 12, 2016 | accessdate=October 14, 2016}} With an estimated 9,500 units delivered worldwide during the fourth quarter of 2016, global sales in 2016 totaled 25,312 Model X cars, allowing the Model X to rank seventh among the world's top ten best-selling plug-in cars just in its first full year in the market.{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/tesla-model-s-is-worlds-best-selling-plug-in-car-for-second-year-in-a-row/ |title=Tesla Model S Is World's Best-Selling Plug-in Car For Second Year In A Row | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | website=HybridCars.com | date=January 31, 2017 |accessdate=January 31, 2017}} {{As of|2016|12}}, cumulative sales totaled 25,524 units since its inception. The United States is its main country market with 18,240 units delivered through December 2016, of which, an estimated 18,028 Model X vehicles were delivered during 2016, making the electric SUV the third best-selling plug-in electric in the American market that year after the Tesla Model S and the [[Chevrolet Volt]].{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/americas-plug-in-car-sales-were-their-best-ever-in-2016/ |title= America's Plug-in Car Sales Were Their Best Ever in 2016 | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | website=HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates | date=January 11, 2017 |accessdate=January 12, 2017}} ''Plug-in electric car sales in the U.S. totaled 157,181 units, up 37.6% from 2015 (114,248). The plug-in car segment achieved an all-time high market share of 0.90% of new car sales in 2016. December sales totaled a record monthly volume of 23,288 units and also achieved a record monthly market share of 1.39% of new car sales. The top selling model for the second year in a row was the Tesla Model S with 29,156 units sold in 2016, followed by the Chevrolet Volt (24,739), Tesla Model X (18,028), Ford Energi Fusion (15,938), and the Nissan Leaf (14,006). {{As of|2016|12}}, cumulative sales totaled 570,187 plug-in cars since 2008, with the Chevrolet Volt as the all-time best selling plug-in car with 113,489 units. The Tesla Model S ranks third with an estimated 92,317 units since its inception in 2012.'' Registrations in California totaled 6,289 units in 2016, representing a 7.0% market share of the state's luxury mid-size SUV segment, ranking as the fifth best-selling car in this class, which was led by the [[Lexus RX]] with 20,070 units.{{cite web | url=http://www.cncda.org/CMS/Pubs/CA%20Auto%20Outlook%204Q%202016.pdf | title=State New Vehicle Market Up Slightly in 2016; Similar Outlook for 2017 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) | publisher=CNCDA | date=February 2017 | accessdate=February 24, 2017 | volume=13 |number=1}} ''Registrations through December 2016 since 2012. Revised figures for 2015.'' Retail deliveries in China began in June 2016, and a total of 4,065 Model X vehicles were sold in 2016.{{better source|date=November 2017}}{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bertelschmitt/2017/03/04/teslas-sudden-chinese-billion-where-are-the-cars-behind-it/2/#380b62515299 |title=Tesla's Sudden Chinese Billion, Where Are The Cars Behind It? | first=Bertel | last=Schmitt | magazine=[[Forbes]] | date=March 4, 2017 | accessdate=March 6, 2017}} Global sales totaled about 11,550 units during the first quarter of 2017. A severe production shortfall of 100 kWh battery packs limited the second quarter of 2017 global deliveries to just about 10,000 Model X vehicles,{{Cite web|url=http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=1032479 |title=UPDATE - Tesla Q2 2017 Vehicle Production and Deliveries (NASDAQ:TSLA)|website=ir.tesla.com|language=en |access-date=2017-09-28}} with a slight increase to 11,865 vehicles during the third quarter of 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=1042449 |title=Telsa Production Q3 2017|last=|first= |date=|website= |access-date=}} An additional 13,120 units were delivered in the fourth quarter of 2017, for total annual deliveries of 46,535 units globally. {{As of|2017|12}}, cumulative sales since inception totaled about 72,059 units. Global sales during the first nine months of 2018 totaled 34,630 units, allowing the Model X to pass the 100,000 milestone in September 2018, with 106,689 units delivered since inception. ==Reception== ''[[Consumer Reports]]'' wrote that the all-wheel-drive Model X 90D largely disappoints, as rear doors are prone to pausing and stopping, the second-row seats that cannot be folded, and the cargo capacity is too limited. Even its panoramic, helicopter-like windshield was disapproved of as it is not tinted enough to offset the brightness of a sunny day. Also, Consumer Reports added that overall "the ride is too firm and choppy for a $110,000 car".[http://www.consumerreports.org/suvs/2016-tesla-model-x-review/ 2016 Tesla Model X Review: Fast and Flawed – Consumer Reports] ''[[Car and Driver]]'', despite some criticism of the Model X's falcon wing doors, approved of the panoramic windshield, stating "We were left dumbfounded, like slack-jawed tourists endlessly looking upward. Lose the Falcon Wing doors, Elon; the windshield is the Model X's best gimmick". Overall, it was given a rating of 5/5 stars, stating "There are no other electric SUVs at the moment. And even against fossil-fuel-fed SUVs, the Tesla's effortless performance and efficiency can't be matched." ''[http://www.caranddriver.com/tesla/model-x Car and Driver: Tesla Model X]'', May 2016. Accessed June 5, 2017 Motoring journalist [[Jeremy Clarkson]]'s made his first review of a Tesla vehicle after 10 years on his TV show [[The Grand Tour (TV series)|''The Grand Tour'']] in February 2018; Clarkson gave a positive review of the car that he called "fabulous" that is unlike anything on the road. Lawyers were present during the review presumably because Clarkson's previous scathing review of the original [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Roadster]] caused a lawsuit.{{cite news|url=http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2018/02/jeremy-clarkson-and-the-grand-tour-admit-many-nice-things-about-the-tesla-model-x/|title=Jeremy Clarkson and The Grand Tour Admit Many Nice Things About the Tesla Model X|first=Tom|last=Pritchard|date=12 February 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|website=[[Gizmodo]] UK|quote=Model X got reviewed on ''The Grand Tour''. … ten years since Jeremy Clarkson reviewed a Tesla car}} ==Awards== On November 16, 2015, the Tesla Model X was chosen as AutoGuide.com's 2016 Reader's Choice ''Green Car of the Year'' and ''Luxury Utility Vehicle of the Year'' awards. The model was noted for its falcon-wing doors, long range, efficiency, and acceleration.''[http://www.autoguide.com/auto-news/2015/11/tesla-model-x-wins-2016-autoguide-com-reader-s-choice-green-car-of-the-year-award.html Tesla Model X Wins 2016 AutoGuide.com Reader's Choice Green Car of the Year Award]'', November 16, 2015. Retrieved March 23, 2018. On November 8, 2016 the Model X was awarded the Golden Steering Wheel ({{lang|de|Das Goldene Lenkrad}}), one of the most prestigious automotive awards in the world, in the "Large SUV" category. Candidates for this award are nominated by hundreds of thousands across Europe for excellence across six categories. The Golden Steering Wheel jury, composed of professional race car drivers, accomplished technicians, editors, designers, and digital and connectivity experts, then spent three days judging Model X.{{cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/blog/model-x-wins-golden-steering-wheel|title=Model X Wins the Golden Steering Wheel|date=November 8, 2016|website=www.tesla.com|publisher=Tesla Motors|access-date=November 8, 2016}}{{cite news|url= http://www.markenartikel-magazin.de/no_cache/events/artikel/details/10015847-goldenes-lenkrad-2016-ua-fuer-audi-tesla-bmw-und-renault/ |website= www.markenartikel-magazin.de |title= 'Goldenes Lenkrad 2016' u.a. für Audi, Tesla, BMW und Renault |date= November 9, 2016 | accessdate= November 10, 2016 |trans-title= 'Golden Steering Wheel 2016' among others for Audi, Tesla, BMW and Renault |language= de}} On April 18, 2017, the [[American Automobile Association]] named the Tesla Model X 75D its Top Green Vehicle overall, as well as best in the [[SUV]]/[[Minivan]] category,''[http://newsroom.aaa.com/2017/04/consumer-appetite-electric-vehicles-rivals-pickups/ Consumer Appetite for Electric Vehicles Rivals Pickups]'', April 18, 2017. Retrieved June 19, 2017 with a score of 100/130. The vehicle scored 10/10 for its EPA Emissions Score, [[crashworthiness]], Fuel Economy and Luggage Capacity. Though ambivalent toward Autopilot and the Model X's glass roof, AAA favoured its falcon-wing doors, and approved of the vehicle's performance, stating that its "acceleration is smooth and strong, as is the braking."''[http://ww1.aaa.com/services/automotive/greencar/greencar.html#/view/2DDC59BE-A593-4128-945A-027536EA9C1B Green Car Guide, 2017 Edition, Tesla Model X 75D]'', April 18, 2017. Retrieved June 19, 2017 On June 8, 2017, the Model X was awarded the Australian ''Good Design Award'' in the Automotive and Transport category. The design of the vehicle was described as "set with an athletic build, whilst remaining proportional. Delivering on the functional form of a cross between SUV and people mover, the design remains true to a sports SUV." ''[https://www.good-design.com/entry/tesla-model-x/ Good Design Award, Automotive and Transport]'', June 8, 2017. Retrieved June 13, 2017 On December 11, 2017, [[Forbes]] named the Model X 100D ''Best Vehicle of the Year'' stating that "Tesla makes every internal combustion vehicle on the highway seem a clunky, clumsy relic of the 20th century." ''[https://www.forbes.com/sites/joshmax/2017/12/11/teslas-x-100d-is-vehicle-of-the-year-in-our-2017s-best-and-worst/ Tesla's X 100D Is 'Vehicle Of The Year' In Our 2017's 'Best And Worst']'', December 11, 2017. Retrieved March 19, 2018 ==Guinness World Record== On May 15, 2018, the Tesla Model X and [[Qantas]] set the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] for "heaviest tow by an electric production passenger vehicle." The Model X was able to tow a {{convert|287,000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sp=us}} [[Boeing 787|Boeing 787-9]] nearly 1,000 feet on a taxiway at [[Melbourne Airport]], which demonstrates the power of the vehicle, while also {{citation needed|date=December 2019}} proving the practicality of an electric powertrain.{{cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/05/15/technology/tesla-tows-boeing-dreamliner-video/index.html |title=Tesla SUV earns a Guinness World Record for towing massive airplane |author=Valinsky, Jordan |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=May 15, 2018 |accessdate=May 18, 2018}} == Issues with production units == The Tesla Model X faced criticism in 2016 for issues with the falcon-wing doors, which sometimes did not open or latch properly in some early production units, and the windows, which sometimes did not open or close all the way.[https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/20/tesla-model-x-owners-finding-car-doors-wont-shut-windows-wont-close/ Tesla Model X owners finding car doors won't shut, windows won't close] [[TechCrunch]], Retrieved April 20, 2016 Tesla addressed these issues with several software updates, and no known issues remained after the 8.0 firmware was released.{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/10/10/tesla-model-x-falcon-wing-doors-v8-0-software-update/ |title=Tesla Model X's Falcon Wing doors are significantly faster after v8.0 software update|date= October 10, 2016 |website=Electrek|accessdate= October 25, 2016}} On June 27, 2016, Tesla settled on a lawsuit over usability concerns, accepting that the Model X was rushed to production before it was ready,[http://fortune.com/2016/06/27/model-x-lawsuit/ Tesla Settles Lawsuit Over Model X Design Flaws - Fortune] and by October 2016, Tesla claimed the problems had been reduced by 92%.{{cite web|url= https://electrek.co/2016/10/26/tesla-model-x-92-reduction-issue/ |title=Tesla says it reduced Model X issues by 92% amid criticism from Consumer Reports|date=October 26, 2016 |website=Electrek |accessdate=October 26, 2016}} In 2017 Chinese newspaper ''Xinhua'' reported that security researchers from Keen Security Lab at [[Tencent]] were able to remotely gain control of the Tesla Model X, allowing them to remotely open the car's doors, blink the lights and control their brakes. They found [[Zero-day (computing)|zero day]] vulnerabilities that allowed them to install new [[firmware]]. The lead researcher for the team said they informed Tesla of the findings and most of the cars were patched by an update one month after Tesla was made aware of issues.{{Cite web| title = Same Chinese white hat group hacks into Tesla for second year |website=Xinhua |accessdate = 2018-03-20| url = http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/01/c_136489007.htm}} === Recalls === {{As of|2017|10}}, Tesla has had four [[Product recall|product safety recalls]] the Model X.{{cite news| url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/11/tesla-recalls-2700-model-x-cars-for-seat-problem/ | title=Tesla Recalls 2,700 Model X Cars for Seat Problem |first=Katie |last=Fehrenbacher | magazine=Fortune | date=April 11, 2016| accessdate=April 12, 2016}} * On April 11, 2016, Tesla voluntarily recalled 2,700 Model X due to safety concerns. During collision testing, it was found that the third-row seats would unlatch and fold over to the second row. Tesla urged customers to avoid using the third-row seats until after repairs.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslarati.com/tesla-recalls-model-x-third-row-seats/|title=Tesla Recalls Model X Third-Row Seats After Failed Strength Testing |publisher=teslarati.com |accessdate=May 9, 2016}} * On April 20, 2017, Tesla issued a worldwide recall of 53,000 (~70%) of the 76,000 Model S and Model X vehicles it sold in 2016 due to faulty parking brakes that affect the Model S and Model X. The recall caused Tesla stock to lose two percent of their value{{clarify|which day?, and for how long? Tesla stock prices are volatile, and often up and down more than 2 percent|date=July 2019}} and added further questions about the reliability of Tesla's vehicles.{{cite web|url= https://www.nhtsa.gov/vehicle/2016/TESLA/MODEL%252520X%25252060D/SUV/AWD%252520Later%252520Release#recalls |title=2016 TESLA MODEL X 60D SUV AWD LATER RELEASE|publisher=|accessdate=5 November 2017}}https://electrek.co/2017/10/12/tesla-recall-model-x-vehicles/[https://static.nhtsa.gov/odi/rcl/2017/RCLRPT-17V260-8654.PDF Part 573 Safety Recall Report 17V-260] 2017-04-19{{cite news |title=Tesla's real problem isn't that its cars are expensive. It's that they're unreliable. |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/6/9/11880450/tesla-doomed |first=Timothy B. |last=Lee |website=Vox |date=June 10, 2016 |access-date=April 21, 2017}}{{cite news |title=Tesla is recalling most of the cars it sold in 2016 |url=https://www.vox.com/new-money/2017/4/20/15374592/tesla-recall-53000-cars |first=Timothy B. |last=Lee |website=Vox |date=April 20, 2017 |access-date=April 21, 2017}} * In October 2017, Tesla issued an 11,000 vehicle recall for a faulty locking cable mechanism in the second row seats, estimating that about 3% of recalled vehicles may be affected.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-recall/tesla-to-recall-11000-model-x-suvs-due-to-seat-issue-idUSKBN1CH32R Tesla to recall 11,000 Model X SUVs due to seat issue], Reuters * In February 2020, 15,000 vehicles recalled due to potential [[power steering]] issues.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-recall/tesla-recalls-15000-model-x-suvs-for-power-steering-issue-in-north-america-idUSKBN2062XO Tesla recalls 15,000 Model X SUVs for power steering issue in North America], Reuters ==Safety== [[File:V10084P006.jpg|thumb|NHTSA side pole crash test of the 2017 Tesla Model X]] {{ external media |align=right |title=NHTSA test videos 2017 | video1= {{youtube|vCXaR3_r164|Frontal crash}} | video2= {{youtube|scvG5aCl47c|Side crash}} | video3= {{youtube|SjapNSJJT0I|Pole crash}} }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=2 | [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]] 2017{{cite web |url=https://www.nhtsa.gov/vehicle/2019/TESLA/MODEL%252520X%252520P100D/SUV/AWD |title=2019 TESLA MODEL X P100D SUV AWD |publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation |access-date=2019-07-04}}{{cite web |title=Official Tesla Model X 2019 safety rating |url=https://www.euroncap.com/en/results/Tesla/Model-X/39141 |website=www.euroncap.com |publisher=[[Euro NCAP]] |language=en}} |- | Overall || {{rating|5|5}} |- | Frontal, driver || {{rating|5|5}} |- | Frontal, passenger || {{rating|5|5}} |- | [[Side collision|Side, driver]] || {{rating|5|5}} |- | Side, passenger || {{rating|5|5}} |- | Side pole, driver || {{rating|5|5}} |- | [[Vehicle rollover|Rollover]] || {{rating|5|5}} / 9.3% |} On June 13, 2017, the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] announced its crash testing results for the 2017-manufactured Tesla Model X, revealing 5-star ratings in all assessed categories, the only SUV to have done so.''[http://www.businessinsider.com/government-says-tesla-model-x-extremely-safe-suv-2017-6 The government says that the Tesla Model X is an extremely safe SUV]'', Business Insider, Matthew Debord, June 13, 2017. Retrieved June 13, 2017{{unreliable source?|date=November 2017}}{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0zX3z2e9I1M |title=In Depth: Model X the Safest SUV! |date=June 19, 2017|website=YouTube (who?)|accessdate=June 19, 2017}} Tesla attributed the ratings to safety-focused design, in addition to a low centre-of-gravity resulting from its [[automotive battery|battery pack]], adding "More than just resulting in a 5-star rating, the data from NHTSA's testing shows that Model X has the lowest probability of injury of any SUV it has ever tested. In fact, of all the cars NHTSA has ever tested, Model X's overall probability of injury was second only to Model S." [[WP:PRIMARY]] source. ''[https://www.tesla.com/en_CA/blog/tesla-model-x-5-star-safety-rating?redirect=no Tesla Model X the First SUV Ever to Achieve 5-Star Crash Rating in Every Category]'', The Tesla Team, June 13, 2017. The Model X has been tested by [[Euro NCAP]], and has not been tested by the [[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety]]. ==See also== * [[Electric car use by country]] * [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles]] * [[List of modern production plug-in electric vehicles]] * [[List of production battery electric vehicles]] * [[Audi e-tron (2018)]] * [[Jaguar I-Pace]] * [[Mercedes-Benz EQC]] * [[Tesla Model Y]] * [[List of Easter eggs in Tesla products]] *[[Tesla Supercharger]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * {{Official website}} * [https://www.teslamotors.com/sites/default/files/pdfs/2016_Model_X_Emergency_Response_Guide.pdf Emergency Response Guide] * [http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2016/02/07/tesla-allows-cameras-in-fremont-factory-for-rare-tour/ Video of production] * {{YouTube|D4peF1EYke8|Tesla Model X First Responder Training}} {{Tesla Motors}} {{Tesla timeline}} [[Category:Battery electric cars currently in production]] [[Category:Automobiles with gull-wing doors]] [[Category:Electric sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Full-size sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Crossover sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Tesla, Inc. vehicles|Model X]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2015]]

revision.comment: [[User:Monkbot/task_14: repair improper use of publisher params in cs1 templates|Task 14]]: cs1 template fixes: misused |publisher= (0×/21×);
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2019}} {{hatnote|For Tesla's second sports car, see [[Tesla Roadster (2020)]].}} {{short description|Electric convertible sports car produced 2008–2012}} {{Infobox electric vehicle | image = Roadster 2.5 windmills trimmed.jpg | caption = Tesla Roadster Sport 2.5 | manufacturer = [[Tesla, Inc.]] | aka = [[Code name]]: DarkStar | production = 2008–2012 | motor = 3-phase [[dipole|4-pole]] [[AC motor#Three-phase AC induction motors|AC induction motor]]
{{plainlist| *'''1.5''' {{convert|248|hp|abbr=on|order=flip}}, {{convert|200|lbft|abbr=on|order=flip}} *'''2.0, 2.5''' {{convert|288|hp|abbr=on|order=flip}}, {{convert|280|lbft|abbr=on|order=flip}} *'''2.5 Sport''' {{convert|288|hp|abbr=on|order=flip}}, {{convert|295|lbft|abbr=on|order=flip}} }} (claimed) | assembly = [[Hethel]], UK
[[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]], [[California]], U.S. | class = {{bulleted list |[[Small car]] (US)| [[S-segment]] (sports cars) (EU)}} | related = [[Lotus Elise]]
[[Lotus Exige]]
[[Tesla Model S]]
[[Tesla Roadster (2020)]] | body_style = 2-door [[Roadster (automobile)|roadster]] | length = {{convert|3946|mm|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1873|mm|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1127|mm|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|2877|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} | designer = | transmission = Single speed [[BorgWarner]] fixed gear (8.27:1 ratio) | battery = {{convert|53|kWh|abbr=on}} [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion]] at the pack level: 117 Wh/kg and 370 Wh/L) CAC (Capacity) approx. 160 Ah when new | electric_range = {{convert|244|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} using [[United States Environmental Protection Agency#Fuel economy testing and results|EPA combined cycle]] | charging = Proprietary inlet, 16.8 kW (70 A 240 V) with {{abbr|HPWC|high-power wall connector}} outlet{{cite web |url= http://www.teslamotors.com/roadster/charging/high-power-wall-connector |title=High Power Wall Connector|publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=August 16, 2013}} and with the SAE J1772-2009 adapter, adapters for domestic [[Alternating current|AC]] [[AC power plugs and sockets|sockets]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2352|mm|abbr=on}} | layout = [[RMR layout|Rear mid-motor, rear-wheel drive]] | successor = [[Tesla Roadster (2020)]] |sp= us }} The '''Tesla Roadster''' is a [[battery electric vehicle]] (BEV) [[sports car]], based on the [[Lotus Elise]] chassis, that was produced by the [[electric car]] firm Tesla Motors (now [[Tesla, Inc.]]) in [[California]] from 2008 to 2012.
