The Roadster was the first highway legal [[serial production]] all-electric car to use [[lithium-ion battery]] cells and the first production all-electric car to travel more than {{convert|320|km|}} per charge.{{cite web| url=https://cleantechnica.com/2015/04/26/electric-car-history/ | title=Electric Car Evolution |first=Zachary |last= Shahan |publisher=Clean Technica |date = April 26, 2015| accessdate=September 8, 2016}} ''2008: The Tesla Roadster becomes the first production electric vehicle to use lithium-ion battery cells as well as the first production electric vehicle to have a range of over 200 miles on a single charge.'' It is also the first production car to be launched into orbit, carried by a [[Falcon Heavy]] rocket in [[Falcon Heavy Test Flight|a test flight]] on February 6, 2018. Tesla sold about 2,450 Roadsters in over 30 countries,{{cite web|url=http://ir.teslamotors.com/secfiling.cfm?filingid=1193125-13-96241&cik=|title=SEC Form 10-K for Fiscal Year Ended Dec 31, 2012, Commission File Number: 001-34756, Tesla Motors, Inc.|date=February 6, 2016|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]|accessdate=February 25, 2014|quote=As of December 31, 2012, we had delivered approximately 2,450 Tesla Roadsters to customers in over 30 countries.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516203427/http://ir.teslamotors.com/secfiling.cfm?filingid=1193125-13-96241&cik=|archive-date=May 16, 2016|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/toddwoody/2012/07/25/investors-hit-accelerator-despite-tesla-q2-revenue-miss/|title=Tesla Hits Accelerator Despite Q2 Revenue Miss|last=Woody|first=Todd|date=July 25, 2012|magazine=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=July 25, 2012}} ''More than 2,350 units sold through June 2012''.{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/11/tesla-20121105.html |title=Tesla Q3 report: $50M revenues, $111M GAAP net loss, 253 Model S delivered in Q3 |publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=November 5, 2012 |accessdate=November 6, 2012}} ''Sales during the 3Q 2012: 68 Roadsters and 253 Model S.'' and most of the last Roadsters were sold in Europe and Asia during the fourth quarter of 2012. Tesla produced right-hand-drive Roadsters from early 2010.{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2009-06/25/tesla-will-build-right-hand-drive-roadsters-for-the-uk.aspx |title=Tesla will build right-hand-drive Roadsters for the UK |publisher=Wired.co.uk |date=June 25, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626201136/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2009-06/25/tesla-will-build-right-hand-drive-roadsters-for-the-uk.aspx |archivedate=June 26, 2009 }} The Roadster qualified for [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles|government incentives]] in several nations.{{cite web |url= http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/04/acea-tax-20100421.html#more |title=Growing Number of EU Countries Levying CO2 Taxes on Cars and Incentivizing Plug-ins|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=April 21, 2010 |accessdate=May 21, 2010}}{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/feb/25/green-sports-cars-subsidise-taxpayers |title=Electric vehicle grants scheme backfires as taxpayers subsidise £87,000 sports cars|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Adam |last=Vaughan |date=February 25, 2010 |accessdate=May 21, 2010| location=London}} According to the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. EPA]], the Roadster can travel {{convert|244|mi|order=flip}} on a single charge of its lithium-ion battery pack, and can accelerate from {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 3.7 or 3.9 seconds depending on the model. It has a top speed of {{convert|125|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}. The Roadster's efficiency, {{as of|2008|9|lc=on}}, was reported as 120 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent|MPGe]] (2.0 L/100 km). It uses 135 [[Watt-hour|Wh]]/km (21.7 kW·h/100 mi, 13.5 kW·h/100 km or 490 kJ/km) battery-to-wheel, and has an efficiency of 88% on average.{{cite web |url= http://www.teslamotors.com/roadster/technology/motor |title=Roadster Innovations: Motor |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=February 25, 2011 |quote=The Roadster achieves an overall driving efficiency of 88%, about three times the efficiency of a conventional car.}} == History == Prototypes of the car were officially revealed to the public on July 19, 2006, in [[Santa Monica, California]], at a 350-person invitation-only event held in Barker Hangar at [[Santa Monica Airport]].{{cite press release | publisher=Tesla Motors | title=Tesla Motors Hosts World Debut of Tesla Roadster Offering Performance, Style & Efficiency – With a Conscience | url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=42 | date=July 20, 2006 | accessdate=April 24, 2007 }} The San Francisco International Auto Show, held on November 18–26, 2006, was the Tesla Roadster's first auto show. It was featured in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' in December 2006 as the recipient of the magazine's "Best Inventions 2006—Transportation Invention" award.{{cite news |url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1939342_1939392_1939459,00.html |title=Batteries Included - Best Inventions of 2006 |work=Time |location=US |year=2006 |access-date=January 31, 2018}} The first "Signature One Hundred" set of fully equipped Roadsters sold out in less than three weeks, the second hundred sold out by October 2007 and general production began on March 17, 2008. The first Tesla Roadster was delivered in February 2008 to Tesla co-founder, chairman and product architect [[Elon Musk]]. The company produced 500 similar vehicles through June 2009. In July 2009, Tesla began production of its 2010 model-year Roadster—the first major product upgrade.{{cite web |url=https://www.teslamotors.com/display_data.php?data_name=WardsAutoArticle |title=Drive Tesla Roadster; Forget What You Knew About Acceleration |first=Eric |last=Mayne |date=September 4, 2009 |format=PDF |publisher=Wards Auto |accessdate=June 21, 2010}} Simultaneously, Tesla began producing the Roadster Sport, the first derivative of Tesla's proprietary, patented powertrain. The car accelerates from {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 3.7 seconds, compared to 3.9 seconds for the standard Roadster. Changes for the 2010 model-year cars included:{{cite web |url=http://www.automobilesreview.com/auto-news/tesla-roadster-2/16337/ |title=Tesla Roadster 2 |date=July 22, 2009 |publisher=Automobiles review |accessdate=June 21, 2010}} * An upgraded interior and push-button gear selector, including "executive interior" of exposed carbon fiber and premium leather, and clear-coat carbon fiber body accents. * Locking, push-button glove box wrapped in leather. * A centrally mounted video display screen to monitor real-time data, including estimated range, power regenerated, and the number of barrels of oil saved. This screen is visible to the driver and passenger. * Adjustable, custom-tuned suspension. The shock absorbers' response and anti-sway bars are manually adjustable. * More powerful and immediate heating, ventilation and air-conditioning. * More efficient motor and hand-wound stator. The increase in efficiency allows the motor to deliver higher peak power. * A suite of sound-deadening measures to dramatically reduce noise, vibration and harshness. For instance, engineers added pellets to a member of the chassis side rail. These pellets expand by 50 times original volume during the adhesive heating cycle to eliminate rattles. All of these features, except for the motor, were available either as standard or as add-on option for the non-sport model. Beginning mid-March 2010, Tesla, in an effort to show off the practicality of its electric cars, sent one of its Roadsters around the world. Starting at the Geneva auto show, the Roadster completed its journey upon its arrival in Paris on September 28, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-13746_7-20003938-48.html?tag=mncol |title=Globe-trotting Tesla Roadster Reaches Moscow |first=Wayne |last=Cunningham |date=April 30, 2010 |work=The Car Tech Blog |publisher=[[CNET.com]] |accessdate=May 3, 2010}} In July 2010, Tesla introduced the "Roadster 2.5", the latest update of the Roadster.{{cite press release |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-unveils-roadster-25-newest-stores-europe-and-north-america |title=Tesla Unveils Roadster 2.5 at Newest Stores in Europe and North America |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=July 1, 2010 |accessdate=October 9, 2010}} New features in Roadster 2.5 include: * A new look, which included a new front fascia with diffusing vents, and rear diffuser reflecting the future of Tesla design * Directional forged wheels available in both silver and black * New seats with improved comfort, larger more supportive bolsters and a new lumbar support system * Power control hardware that enables spirited driving in exceptionally hot climates * An optional 7" touchscreen display with back-up camera * Improved interior sound reduction including new front fender liner material to make the cabin quieter At the time, the US$112,000 Roadster was the most expensive single prize ever offered, though not won, on ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'', in a playing of [[List of The Price Is Right pricing games|Golden Road]] on April 22, 2010 for Earth Day.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IPq_I_L2UL4 |title= TPiR 4/22/10: Historic Golden Road - TESLA ROADSTER - $112,000+ |accessdate=December 15, 2015}} A Roadster was used as a promotional tool for a [[wind power]] electricity company in 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.vinditanken.dk/ |work=Wind in the tank |title=Wind Energy |language=Danish |accessdate=September 24, 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://www.vinditanken.dk/dokumenter/ViT%20Vindoptimeret%20sammenfatning%20Final.pdf |title=Vindoptimeret opladning af elbiler |trans-title=Wind Optimised Charging Electric Cars |first1=Jørgen |last1=Horstmann |first2=Frank |last2=Nørgaard |work=vinditanken |language=Danish |date=April 25, 2012 |accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Tesla produced the Roadster until January 2012, when its supply of [[Lotus Cars|Lotus]] [[Glider (automobiles)|gliders]] ran out, as its contract with [[Lotus Cars]] for 2,500 gliders expired at the end of 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.mspnews.com/news/2012/02/27/6148529.htm|title=Tesla Motors Inc – 10-K -Management's Discussion And Analysis Of Financial Condition And Results of Operations|publisher=MSP News Channels|date=February 27, 2012|accessdate=August 28, 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20121209210930/http://www.mspnews.com/news/2012/02/27/6148529.htm|archivedate=December 9, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/driveon/post/2011/08/tesla-boasts-about-electric-car-deliveries-plans-for-sedan/1|title=Tesla boasts about electric car deliveries, plans for sedan|first=Chris |last=Woodyard|work=[[USA Today]]|date=August 3, 2011|accessdate=October 4, 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/automobiles/08TESLA.html?_r=1&emc=eta1|title=Tesla Prepares for a Gap as Roadster Winds Down|first=Josie |last=Garthwaite|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 6, 2011|accessdate=May 7, 2011}} Tesla stopped taking orders for the Roadster in the U.S. market in August 2011.Dillow, Clay. (June 23, 2011) [http://www.popsci.com/cars/article/2011-06/farewell-roadster-tesla-will-stop-taking-orders-its-iconic-ev-two-months Farewell Roadster: Tesla Will Stop Taking Orders for its Iconic EV in Two Months | Popular Science]. Popsci.com. Retrieved on 2013-08-10.{{cite web|last=Valdes-Dapena|first=Peter|title=Tesla Roadster reaches the end of the line|url=http://autos.yahoo.com/news/tesla-roadster-reaches-the-end-of-the-line.html|publisher=Yahoo!}} The [[Tesla Roadster (2020)|next generation]] will not be based on the Lotus gliders but instead on a shortened version of the architecture developed for the [[Tesla Model S]].{{cite news|url=http://insideevs.com/tesla-vp-next-gen-tesla-roadster-to-push-ev-envelope-to-the-extreme-will-boast-more-range-and-be-quicker-than-original-roadster/|title=Tesla VP: Next-Gen Tesla Roadster to Push EV Envelope to the Extreme; Will Boast More Range and be Quicker Than Original Roadster|first=Eric |last=Loveday|work=[[Inside EVs]]|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=October 25, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/News/NewsArticle/AllCars/259752/|title=Tesla plans all-new Roadster|first=Mark |last=Tisshaw|work=[[Autocar (magazine)|Autocar]]|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=October 29, 2011}} Featuring new options and enhanced components, the 2012 Tesla Roadster was sold in limited numbers only in Europe, Asia, and Australia. Tesla's U.S. exemption for not having special two-stage passenger airbags expired for cars made after the end of 2011 so the last Roadsters could not be sold in the American market.{{cite web |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2012/01/11/tesla-continues-roadster-sales-in-europe-asia-and-australia/#continued|title=Tesla continues Roadster sales with tweaks in Europe, Asia and Australia|first=Danny |last=King|publisher=[[Autoblog|Autoblog Green]]|date=January 11, 2012|accessdate=January 13, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1071608_tesla-updates-roadster-for-2012-theres-just-one-catch|title=Tesla Updates Roadster For 2012. There’s Just One Catch...|first=Nikki |last=Gordon-Bloomfield|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=January 12, 2012|accessdate=January 16, 2012}} Fifteen Final Edition Roadsters were produced to close the manufacturing cycle of Tesla's first electric car. Tesla announced an optional upgrade to current Roadsters, the Roadster 3.0, in December 2014. It offered a new battery pack from [[LG Chem]]{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100683_lg-chem-adds-tesla-to-customer-list-will-supply-cells-for-roadster-upgrade |title=LG Chem Adds Tesla To Customer List, Will Supply Cells For Roadster Upgrade |first=John |last=Voelcker |work=Green Car Reports |date=October 29, 2015 |accessdate=November 7, 2015}} increasing capacity by 50% to {{convert|70|kWh|abbr=on}}, a new aero kit designed to reduce drag, and new tires with lower [[rolling resistance]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/12/26/tesla_updates_its_original_roadster_electric_car_with_better_batteries_and_new_body/ |title=Tesla parades sleek model body and fab batt at Roadster fans |first=Iain |last=Thomson |work=The Register |date=December 26, 2014 |accessdate=May 5, 2015}} == Development == {{see also|History of Tesla Inc.}} The Roadster was developed by Tesla to mass-produce [[AC Propulsion tzero|AC Propulsion's tzero concept car]]. After [[Martin Eberhard]] sold [[NuvoMedia]] to [[Gemstar-TV Guide International|TV Guide]], he wanted a sports car with high mileage, but could not find one. His battery experience with the Rocket eBook inspired him to develop an electric car.{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2006/08/tesla-3/ |title=Batteries Included |date=August 1, 2006 |work=WIRED |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305141833/http://www.wired.com/2006/08/tesla-3/ |archivedate=March 5, 2016 |url-status=live }} The production idea was conceived by Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning who incorporated Tesla Motors in Delaware on July 1, 2003, to pursue the idea commercially.{{cite web |url=https://delecorp.delaware.gov/tin/GINameSearch.jsp |title=Division of Corporations – Online Services |date=July 1, 2003 |accessdate=October 12, 2009 |publisher=State of Delaware |quote=Tesla Motors incorporation is found under file number 3677166 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106214416/https://delecorp.delaware.gov/tin/GINameSearch.jsp |archivedate=January 6, 2010 }} South African-born entrepreneur [[Elon Musk]] took an active role within the company starting in 2004, including investing US$7.5 million, overseeing Roadster product design from the beginning, and greatly expanding Tesla's long-term strategic sales goals by using the sports car to fund development of mainstream vehicles.{{cite web|last=Musk |first=Elon |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |title=The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan (just between you and me) #124 |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=August 2, 2006 |accessdate=October 3, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802142703/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |archive-date=August 2, 2010 |url-status=live}} {{Self-published source|inline|date=May 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://gigaom.com/cleantech/elon-musk-envisions-tesla-electric-car-as-low-as-20k/ |title=Elon Musk Envisions Tesla Electric Car as Low as $20K: Cleantech News |publisher=Gigaom.com |date=September 17, 2008 |accessdate=October 9, 2010}} Musk became Tesla's Chairman of the Board in April 2004 and had helped recruit JB Straubel as chief technology officer in March 2004.{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000119312510017054/ds1.htm | title=Tesla Motors, Inc. Registration Statement on Form S-1 filed with SEC| date=January 29, 2010 | accessdate=October 22, 2010}} Musk received the [[Global Green]] 2006 product design award for the design of the Tesla Roadster, presented by [[Mikhail Gorbachev]],{{cite web|title=Tesla Motors team|publisher=Tesla Motors|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/company_team.php}} and he received the 2007 Index Design award for the design of the Tesla Roadster.{{cite web|title=Tesla Roadster |publisher=Index |year=2007 |url=http://www.indexaward.dk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=89&Itemid=71 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118131526/http://www.indexaward.dk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=89&Itemid=71 |archivedate=January 18, 2012 }} [[File:Tesla Roadster - Flickr - Alexandre Prévot (1).jpg|thumb|left|Tesla Roadster (France)]] [[File:Tzero - The first Tesla vehicle.jpg|thumb|Tzero - The [[proof of concept]] Tesla]] Before Tesla had developed the Roadster's proprietary powertrain, they borrowed an [[AC Propulsion]] [[AC Propulsion tzero|Tzero]] vehicle as a test mule and converted from lead acid AGM batteries to lithium ion cells which substantially increased the range, reduced weight, and boosted 0-60 performance. Tesla then licensed [[AC Propulsion]]'s EV power system design and reductive charging patent which covers integration of the charging electronics with the [[Inverter (electrical)#Electric vehicle drives|inverter]], thus reducing mass, complexity, and cost. However, Tesla was dissatisfied with how the motor and transmission worked in the chassis.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Elon-Musk-Tesla-was-founded-on-2-false-ideas-7955528.php |title=Elon Musk: Tesla was founded on 2 false ideas, and survived anyway |first=David R. |last=Baker |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=May 31, 2016 |accessdate=August 10, 2016}} Tesla then designed and built its own power electronics, motor, and other drivetrain components that incorporated this licensed technology from [[AC Propulsion]].{{cite web |url=http://www.acpropulsion.com/technology/reductivecharging.htm|publisher=[[AC Propulsion]]|accessdate=March 7, 2007|title=Reductive Charging, AC Propulsion's Reductive Charger Integrated Charging for the Electric Vehicle |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070206121745/http://www.acpropulsion.com/technology/reductivecharging.htm |archivedate = February 6, 2007 |url-status=dead}}{{cite web | url = http://www.autobloggreen.com/2008/06/24/autobloggreen-qanda-tesla-motors-chairman-elon-musk-part-2-tran/ | title=AutoblogGreen Q&A: Tesla Motors Chairman Elon Musk Part 2 – Transmission shifts | date=June 24, 2008 | accessdate= June 24, 2008 | first=Sam |last=Abuelsamid }}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/efficiency/well_to_wheel.php|title=Well-to-Wheel Energy Efficiency|last1=Tarpenning|first1=Marc|first2=Martin |last2=Eberhard |date=August 24, 2007|publisher=Tesla Motors| accessdate=February 25, 2011|quote=The AC Propulsion lithium-ion charging system (the basis for the design of the Tesla Roadster charging system)...|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011010258/http://www.teslamotors.com/efficiency/well_to_wheel.php|archivedate=October 11, 2007}} Given the extensive redevelopment of the vehicle, Tesla Motors no longer licenses any proprietary technology from AC Propulsion. The Roadster's powertrain is unique.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=73 |title=Tesla Leadership |date=June 22, 2009 |accessdate=August 1, 2009 |first=Elon |last=Musk |publisher=Tesla Motors |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624221445/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=73 |archivedate=June 24, 2009 |quote=Tesla Motors, Inc. consisted of Eberhard, Tarpenning and Wright, plus an unfunded business plan and they were looking for an initial round of funding to create a more advanced prototype than the AC Propulsion Tzero. While there was a basic corporation in place, Tesla hadn't even registered or obtained the trademark to its name and had no formal offices or assets. To save legal fees, we just copied the SpaceX articles of incorporation and bylaws for Tesla and I invested $6.35M (98%) of the initial closing of $6.5M in Series A funding. Eberhard invested $75k (approximately 1%). |url-status=dead }} {{external media | float = right | width = 300px | image1 = [https://www.flickr.com/photos/rnair/393866815/ Tesla Roadster and Lotus Elise] | image2 = [https://www.flickr.com/photos/rnair/393847103 Black Roadster and grey Elise] }} On July 11, 2005, Tesla and British sports car maker Lotus entered an agreement about products and services based on the [[Lotus Elise]], where Lotus provided advice on designing and developing a vehicle as well as producing partly assembled vehicles,{{cite web |url=http://contracts.onecle.com/tesla-motors/lotus-supply-2005-07-11.shtml |title=Supply agreement for products and services based on Lotus Elise technology |first1=Clive |last1=Dopson |first2=Simon |last2=Wood |first3=Thomas E. |last3=Colson |first4=Martin F. |last4=Eberhard |website=OneCLE |date=July 11, 2005 |accessdate=September 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617160922/http://contracts.onecle.com/tesla-motors/lotus-supply-2005-07-11.shtml |archivedate=June 17, 2016 |url-status=live }} and amended in 2009,{{cite web |url=http://contracts.onecle.com/tesla-motors/lotus-supply-2009-08-04.shtml |title=Contract Amendment 1 |first1=Luke |last1=Bennett |first2=Roger |last2=Becker |first3=Mike |last3=Donoughe |first4=Craig W. |last4=Harding |website=OneCLE |date=August 4, 2009 |accessdate=September 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617171938/http://contracts.onecle.com/tesla-motors/lotus-supply-2009-08-04.shtml |archivedate=June 17, 2016 |url-status=live }} helped with basic chassis development. The Roadster has a parts overlap of roughly 6% with the [[Lotus Elise]], a 2-inch-longer [[wheelbase]], and a slightly [[Structural rigidity|stiffer chassis]] according to Eberhard.{{cite web |url=https://www.tesla.com/blog/lotus-position |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822083018/https://www.tesla.com/blog/lotus-position |title=Lotus Position |archivedate=August 22, 2016 |accessdate=September 14, 2016 |url-status=dead }} Tesla's designers chose to construct the body panels using [[resin transfer molded]] [[carbon fiber reinforced plastic|carbon fiber composite]] to minimize weight; this choice makes the Roadster one of the least expensive cars with an entirely carbon fiber skin.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/mythbusters-part-2-tesla-roadster-not-converted-lotus-elise |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211094238/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/mythbusters-part-2-tesla-roadster-not-converted-lotus-elise |title=Mythbusters Part 2: The Tesla Roadster is not a Converted Lotus Elise - Tesla Motors |accessdate=October 2, 2015 |archivedate=February 11, 2015 |work=teslamotors.com |url-status=live}} Several prototypes of the Tesla Roadster were produced from 2004 through 2007. Initial studies were done in two "[[test mule]]" vehicles based on Lotus Elises equipped with all-electric drive systems. Ten engineering prototypes (EP1 through EP10) which led to many minor changes were then built and tested in late 2006 and early 2007. Tesla then produced at least 26 validation prototypes which were delivered beginning in March 2007.[http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/showthread.php/429-Validation-Prototypes-(VPs) VP1 through VP26] These final revisions were endurance and crash tested in preparation for series production. In August 2007, Martin Eberhard was replaced by an interim CEO, Michael Marks.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=52 |title=The Next Leg of the Race |date=August 15, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813025929/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=52 |archivedate=August 13, 2007 }} Marks accepted the temporary position while a recruitment was undertaken. In December 2007, Ze'ev Drori became the CEO and president of Tesla. In October 2008, Musk succeeded Drori as CEO. Drori became vice chairman and left the company in December. In January 2008, the U.S. [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) announced that it would grant a waiver of the ''advanced'' air bag rule[http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/cars/rules/rulings/index_airbag.html Notices and Final Rules: Air Bag Information]. Nhtsa.dot.gov. Retrieved on August 10, 2013. noting that the Tesla Roadster already includes standard [[air bag]]s; similar waivers have been granted to many other small volume manufacturers as well, including [[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], [[Ferrari]], and [[Bugatti]].{{ cite journal |url=http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/2008/pdf/E8-1359.pdf |title=Docket No. NHTSA-2008-0013. Tesla Motors, Inc.; Grant of Application for a Temporary Exemption From Advanced Air Bag Requirements of Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard No. 208 |volume=73 |issue=18 |date=January 28, 2008 |publisher=[[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]]}}{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/economy/2008-01-28-3400362215_x.htm | title=Tesla Sports Car Gets Air Bag Waiver |first=Ken |last=Thomas | date=January 28, 2008 | accessdate=December 30, 2008 | agency=Associated Press | work=USA Today }}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog3/?p=73|title=Mythbusters Part 1: Airbags? We got 'em!|last=Siry|first=Daryl|date=February 29, 2008|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=December 30, 2008}} Tesla delivered its first production car in February 2008 to Musk. Tesla announced in early August 2009 that Roadster sales had resulted in overall corporate profitability for the month of July 2009, earning {{USD|1 million}} on revenue of {{USD|20 million}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090807005516/en/Tesla-Motors-Attains-Profitability-Milestone |title= Tesla Motors Attains Profitability Milestone (press release) |website=[[Business Wire]] |date= August 7, 2009 }} Tesla, which signed a production contract with Group Lotus in 2007 to produce "gliders" (complete cars minus electric powertrain) for the Roadster, announced in early 2010 that Roadster production would continue until early 2012. Starting one year prior to the end of the contract, Tesla put a hiatus on new orders to allow time for tooling changes at Lotus's assembly plant in the UK.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.automobilemag.com/news/tesla-extends-production-contract-with-lotus-2822/ |title=Tesla Extends Production Contract with Lotus |magazine=Automobile Magazine |date=March 30, 2010 |accessdate=April 5, 2010 |url-status=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160411195948/http://www.automobilemag.com/news/tesla-extends-production-contract-with-lotus-2822/ |archivedate=April 11, 2016 }} == Production == [[File:Roadster interior.jpg|thumb|Interior of Roadster 2.5 from July 2010]] Tesla's cumulative production of the Roadster reached 1,000 cars in January 2010.{{cite press release |title=Tesla Celebrates 1,000th Roadster |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-celebrates-1000th-roadster |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=January 12, 2010 |accessdate=September 13, 2010}} The Roadster is considered an American car though many carry a [[Vehicle Identification Number]] beginning with the letter "S" which is the designation for the United Kingdom.{{cite web |url=https://teslamotorsclub.com/tmc/threads/decoding-tesla-roadster-vins.1128/ |title=Decoding Tesla Roadster VINs |website=Tesla Motors Club |date=May 6, 2008 |access-date=April 8, 2016}} Some however carry a number starting with "5" appropriate to the US. Parts were sourced from around the world. The body panels came from French supplier Sotira. These were sent from France to [[Hethel]], U.K., where Tesla contracted with Lotus to build the Roadster's unique chassis.{{cite magazine | magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2007/05/tesla200705?currentPage=1 | title=Quiet Thunder |first=Michael |last=Shnayerson |date=May 2007 | accessdate=April 24, 2007 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog4/?p=50|title=Cut From a Different Cloth|date=February 15, 2007|accessdate=February 15, 2008 |first=Barrie |last=Dickinson |publisher=Tesla Motors}} The Roadster shares roughly 6% of its components with the [[Lotus Elise]]; shared components include the windshield, air bags, some tires, some dashboard parts, and suspension components. The Roadster's single-speed gearbox was made in Detroit to Tesla's specifications by Auburn Hills, Michigan-based supplier [[BorgWarner]]. Brakes and airbags were made by [[Siemens]] in [[Germany]], and some crash testing was conducted at Siemens as well.{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120761191252596525?mod=hps_us_whats_news | title=Detroit Sets Bold Goal: Exporting U.S. Cars | date=April 8, 2008 | last=John D. Stoll, Norihiko Shirouzo and Neal E. Boudette | accessdate=June 10, 2008 | newspaper=Wall Street Journal | quote=Tesla Motors, a Northern California start-up developing an electric car, recently decided to scrap plans to build its US$20,000-plus batteries in Thailand. Instead, it will assemble the components in the U.S. because of currency values. }} For Roadsters bound for customers in North America, the chassis was then sent to Menlo Park, California, for final assembly, and for Roadsters bound for customers in Europe or elsewhere outside of North America, the chassis was sent to a facility at Wymondham near Hethel, for final assembly. At these final assembly locations, Tesla employees installed the entire powertrain, which consisted of the battery pack, power electronics module, gearbox and motor. Tesla also performed rigorous "pre-delivery inspection" on every car before customers took ownership. Tesla ordered 2,500 [[glider (automobiles)|glider]]s from Lotus, which ended supplies in December 2011 when their contract expired. Tesla ended production of the Roadster in January 2012. === Timeline === Subsequent to completion of production car number one at Hethel, the company announced problems with [[transmission (mechanics)|transmission]] reliability. The development transmission, with first gear enabled to accelerate {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 4 seconds, was reported to have a life expectancy of as low as only a few thousand miles. Tesla's first two transmission suppliers were unable to produce transmissions, in quantity, that could withstand the gear-shift requirements of the high torque, high rpm electric motor. In December 2007, Tesla announced plans to ship the initial Roadsters with the transmissions locked into second gear to provide {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} acceleration in 5.7 seconds. The first production car was not delivered with this interim solution; P1 has both transmission gears enabled. According to the plan, the initial transmissions were to be swapped out under warranty when the finalized transmission, power electronics module (PEM), and cooling system became available. The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency#Fuel economy testing and results|EPA range]] of the car was also restated downward from {{convert|245|to|221|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}}. The downward revision was attributed to an error in equipment calibration at the laboratory that conducted the original test.{{cite web | url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=55 | title=A Letter to Customers from Ze'ev Drori |first=Ze'ev |last=Drori | author-link =Ze'ev Drori| date=December 27, 2007 | access-date=December 31, 2007| publisher=Tesla Motors|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071230184757/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=55 |archive-date=December 30, 2007}}{{cite web | url=http://qik.com/video/22264 | title=Ride in first production Tesla with Elon Musk |first=Robert |last=Scoble | date=February 19, 2008 | accessdate=February 26, 2008 | quote=2:58 into video Elon Musk says "This particular car [P1] actually has two speeds" }}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/4465-post11.html |date=December 12, 2007 |accessdate=February 12, 2008 |first=Daryl |last=Siry |author-link=Daryl Siry |title=Re: My Town Hall Notes |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716212321/http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/4465-post11.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011}} * During the first two months of production, Tesla produced a total of three Roadsters (P3/VINF002, P4/VINF004, and P5/VINF005). Production car # 1 (P1) and P2 were built prior to the start of regular series production, which began March 17, 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/tesla-production-slower-than-expected-908.html |title=Tesla Production Slower Than Expected |work=Greentech Media |date=May 16, 2008 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * By September 10, 2008, Tesla had delivered 27 of the cars to customers. It was also reported that a newer, better transmission had been developed and that production of the car was hoped to reach 20 per week by December 2008, and 40 per week by March 2009.{{ cite news |url=http://wot.motortrend.com/6294593/green/tesla-declares-transmission-problems-solved-finished-roadster-now-in-production/index.html |title=Tesla declares transmission problems solved, finished Roadster now in production |work=Motor Trend |date=September 10, 2008 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} Over the next 20 days, however, only three more cars had been delivered to customers which brought the total to 30 as of September 30, 2008.{{cite news |url=http://media.www.themichiganjournal.com/media/storage/paper255/news/2008/09/30/GoingGreen/Tesla.Roadster.Takes.Green.Trend.For.Joy.Ride-3460575.shtml |title=Tesla Roadster takes green trend for joy ride |newspaper=The Michigan Journal |date=September 30, 2008 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * By November 19, 2008, more than 70 of the cars had been delivered to customers.{{cite news |url=http://blog.wired.com/cars/2008/11/the-jersey-turn.html |title=The Jersey Turnpike is No Match for the Roadster |work=Wired |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * By December 9, 2008, the 100th car had been delivered.{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/peninsula/ci_11183440 |title=Tesla Motors hands keys to 100th Roadster owner |newspaper=The Mercury News |date=December 10, 2008 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * By February 11, 2009, 200 Roadsters had been produced.{{cite news |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2340898,00.asp?kc=PCRSS03069TX1K0001121 |title=Tesla Motors Says Will Be Profitable in 2009 |work=PC Mag |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * By April 2, 2009, 320 Roadsters had been delivered.{{cite news |url=http://www.physorg.com/news157917126.html |title=Orders streaming in for new Tesla electric sedans |website=Physorg.org |date=April 2, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2015}} * In May 2009, Tesla issued a [[product recall|safety recall]] for all 345 of its Roadsters that were manufactured before April 22, 2009. Tesla sent technicians to customers' homes to tighten the rear, inner hub flange bolts. Tesla told customers that without this adjustment, the driver could lose control of the car and crash. The problem originated at the Lotus assembly line that builds the Roadster and Lotus also recalled some of its own vehicles. Tesla reminded customers that millions of cars are recalled every year.{{cite press release|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1376 |title=Tesla To Do House Calls |date=May 28, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 |publisher=Tesla Motors |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611150607/http://www.teslamotors.com:80/media/press_room.php?id=1376 |archivedate=June 11, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-recalls-345-roadsters-2009-5 |title=Tesla Recalls More Than 75% Of Its Roadsters |newspaper=Business Insider |date=May 28, 2009}} * By the end of May 2009, the 500th Roadster had been delivered.{{cite press release|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1380 |title=Tesla Motors Delivers 500th Roadster |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=June 3, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616065539/http://www.teslamotors.com:80/media/press_room.php?id=1380 |archivedate=June 16, 2009 }} * Tesla made its first profit ever in July 2009, when it shipped 109 vehicles, the most in a single month at that time.{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/08/07/technology/tesla_profitability/?postversion=2009080716 |title=Electric roadster maker making money |work=CNN |date=August 7, 2009 |accessdate=May 5, 2015 |first=Julianne |last=Pepitone}} * By September 15, 2009, 700 Roadsters had been delivered.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aJqdKspAEAkA |title=Electric Sports-Car Maker Tesla Gets $82.5 Million Investment |work=Bloomberg |date=September 15, 2009}} * Tesla announced on January 13, 2010, that it had produced its 1,000th Roadster. The company had delivered vehicles to customers in 43 states and 21 countries worldwide.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=2279 |title=Press Center |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=October 9, 2010}} In 2009 Tesla began taking orders from customers in Canada, and Canadian deliveries began in February 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1380 |title=Press Releases |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=August 6, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616065539/http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1380 |archivedate=June 16, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://bostonherald.com.nyud.net/business/automotive/view/20100113electric_dreams_less_wild_more_pragmatic_at_2010_auto_show/srvc=home&position=also |title=Electric dreams less wild, more pragmatic at 2010 auto show |newspaper=The Boston Herald |date=January 13, 2010}} * In January 2010, Tesla began producing its first right-hand-drive Roadsters for the UK and Ireland. The 2010 model-year right-hand-drive Roadster included a suite of unique noise-reduction materials and an upgraded sound system. The Roadster started at £86,950 and cost about 1.5p per mile. * On January 29, 2010, in a [[Form S-1]] filing of its [[Prospectus (finance)|preliminary prospectus]] with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the company stated that it would halt production of the Roadster in 2011 and replace it with a new model which would not be introduced until 2013 at the earliest: "...we do not plan to sell our current generation Tesla Roadster after 2011 due to planned tooling changes at a supplier for the Tesla Roadster, and we do not currently plan to begin selling our next-generation Tesla Roadster until at least one year after the launch of the [[Tesla Model S|Model S]], which is not expected to be in production until 2012..."{{cite web | url = https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000119312510017054/ds1.htm | title = Form S-1, Registration Statement under The Securities Act of 1933: Tesla Motors, Inc. | publisher = [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] | date = January 29, 2010 | accessdate = January 30, 2010 }}{{cite magazine | url = https://www.wired.com/autopia/2010/01/teslas-roadster-to-exit-in-2011/ | title = Tesla's Roadster To Exit In 2011 | last = Squatriglia | first = Chuck | magazine = Wired Magazine | date = January 29, 2010 | accessdate = January 30, 2010 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000119312510017054/ds1.htm |title=Tesla Prospectus |location=U.S. |publisher=Securities and Exchange Commission |date=February 7, 2010}} The Model S was released in June 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_20919722/silicon-valley-milestone-tesla-motors-begins-delivering-model?refresh=no |title=In a Silicon Valley milestone, Tesla Motors begins delivering Model S electric cars |author=John Boudreau |work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |date=June 22, 2012 |access-date=June 22, 2012}} * On March 16, 2010, Tesla announced that it had "negotiated agreements with key suppliers that will increase total Roadster production by 40 percent and extend sales into 2012",{{cite magazine | url = https://www.wired.com/autopia/2010/03/tesla-roadster-gets-a-reprieve-and-new-markets/ | title = Tesla Roadster Gets a Reprieve – And New Markets | last = Squatriglia | first = Chuck | magazine = Wired Magazine | date = March 15, 2010 | accessdate = March 15, 2010 }} also indicating that it would expand into the Asian and Australian markets by 2011. * On December 2, 2010, Tesla had delivered more than 1,400 Roadsters.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-delivers-100th-german-car-during-race-champions |title=Tesla delivers 100th German car during Race of Champions |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=December 2, 2010}} * On September 28, 2011, Tesla delivered its 100th Roadster in Switzerland.{{cite press release |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/100th-swiss-tesla-roadster-hits-road |title=100th Swiss Tesla Roadster Hits the Road |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2015}} * Production ended in January 2012 and was no longer available for sale the U.S. after December 2011. * More than 2,418 units were sold worldwide through September 2012. The remaining cars were available for sale only in Europe and Asia. Most of the remaining Roadsters were sold during the fourth quarter of 2012.{{cite web|url=http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/2155882767x0x637040/4e3260f0-b711-47df-9c9e-16a8dda99a19/Q4'12%20SHL%20022013%20final.pdf|title=Tesla Motors, Inc. – Fourth Quarter & Full Year 2012 Shareholder Letter|publisher=Tesla Motors|date=February 20, 2013|accessdate=February 13, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527212049/http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/2155882767x0x637040/4e3260f0-b711-47df-9c9e-16a8dda99a19/Q4'12%20SHL%20022013%20final.pdf|archive-date=May 27, 2014|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|last=Bortzfield|first=Bill|title=First Coast Gears: Tesla celebrates "Final 5" Roadsters, attention now turns to Model S|url=http://downtownjax.firstcoastnews.com/photo-gallery/transportation/67644-first-coast-gears-tesla-celebrates-final-5-roadsters-attention-now-turns-model-s-slideshow|publisher=First Coast News|accessdate=February 25, 2014|date=December 23, 2011}} * In 2015, it was announced that a successor to the Roadster would debut in 2019.{{cite news |url=http://jalopnik.com/the-tesla-model-s-just-got-upgraded-to-ludicrous-speed-1718577723 |title=The Tesla Model S Just Got Upgraded to LUDICROUS SPEED |first=Michael |last=Ballaban |date=July 17, 2015 |publisher=Jalopnik }} * In 2016, Tesla began selling a battery upgrade from {{convert|53|to|80|kWh|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |url=http://shop.teslamotors.com/collections/roadster/products/roadster-3-0-upgrade |title=Tesla — Roadster 3.0 Battery Upgrade |publisher=Tesla Motors |access-date=July 14, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904000211/http://shop.teslamotors.com/collections/roadster/products/roadster-3-0-upgrade |archive-date=September 4, 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://electrek.co/2016/07/08/tesla-roadster-3-0-battery-upgrade-r80/ |title=Tesla Roadster 3.0 battery upgrade (R80) are finally starting to arrive – ~340 miles of range |first=Fred |last=Lambert |work=Electrek |location= |date=July 9, 2016 |access-date=July 14, 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2017/06/25/tesla-roadster-3-0-review/|title=Tesla Roadster 3.0 - the electric car that sparked a revolution, revisited|first=Fred |last=Lambert |work=Electrek |location= |date=June 25, 2017 |access-date=June 25, 2017}} * In 2017, it was announced that a successor to the Roadster would debut in 2020.{{cite news |url= https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/16/tesla-unveils-the-new-roadster/|title=Tesla unveils the new Roadster |work=TechCrunch |accessdate=November 17, 2017 |quote=with speeds of just 1.9 seconds for 0 to 60, 4.2 seconds for 0 to 100. It can handle a quarter mile in 8.9 seconds .... its top speed is above 250 mph. and it has a 200 kWh battery pack that offers 630 miles of highway driving range.}} === Special final edition === Tesla produced a special edition of 15 Final Edition Roadsters to close the production cycle of the electric car. The 15 special-edition cars were sold in each of the three sales regions, North America, Europe and Asia, and five units were allocated to each. The Final Edition Roadster did not have any performance modifications, but featured sporting atomic red paint, a duo of dark silver stripes on its hood and rear clamshell, and exclusive [[anthracite]] [[aluminum]] wheels.{{cite web |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/12/16/this-is-the-last-tesla-roadster/|title=This is the last Tesla Roadster |first=Damon |last=Lavrinc |publisher=[[Autoblog|Autoblog Green]]|date=December 16, 2011|accessdate=December 17, 2011}} == Specifications == === Motor === {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Tesla Roadster DSC 0179.jpg|image2=Tesla Roadster DSC 0291.jpg|caption2=Tesla Roadster with hood and trunk open}} The Roadster is powered by a [[3-phase]], 4-[[dipole|pole]], [[induction motor|induction electric motor]] with a maximum output power of {{convert|248|hp|kW|lk=in|abbr=on|order=flip}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1205 |title=Tesla Motors introduces Roadster Sport |date=January 11, 2008 |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=January 14, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090120030251/http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1205 |archivedate=January 20, 2009}} Its maximum torque of {{convert|200|lb.ft|Nm|abbr=on}} is immediately available and remains constant from 0 to 6,000 rpm;{{cite web|title=Performance: Acceleration & Torque|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/performance/acceleration_and_torque.php|publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=February 25, 2014| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109013516/http://www.teslamotors.com/performance/acceleration_and_torque.php|archivedate=January 9, 2009}} nearly instantaneous torque is a characteristic of electric motors and offers one of the biggest performance differences from internal combustion engines. The motor is air-cooled and does not need a liquid cooling system.{{cite news |url=http://designapplause.com/design/design-green/tesla-roadster/106/ |title=Tesla roadster |work=Design Applause |date=April 18, 2008 |accessdate=June 16, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/roadster/technology/motor |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704030129/http://www.teslamotors.com/roadster/technology/motor |title=Tesla - Motor - www.teslamotors.com |archivedate=July 4, 2010 |accessdate=June 16, 2016 |url-status=dead}} The Sport model introduced during the [[North American International Auto Show|Jan 2009 Detroit Auto Show]] includes a motor with a higher density, hand-wound [[stator]] that produces a maximum of {{convert|288|hp|kW|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/roadstersport/|title=Roadster Sport|date=January 11, 2009|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=January 14, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118211155/http://teslamotors.com/roadstersport|archivedate=January 18, 2009}} Both motors are designed for rotational speeds of up to 14,000 rpm, and the regular motor delivers a typical efficiency of 88% or 90%; 80% at peak power. It weighs less than {{convert|70|lb}}.{{cite web |url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/tesla-roadster.htm/printable|title=How stuff works|date=January 11, 2010|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=January 11, 2010}} === Transmission === Starting in September 2008 Tesla selected [[BorgWarner]] to manufacture gearboxes and began equipping all Roadsters with a single speed, fixed gear gearbox (8.2752:1) with an electrically actuated [[parking pawl]] mechanism and a mechanical lubrication pump. The company previously worked with several companies, including XTrac and [[Magna International]], to find the right [[automatic transmission]], but a two-gear solution proved to be too challenging. This led to substantial delays in production. At the "Town Hall Meeting" with owners in December 2007, Tesla announced plans to ship the initial 2008 Roadsters with their interim Magna two-speed direct shift [[manual transmission]]s locked into second gear, limiting the performance of the car to less than what was originally stated ({{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 5.7 seconds instead of the announced 4.0 seconds). Tesla also announced it would upgrade those transmissions under warranty when the final transmission became available.{{cite web | url = http://www.autoblog.com/2007/12/19/tesla-clarifies-report-of-temporary-transmissions/ |date=December 19, 2007 |title=Tesla clarifies report of "temporary transmissions" | first = John | last = Neff }} At the "Town Hall Meeting" with owners on January 30, 2008, Tesla Motors described the planned transmission upgrade as a single-speed gearbox with a drive ratio of 8.27:1 combined with improved electronics and motor cooling that retain the acceleration from {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on}} in under 4 seconds and an improved motor limit of 14,000 rpm to retain the {{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} top speed.{{cite web | url = http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=55 | title = A Letter to Customers from Ze'ev Drori |publisher=Tesla Motors |first=Ze'ev |last=Drori |date=December 17, 2007 |accessdate=December 8, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231060859/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=55 |archive-date=December 31, 2007}} The upgraded system also improved the maximum torque from {{convert|200|to|280|lb·ft|abbr=on|order=flip|N.m}} and improves the Roadster's [[Dragstrip|quarter mile]] times.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==== Gear selector ==== In the interior the gear selector is similar to a push-button automatic with buttons labeled P, R, N and D while some earlier models have a gear lever similar to that in cars with manual transmission. === Performance === The Roadster's {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} acceleration time is 3.9 seconds for the Standard model and 3.7 seconds for the 2010 V2.5 Sport, which ''Motor Trend'' confirmed in the first independent, instrumented testing of the V2.5 Sport model. The magazine also recorded a {{convert|0|to|1/4|mi|adj=on}} time of 12.6 seconds at {{convert|102.6|mph||abbr=on|order=flip}}.[http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/alternative/112_0912_2010_tesla_roadster_sport_test/specs.html#ixzz0b8yiYKO0 Motor Trend] First Test: 2010 Tesla Roadster Sport Tesla said the top speed is electronically limited to {{convert|125|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}. Tesla claims it has a weight of {{convert|2877|lb||abbr=on|order=flip}}, a {{Cd|0.35–0.36|link=car|long=yes}}{{cite web |url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2009/03/26/tesla-model-s-50-000-ev-sedan-seats-seven-300-mile-range-0-6/ |title=Tesla Model S: US$50,000 EV sedan seats seven, 300-mile range, 0–60 in 5.5s (press release)| last=Ramsey| first=Jonathon |date=March 26, 2009 |website=[[Autoblog|Autoblog Green]] |accessdate=April 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090327185141/http://www.autobloggreen.com/2009/03/26/tesla-model-s-50-000-ev-sedan-seats-seven-300-mile-range-0-6/ |archivedate=March 27, 2009}} and a {{Crr|0.011|long=yes|link=yes}}.{{cite press release |title=Roadster 3.0 |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/roadster-30 |website=teslamotors.com|publisher=Tesla Motors |date=December 26, 2014 |accessdate=April 8, 2015}} Tesla began delivering the higher performance version of the Roadster in July 2009. The Roadster Sport has adjustable dampers and a new hand-wound motor, capable of {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 3.7 seconds.{{cite press release|title=Tesla Motors introduces Roadster Sport |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1205 |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=January 11, 2009 |accessdate=May 7, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090120030251/http://www.teslamotors.com:80/media/press_room.php?id=1205 |archivedate=January 20, 2009 }} Scotty Pollacheck, a high-performance driver for [[Killacycle]], drove a 2010 Tesla Roadster Sport at the Wayland Invitational Drag Race in Portland, Oregon, in July 2009. He did a quarter-mile (~400 m) in dry conditions in 12.643 seconds, setting a new record in the [[National Electric Drag Racing Association]] among the SP/A3 class of vehicles.{{cite web |url=http://peakoilgarage.com/2009/07/27/tesla-roadster-sport-nedra-record-12-643-at-14-mile/ |title=Tesla Roadster Sport NEDRA record 12.643 at 1/4 mile « Peak Oil Garage |publisher=Peakoilgarage.com |date=July 27, 2009 |accessdate=August 1, 2009}} The [[Fuel economy in automobiles#EPA testing procedure: 2008 and beyond|EPA]] combined range (specifying distance traveled between charges) measured in February 2008 for early production Roadsters was {{convert|231|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} city, {{convert|224|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} highway, and {{convert|227|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} combined (city/highway).{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/learn_more/faqs.php?flat=1#faq-q-item3 |date=February 28, 2008 |accessdate=December 13, 2008 |publisher=Tesla Motors |title=How far can the Tesla Roadster drive between charges? |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080729041920/http://www.teslamotors.com/learn_more/faqs.php?flat=1#faq-q-item3 |archive-date=July 29, 2008}} In August 2008, additional testing with the newer Powertrain 1.5 resulted in an EPA combined range of {{convert|244|mi||abbr=on|order=flip}}.{{cite web | url=http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-motors-selects-borgwarner-production-new-gearbox-tesla-roadster | date=February 25, 2011 | publisher=Tesla Motors |title=Tesla Motors Selects BorgWarner for Production of New Gearbox for Tesla Roadster }} The vehicle set a new distance record when it completed the {{convert|241|mi|km|order=flip|adj=on}} Rallye Monte Carlo d'Energies Alternatives with {{convert|36|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} left on the charge.{{cite web|last=Taylor |first=Alun |url=http://www.reghardware.co.uk/2009/04/10/tesla_wins_at_monaco/ |title=Tesla Roadster runs for 241 miles in Monte Carlo e-rally • Register Hardware |publisher=Reghardware.co.uk |date=April 10, 2009 |accessdate=August 1, 2009}} A Roadster drove around the world (although flying as cargo over oceans) in 2012,{{cite web |url=http://80diaselectricos.com/genesis-2012/#history |title=Genesis 2012 - 80edays |website=80diaselectricos.com |accessdate=September 27, 2016}} and repeated it in 80 days with other electric cars in 2016.{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2016/09/16/eleven-teams-just-drove-around-the-world-in-electric-vehicles-9-teslas-1-denza-a-bus/ |title=Eleven teams just drove around the world in electric vehicles: 9 Teslas, 1 Denza & a bus |first=Jameson |last=Dow |work=Electrek |date=September 16, 2016 |access-date=September 27, 2016}} [[Simon Hackett]] and Emilis Prelgauskas broke the distance record for an electric vehicle, driving {{convert|501|km|abbr=on}} from [[Alice Springs]] to [[Marla, South Australia|Marla]], South Australia, in Simon's Tesla Roadster. The car had about {{convert|4.8|km|abbr=on}} of range left when the drive was completed.{{cite web| url=http://www.internode.on.net/news/2009/10/155.php |title=Internode M.D. smashes E.V. world distance record | date=October 29, 2009 | accessdate=October 29, 2009}} === Battery system === {{multiple image | footer = | align = right | image1 = Tesla Roadster Sport electrical charge.jpg | width1 = {{#expr: (150 * 4272 / 2848) round 0}} | alt1 = | caption1 = An electrical plug of the Tesla Roadster Sport | image2 = Tesla Roadster Sport battery pack rear.jpg | width2 = {{#expr: (150 * 2848 / 4272) round 0}} | alt2 = | caption2 = The rear side of a Tesla Roadster battery pack | image3 = Tesla Roadster charging screen.jpg | width3 = {{#expr: (150 * 4272 / 2848) round 0}} | alt3 = | caption3 = The charging screen of a Tesla Roadster Sport }} Tesla refers to the Roadster's battery pack as the Energy Storage System or ESS. The {{convert|992|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} ESS contains 6,831 [[lithium ion battery|lithium ion]] cells arranged into 11 "sheets" connected in series; each sheet contains 9 "bricks" connected in series; each "brick" contains 69 cells connected in parallel (11S 9S 69P). The cells are of the [[18650]] form factor commonly found in [[laptop]] batteries. Sources disagree on the exact type of Li-Ion cells—GreenCar says [[lithium cobalt oxide]] (LiCo),{{cite web|last=Voelcker|first=John|title=Boeing 787 Batteries Same As Those In Electric Cars? Umm, NO|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1081753_boeing-787-batteries-same-as-those-in-electric-cars-umm-no |publisher=GreenCar|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=January 18, 2013}} while researchers at [[Technical University of Denmark|DTU]]/[[INESC Porto]] state lithium manganese oxide (LMO).{{cite book |first1=Rodrigo |last1=Garcia-Valle |first2=João Abel Peças |last2=Lopes |title=Electric Vehicle Integration Into Modern Power Networks |publisher=Springer |isbn=9781461401346 |page=33 |date=September 28, 2012}} LiCo has higher reaction energy during [[thermal runaway]] than LMO.{{cite magazine|last=Dalløkken|first=Per Erlien |title=Her er Dreamliner-problemet|url=http://www.tu.no/industri/2013/01/17/her-er-dreamliner-problemet |magazine=[[Teknisk Ukeblad]]|accessdate=January 17, 2013 |language=Norwegian|date=January 17, 2013}} [https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=no&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tu.no%2Findustri%2F2013%2F01%2F17%2Fher-er-dreamliner-problemet English translation] The pack is designed to prevent catastrophic cell failures from propagating to adjacent cells (thermal runaway), even when the cooling system is off.{{US patent reference | number = 7433794 | y = 2008 | m = 10 | d = 07 | inventor = Berdichevsky; Eugene Michael (Palo Alto, CA), Cole; Philip David (Redwood City, CA), Hebert; Arthur Joseph (San Carlos, CA), Hermann; Weston Arthur (Palo Alto, CA), Kelty; Kurt Russell (Palo Alto, CA), Kohn; Scott Ira (Menlo Park, CA), Lyons; David Frederick (Palo Alto, CA), Straubel; Jeffrey Brian (Menlo Park, CA), Mendez; Noel Jason (Mountain View, CA) | title = Mitigation of propagation of thermal runaway in a multi-cell battery pack }} Coolant is pumped continuously through the ESS both when the car is running and when the car is turned off if the pack retains more than a 90% charge. The coolant pump draws 146 watts.{{cite web | url=http://www.teslamotors.com/display_data/pressguild.swf | title=The Future of Cars is Electric |first=Martin |last=Eberhard | authorlink=Martin Eberhard | publisher=Tesla Motors | date=August 7, 2007 | quote=Video available from [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-6124789175148491596 Google Video]. Slide 90 shows that "The ESS consists of 6831 individual cells that are electrically connected into parallel groups of 69 cells". (11S 9S 69P) }}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/technical-discussion/1727-little-water-pump-3.html#post13734 |title=That Little Water Pump |work=Tesla Motors Club Forum |publisher=Teslamotorsclub.com |accessdate=June 9, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518092358/http://www.teslamotorsclub.com/technical-discussion/1727-little-water-pump-3.html |archivedate=May 18, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://teslafounders.wordpress.com/2008/10/12/wasting-energy-like-two-really-nice-refrigerators/ |title=Wasting Energy like Two Really Nice Refrigerators |date=October 12, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081023151402/http://teslafounders.wordpress.com/2008/10/12/wasting-energy-like-two-really-nice-refrigerators/ |archivedate=October 23, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/display_data/Tesla_rebuttal_ZEV_expert_panel.pdf |title=Response to the CARB ZEV Expert Panel Position on Lithium-Ion Full-Performance Battery Electric Vehicles |first=Andrew |last=Simpson | date=March 23, 2008 |publisher=Tesla Motors}} The cooling and [[battery management system]] keeps the temperatures and voltages within specific limits.{{cite web|url= https://www.tesla.com/blog/bit-about-batteries |title=A Bit About Batteries |first=Martin |last=Eberhard | authorlink=Martin Eberhard | publisher=Tesla |date=November 30, 2006 |accessdate= June 17, 2017 |url-status=live |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170617222802/https://www.tesla.com/blog/bit-about-batteries |archivedate= June 17, 2017 }} [[File:Tesla Roadster charger DSC 0200.jpg|thumb|upright|Charging unit]] A full recharge to {{convert|53|kWh|abbr=on}} requires about 3½ hours using the High Power Connector which supplies 70-amp, 240-volt electricity.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog4/?p=59|title=The Most Coddled Automotive Battery Ever? - Tesla Motors|work=teslamotors.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog4/?p=59|title=The Most Coddled Automotive Battery Ever?|last=Toomre, Tesla Motors Director of Manufacturing Programs|first=Eric|date=August 8, 2007|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=February 17, 2009}} Tesla said in February 2009 that the ESS had expected life span of seven years/{{convert|100000|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}}, and began selling pre-purchase battery replacements for about one third of the battery's price today, with the replacement to be delivered after seven years. Tesla says the ESS retains 70% capacity after five years and {{convert|50000|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} of driving, assuming {{convert|10000|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} driven each year. A July 2013 study found that after {{convert|100000|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}}, Roadster batteries still had 80%–85% capacity and the only significant factor is mileage (not temperature).{{cite web |url=http://www.pluginamerica.org/surveys/batteries/tesla-roadster/PIA-Roadster-Battery-Study.pdf |title=Tesla Roadster Battery Study |first=Tom |last=Saxton |website=Plug In America |date=July 13, 2013 |access-date=June 18, 2017}} Tesla announced plans to sell the battery system to ''[[Think Nordic|TH!NK]]'' and possibly others through its Tesla Energy Group division. The TH!NK plans were put on hold by interim CEO Michael Marks in September 2007.{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Nauman |title=Tesla Motors to sell batteries in $43 million deal with Think |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_5956932 |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |date=May 22, 2007 |accessdate=June 19, 2007}}{{cite web | url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2006/11/29/tesla-motors-ready-to-license-batter-tech-to-other-companies/ | title=EDTA Conference: Tesla Motors ready to license battery tech to other companies | accessdate=March 11, 2007 |first=Sebastian |last=Blanco}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news.com/8301-10784_3-9798162-7.html | title=Tesla delays its battery business, but test drives begin | date=October 16, 2007 | accessdate=February 9, 2008 |first=Michael |last=Kanellos | publisher=News.com }} TH!NK now obtains its lithium-ion batteries from Enerdel. === Recharging === The Roadster uses a proprietary charging connector, although Tesla sells a mobile adapter that enables recharging with an [[SAE J1772|SAE J1772-2009]] connector.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/charging/j1772-mobile-connector |title=J1772 Mobile Connector |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=May 13, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607050856/http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/charging/j1772-mobile-connector |archivedate=June 7, 2012 |df= }} The vehicle can be recharged using:{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/electric/charging.php |title=Tesla Motors – Charging Solutions |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=May 11, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104104736/http://www.teslamotors.com/electric/charging.php|archivedate=January 4, 2010}} * A wall-mounted 208–240 V, 70 A maximum current Home Connector. This appears to be an OEM version of the TS-70 [[charging station]] from ClipperCreek.{{cite press release |title=ClipperCreek to Supply Power Control Stations for Tesla Motors |url=http://clippercreek.net/images/ClipperCreek%20to%20Supply%20Power%20Control%20Stations%20for%20Tesla%20Motors.pdf |publisher=ClipperCreek |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=May 11, 2010}} * A portable 120–240 V, 40 A maximum current Universal Mobile Connector cable that can plug into a [[NEMA connector#NEMA 14|NEMA 14–50]] receptacle and other 240 V receptacles using adapters. * A portable 120 V, 15 A maximum current Spare Mobile Connector cable that plugs into a standard North American domestic socket. Charging times vary depending on the ESS's state-of-charge, the available voltage, and the available circuit breaker amp rating ([[Electric current|current]]). In a best case scenario using a 240 V charger on a 90 A circuit breaker, Tesla documents a recharging rate of {{convert|56|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} of range for each hour charging; a complete recharge from empty would require just under four hours. The slowest charging rate using a 120 V outlet on a 15 A circuit breaker would add {{convert|5|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} of range for each hour charging; a complete recharge from empty would require 48 hours.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/charging |title=Charging |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=October 9, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628041831/http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/charging |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |url-status=live }} === Technical data === {| class="wikitable" ! 2017|language=en}} !Tesla Roadster ("P1"){{Cite news|url=https://www.autoblog.com/2008/01/23/breaking-tesla-has-a-solution-for-their-transmission-woes-get/|title=Breaking: Tesla has a solution for
