four seconds 5.7 seconds (limited due to durability) | align="center" |4.0 sec | align="center" |3.9 sec | align="center" |3.9 sec | align="center" |3.7 sec | align="center" |3.7 sec |- ! align="Right" |Curb weight (kg) / (lb) All fluids, 50% fuel | | align="center" |{{convert|2877|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|2727|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|1237|kg|abbr=on}} | align="center" |{{convert|1237|kg|abbr=on}} | align="center" |{{convert|1237|kg|abbr=on}} |- ! align="Right" |Top speed | align="center" |over 130 mph | align="center" |{{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} | align="center" |{{convert|125|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} |- ! align="Right" |Base price | align="center" | $80,000-$120,000 | align="center" |$98,950 | align="center" |$109,000 | align="center" |$110,950 | align="center" |$128,500 | align="center" |Car+ $29,000 |} == Energy efficiency == In June 2006, Tesla reported the Roadster's battery-to-wheel efficiency as 110 W·h/km (17.7 kW·h/100 mi) on an unspecified driving cycle—either a constant {{convert|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}) or SAE J1634 test—and stated a charging efficiency of 86% for an overall plug-to-wheel efficiency of 128 W·h/km (20.5 kW·h/100 mi).{{cite web | url = http://ev.inel.gov/pdf/fsev/eva/genmot.pdf |title=EVAmerica Baseline Performance Testing for 1997 General Motors EV1 with PbA Batteries |accessdate=March 5, 2007 |publisher=Idaho National Laboratory |quote = Footnote 8 in Tesla Motor's white paper refers to this INL study for the equivalent efficiency number from GM EV1 testing but does not specify the driving cycle. }}{{ cite journal |first1=Martin |last1=Eberhard |first2=Marc |last2=Tarpenning |title=The 21st century Electric Car |publisher=Tesla Motors |date=October 6, 2006 |url=http://www.evworld.com/library/Tesla_21centuryEV.pdf |accessdate=February 23, 2007 }} [[File:Graph Evolution of Tesla Roadster Efficiency.PNG|thumb|left|Evolution of the Roadster's plug-to-wheel efficiency (smaller values indicate better efficiency)]] In March 2007, Tesla reported the Roadster's efficiency on the EPA highway cycle as "135 mpg [U.S.] equivalent, per the conversion rate used by the EPA" or 133 W·h/km (21.5 kW·h/100 mi) battery-to-wheel and 155 W·h/km (24.9 kW·h/100 mi) plug-to-wheel.{{ cite journal | title = Musk Testimony |first=Elon |last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk | publisher = United States Senate Committee on Energy & Natural Resources |date=March 7, 2007 | url = http://energy.senate.gov/public/_files/MuskTestimony.doc | accessdate = March 14, 2007}}{{cite press release |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=53&js_enabled=0 |title=Tesla Motors Corporate Backgrounder |accessdate=December 5, 2006 |publisher=Tesla Motors |quote=...the Tesla Roadster is capable of 135 mpg equivalent...}}{{cite web |url=http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/News/articleId=116204 |title=Tesla Roadster: Lotus Helps Create Sporty 135 MPG Electric Car |accessdate=December 5, 2006 |publisher=Edmunds.com Inside Line |date=July 21, 2006 |quote=...achieves the equivalent of 135 mpg.}}{{cite news |last = Neil |first = Dan |title = A roadster that's electric |publisher = Marketplace Public Radio |date =July 20, 2006 | url = http://marketplace.publicradio.org/shows/2006/07/20/PM200607208.html |accessdate = September 18, 2006 }} The official U.S. [[window sticker]] of the 2009 Tesla Roadster showed an EPA rated energy consumption of 32 kW-hrs/100 mi in city and 33 kW-hrs/100 mi on the highway, equivalent to 105 mpg city and 102 mpg highway.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/16/automobiles/16STICKER.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=Cranking the Volt to 100 M.P.G.|first=Don |last=Sherman |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 13, 2008|accessdate=March 15, 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2008/11/16/automobiles/16sticker-inline1.html|title=2009 Tesla Roadster window sticke|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 13, 2008|accessdate=March 15, 2014}} The EPA rating for on board energy efficiency for electric vehicles before 2010 was expressed as [[kilowatt-hour]] per 100 miles (kW-hrs/100 mi).{{cite web |url=http://electric-vehicles-cars-bikes.blogspot.com/2009/08/why-are-volt-and-leaf-evs-measured-in.html#|title=Why are the VOLT and LEAF EVs measured in Miles Per Gallon|publisher=Electric Vehicle News|date=August 15, 2009|accessdate=March 15, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/confusion-over-mpg-ratings-electric-cars-25946/|title=Confusion Over MPG Ratings for Electric Cars|first=Brad |last=Berman |publisher=HybridCars.com|date=July 29, 2009|accessdate=March 15, 2014}} Since November 2010, with the introduction of the [[Nissan Leaf]] and the [[Chevrolet Volt]], EPA began using a new metric, [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPGe). The Roadster was never officially rated by the EPA in MPGe.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/23/business/23leaf.html?_r=1&hpw|title=Nissan Says Its Electric Leaf Gets Equivalent of 99 M.P.G.|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|first=Nick |last=Bunkley|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=March 15, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/driveon/post/2010/11/volt-is-rated-93-mpg-on-electricity-alone-37-mpg-on-gas-generator/1|title=Volt is rated 93 mpg on electricity alone, 37 mpg on gas generator |first=Fred |last=Meier |work=[[USA Today]] |date=November 24, 2010 |accessdate=March 15, 2014}} In August 2007, Tesla dynamometer testing of a validation prototype on the EPA combined cycle yielded a range of {{convert|221|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} using 149 W·h/km (23.9 kW·h/100 mi) battery-to-wheel and 209 Wh/km (33.6 kW·h/100 mi) plug-to-wheel.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog4/?p=60 |title=Where the Rubber Meets the Road |first=Andrew |last=Simpson |date=September 24, 2007 |accessdate=February 22, 2008 |quote=Mr. Simpson confirmed via email that "We do not quote station-to-wheel efficiency, but we do quote plug-to-wheel efficiency which includes all energy use downstream of the charging plug. For the most recent {{convert|221|mi|abbr=on}} range test, our plug-to-wheel efficiency was 336 Wh/mi". }} In February 2008, Tesla reported improved plug-to-wheel efficiency after testing a validation prototype car at an EPA-certified location. Those tests yielded a range of {{convert|220|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} and a plug-to-wheel efficiency of 199 Wh/km (32.1 kW·h /100 mi).{{cite web | url=http://www.teslamotors.com | title=Tesla Motors | accessdate=June 25, 2008 | quote=256 mpg equivalent*, 220 miles per charge*, less than 2¢ per mile*...* Range is based on our most recent testing with a Validation Prototype car at an EPA-certified location in February 2008. EPA range is subject to change pending future testing. Actual range will vary with driving style and conditions. Conversion from electric consumption to gallons of gasoline equivalent is calculated using the Department of Energy equivalence factor documented in the Code of Federal Regulations, Section 10, Part 474. }}{{cite news |last = Rogers |first = John |title = Tesla rolls out its long-awaited electric sports car |agency = Associated Press |date =May 2, 2008 |url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2004388491_apelectriccar.html |accessdate = May 2, 2008 | work=The Seattle Times}} In August 2008, Tesla reported on testing with the new, single-speed gearbox and upgraded electronics of powertrain 1.5 which yielded an EPA range of {{convert|244|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} and an EPA combined cycle, plug-to-wheel efficiency of 174 W·h/km (28 kW·h/100 mi).{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com|title=Tesla Motors|accessdate=October 29, 2008|quote=*[244 mile] Range is based on our most recent testing with a Validation Prototype car at a location certified by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) in August 2008. EPA-certified electricity consumption is 28 kW·h per 100 miles (17 kW·h/100 km or 630 kJ/km) on EPA combined cycle. EPA range and electricity consumption are subject to change pending future testing. Actual range and electricity consumption will vary with driving conditions and charging location. [Pennies per mile] Cost calculated using average winter/summer PG&E schedule E-9 off-peak "rate A" tariff, as of March 1, 2007. }} [[File:Testing the Tesla at Argonne National Laboratory (3).jpg|thumb|Roadster being tested through a driving cycle at [[Argonne National Laboratory]]'s two-wheel dynamometer. These tests helped researchers develop test procedures to evaluate [[fuel efficiency]] in electric vehicles in 2010]] In 2007, the Roadster's [[life cycle analysis|battery-to-wheel]] motor efficiency was reported as 88% to 90% on average and 80% at peak power.{{cite web | url=http://www.teslamotors.com/performance/tech_specs.php | title=2007 Tesla Roadster Technical Specifications | accessdate=February 25, 2011 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020043035/http://www.teslamotors.com/performance/tech_specs.php | archivedate=October 20, 2007 }} For comparison, [[internal combustion engine]]s have a tank-to-wheel efficiency of about 15%.{{cite web |url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/atv.shtml |title=Advanced Technologies and Energy Efficiency |accessdate=February 10, 2008 |publisher=US EPA }} Taking a more complete picture including the cost of energy drawn from its source, Tesla reports that their technology, assuming electricity generated from natural gas-burning power plants, has a high [[Tank-to-wheel|well-to-wheel]] efficiency of 1.14 km per mega[[joule]], compared to 0.202 km/MJ for gasoline-powered sports cars, 0.478 km/MJ for gasoline-powered commuter cars, 0.556 km/MJ for [[Hybrid electric vehicle|hybrid cars]], and 0.348 km/MJ for hydrogen [[fuel cell vehicle]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/efficiency |title=Using Energy Efficiently |publisher=Tesla Motors |accessdate=February 25, 2011}} === Petroleum-equivalent efficiency === {{Howto|section|date=June 2017|reason=Besides how-to instructions, this isn't specific to the Roadster. This applies to any BEV. Why is it here? }} {{see also|electric car#Comparison with internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs)}} As the Roadster does not use gasoline, petroleum efficiency (MPG, L/100 km) cannot be measured directly but instead is calculated using one of several equivalent methods: A number comparable to the typical [[Monroney sticker]]'s "pump-to-wheel" fuel efficiency can be calculated based on regulations from the [[United States Department of Energy|DOE]] and its energy content for a U.S. gallon of gasoline of 33,705 {{frac|Wh|gal}} (also called the [[Lower heating value|Lower Heating Value (LHV)]] of gasoline):{{cite web |url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/compx2008f.jsp?year=2003&make=Toyota&model=RAV4%20EV&hiddenField=Findacar |title=fueleconomy.gov 2003 Toyota RAV4 EV |year=2003 |publisher=[[USDOE]] and [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] |accessdate=May 11, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115024534/https://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/compx2008f.jsp?year=2003&make=Toyota&model=RAV4%20EV&hiddenField=Findacar |archivedate=January 15, 2009 }} :\frac{33705\,\frac{\mathrm{Wh}}{\mathrm{gal_{ge}}}} {135\,\frac{\mathrm{Wh}}{\mathrm{km}} \times \frac{1.6\, \mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{mi}}} \times 77.6 \% {\mathrm{_{charging\ eff.}}}= 120 \,\mathrm{mpg_{ge}} = 1.95 \frac{\mathrm{L_{ge}}}{100\, \mathrm{km}} For [[Corporate average fuel economy|CAFE]] regulatory purposes, the [[United States Department of Energy|DOE]]'s full petroleum-equivalency equation combines the primary energy efficiencies of the USA [[electric power transmission|electric grid]] and the well-to-pump path with a "fuel content factor" that quantifies the value of conservation, scarcity of fuels, and energy security in the USA.{{cite journal | publisher=[[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)]], Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy |title=10 CFR Part 474, Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Research, Development, and Demonstration Program; Petroleum-Equivalent Fuel Economy Calculation; Final Rule |volume=64 |number=113 | date=July 12, 2000 |url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=2000_register&docid=00-14446-filed.pdf |accessdate=September 22, 2006 }} This combination yields a factor of 82,049 {{frac|Wh|gal}} in the above equation and a regulatory fuel efficiency of 293 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent|mpgge]]CAFE. [[File:Roadster 2.5 charging.jpg|thumb|Tesla Roadster 2.5 charging from a conventional outlet]] Recharging with electricity from the average US grid, the factor changes to 12,307 {{frac|Wh|galUS}} to remove the "fuel content factor" = {{frac|1|0.15}} and the above equation yields a [[life cycle energy analysis|full-cycle energy-equivalency]] of 44.0 mpgge full-cycle. For full-cycle comparisons, the sticker or "pump-to-wheel" value from a gasoline-fueled vehicle must be multiplied by the fuel's "well-to-pump" efficiency; the DOE regulation specifies a "well-to-pump" efficiency of 83% for gasoline. The [[Prius]]'s sticker{{cite web |url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/compx2008f.jsp?year=2008&make=Toyota&model=Prius&hiddenField=Findacar |title=Model 1 Vehicle Characteristics |publisher=Fueleconomy.gov |date=September 10, 2006 |accessdate=June 21, 2011}} {{convert|46|mpgus|abbr=on}}, for example, converts to a full-cycle energy-equivalent of 38.2 mpgfull-cycle. Recharging with electricity generated by newer, 58% efficiency [[Combined cycle|CCGT]] power plants,{{cite news | url=http://www.fossil.energy.gov/news/techlines/2003/tl_baglanbay.html | title = Advanced Natural Gas Turbine Hailed as Top Power Project of 2003 | publisher = [[United States Department of Energy|DOE]] | date=December 30, 2003 | accessdate = March 14, 2007 }} changes the factor to 21,763 {{frac|Wh|gal}} in the above equation and yields a fuel efficiency of 77.7 mpgge. Recharging with non-fossil fuel electricity sources such as [[hydroelectricity|hydroelectric]], [[solar power]], [[wind power|wind]] or [[nuclear power|nuclear]], the petroleum equivalent efficiency can be even higher as fossil fuel is not directly used in refueling.{{cite web |url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/evtech.shtml |title=Electric Vehicles (EVs) |publisher=Fueleconomy.gov |accessdate=June 9, 2009}} == Service == Whereas vehicles with internal combustion engines require more frequent service for oil changes and routine maintenance on engine components and other related systems, Tesla's website recommends the owner bring the vehicle in for service "once a year or every 12,000 [[mile]]s".{{cite web|url=https://www.teslamotors.com/own/service|title=Service Everywhere | Own a Tesla | Tesla Motors|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=August 7, 2010}} For other concerns with vehicles, Tesla created a "mobile service unit" that dispatches company-trained technicians to customers' homes or offices in case the owner is experiencing problems. Tesla charges the customer according to the distance the service unit needs to travel: one US dollar per mile roundtrip with a 100-dollar minimum. Technicians drive company vans equipped with numerous tools and testing equipment to do "in the field" repairs, enhancements and software upgrades. Tesla debuted this "house call" approach in the spring of 2009, when the company announced a recall due to a manufacturing problem in the Lotus assembly plant, which also affected the Lotus Elise and other models from the British sports car maker.{{cite web|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1376|title=Press Releases|publisher=Tesla Motors|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611150607/http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1376|archivedate=June 11, 2009|url-status=dead|accessdate=August 30, 2009}} The first Tesla service center, in Los Angeles, [[California]], was opened on [[Santa Monica Boulevard]] on May 1, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2008/05/02/first-tesla-store-opens-in-santa-monica-now-we-just-need-some-c/|title=First Tesla store opens in Santa Monica, now we just need some cars|last=Abuelsamid|first=Sam|date=May 2, 2008}} Tesla publicly opened their second showroom and service area in [[Menlo Park, California]] on July 22, 2008. The Menlo Park location is also the final assembly area for Tesla Roadsters. Tesla also operates service centers in [[New York City]], [[Miami]], [[Chicago]], and [[Seattle]]. In 2007, Tesla announced plans to build additional service centers over the following few years to support sales of its next vehicle, the [[Tesla Model S|Model S sports sedan]]. This included an additional 15 service centers in United States major metropolitan locations.{{cite news|url=http://pogue.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/04/05/solving-the-car-propulsion-problem/|title=Solving the Car Propulsion Problem|last=Pogue|first=David|date=April 5, 2007|newspaper=The New York Times}} Possible locations for sales and service locations in Europe were announced in a letter to customers in May 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog2/?p=59|title=Program Update | Blog|last=Motors|first=Tesla|date=May 15, 2008|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=April 18, 2011}} === Recalls === {{As of|2017|05}}, Tesla has issued two product safety recalls for the Roadster.{{cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/11/tesla-recalls-2700-model-x-cars-for-seat-problem/|title=Tesla Recalls 2,700 Model X Cars for Seat Problem|last=Fehrenbacher|first=Katie|date=April 11, 2016|work=Fortune|accessdate=April 12, 2016}} In May 2009, Tesla issued a recall for 345 Roadsters manufactured before April 22, 2009. Tesla sent technicians to customers' homes to tighten the rear, inner hub flange bolts. Using wording from the [[National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration]], Tesla told customers that without this adjustment, the driver could lose control of the car.{{cite web|url=http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-13746_7-10251758-48.html|title=Tesla Motors recalls electric Roadster|last=Ashe|first=Suzanne|date=May 28, 2009|accessdate=January 11, 2013|website=CNET}} The problem originated at the [[Lotus Cars|Lotus]] assembly line, where the Roadster glider was built. Lotus also recalled some [[Lotus Elise|Elise]] and [[Lotus Exige|Exige]] vehicles for the same reason.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.motortrend.com/cars/2009/lotus/elise/recalls/index.html|title=2009 Lotus Elise Recalls—2009 Lotus Elise Recall Reports|magazine=Motor Trend|accessdate=October 25, 2009}} On October 1, 2010, Tesla issued a second product safety recall in the US affecting 439 Roadsters. The recall involved the 12V low-voltage auxiliary cable from a redundant back-up system. The recall followed an incident where the low voltage auxiliary cable in a vehicle chafed against the edge of a carbon fiber panel, causing a short, smoke and a possible fire behind the right front headlamp. This issue was limited to the 12V low-voltage auxiliary cable and did not involve the main battery pack or main power system.{{cite press release|title=Tesla Initiates Voluntary Recall After Single Customer Incident|date=October 1, 2010|publisher=Tesla Motors|url=http://www.tesla.com/about/press/releases/tesla-initiates-voluntary-recall-after-single-customer-incident|accessdate=October 20, 2010}} == Reviews == Tesla Roadster reviews can be grouped in two main categories: older reviews of "validation prototypes" (2006–2008), before Tesla began serial production and customer deliveries, and reviews on cars in serial production (2008–2010). The global online auto review site Autoguide.com tested Tesla's fourth-generation car in October 2010. Autoguide editor Derek Kreindler said "The Tesla Roadster 2.5 S is a massively impressive vehicle, more spacecraft than sports car. Theories like global warming, peak oil and rising oil prices should no longer bring heart palpitations to car fans. The Tesla shows just how good zero-emissions "green" technology can be. Quite frankly, getting into a normal car at the end of the test drive was a major letdown. The whirr of the engine, the shove in the backside and the little roadster that seems to pivot around you is replaced by a grunting, belching, feedback-free driving experience". He continues on that "but for a $100,000 car, it could use some work" complaining of purposefully cheap work.{{cite web |url=http://www.autoguide.com/manufacturer/tesla/2011-tesla-roadster-25-s-review-1444.html |title=2011 Tesla Roadster 2.5 S Review: Car Reviews |publisher=Autoguide.com |date=October 12, 2010 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}} In the March 2010 print edition of British enthusiast magazine ''EVO'' (p. 120), editor Richard Meaden was the first to review the all-new right-hand-drive version of the Roadster. He said the car had "serious, instantaneous muscle". "With so much torque from literally no revs the acceleration punch is wholly alien. Away from traffic lights you'd murder anything, be it a 911 Turbo, GT-R or 599, simply because while they have to mess about with balancing revs and clutch, or fiddle with launch controls and invalid warranties, all you have to do is floor the throttle and wave goodbye". In December 2009, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' editor Joseph White conducted an extended test-drive and determined that "you can have enormous fun within the legal speed limit as you whoosh around unsuspecting Camry drivers, zapping from 40 to 60 miles per hour in two seconds while the startled victims eat your electric dust". White praised the car's environmental efficiency but said consumer demand reflected not the environmental attributes of the car but its performance. "The Tesla turns the frugal environmentalist aesthetic on its head. Sure, it doesn't burn petroleum, and if plugged into a wind turbine or a nuclear plant, it would be a very low-carbon machine. But anyone who buys one will get the most satisfaction from smoking someone's doors off. The Tesla's message is that "green" technology can appeal to the id, not just the superego".{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704201404574589900770542192 |work=The Wall Street Journal |title=The Surge in Electric Cars |date=December 16, 2009 |first=Joseph B. |last=White}} In December 2009, ''Motor Trend'' was the first to independently confirm the Roadster Sport's reported {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} time of 3.7 seconds. (''Motor Trend'' recorded {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} of 3.70 seconds; it recorded a quarter-mile test at 12.6 sec at {{convert|102.6|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}). Engineering editor Kim Reynolds called the acceleration "breathtaking" and said the car confirms "Tesla as an actual car company. ...Tesla is the first maker to crack the EV legitimacy barrier in a century".{{cite magazine |url=http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/alternative/112_0912_2010_tesla_roadster_sport_test/specs.html#ixzz0b8yiYKO0 |title=2010 Tesla Roadster Sport Specs |magazine=Motor Trend |accessdate=October 9, 2010}} In November 2009, ''Automobile Magazine West Coast'' editor Jason Cammisa spent a week driving a production Tesla Roadster.{{cite web |url=http://www.automobilemag.com/green/reviews/0911_2009_tesla_roadster_electric_car/index.html |title=2009 Electric Tesla Roadster – Electric Convertible Sport Coupe – Automobile Magazine |publisher=Automobilemag.com |accessdate=October 9, 2010}} Cammisa was immediately impressed with the acceleration, saying the car "explodes off the line, pulling like a small jet plane. ... It's like driving a Lamborghini with a big V-12 revved over 6000 rpm at all times, waiting to pounce—without the noise, vibration, or misdemeanor arrest for disturbing the peace". He also took the car to [[Infineon Raceway]] in Sonoma, California, and praised the car for its robustness, saying the Roadster:
"wins the Coolest Car I've Ever Driven award. Why? Despite the flat-out sprints, the drag racing, the donuts, the top-speed runs, and dicing through traffic like there's a jet pack strapped to the trunk, [[Pacific Gas and Electric Company|Pacific Gas and Electric]]—which generated power for the Tesla—released into the atmosphere the same amount of carbon dioxide as would a gasoline-powered car getting 99 mpg. And the Roadster didn't break. It didn't smoke, lock up, freeze, or experience [[Flux capacitor|flux-capacitor]] failure. Over the past ten decades, no company has been able to reinvent the car—not General Motors with the EV1, not Toyota with the Prius. And now, a bunch of dudes from Silicon Valley have created an electric car that really works—as both an environmental fix and a speed fix".
In 2009 the Tesla Roadster was one of the Scandinavian Sports Car of the Year participants. In a comparison made by Nordic car magazines ''[[Tekniikan Maailma]]'' (Finland), ''[[Teknikens Värld]]'' (Sweden) and [[Bil Magasinet|''Bil Magasine''t]] (Denmark), critics praised the torque of the car and a track car structure, but also highlighted more negative aspects such as a short battery life; they were unable to drive a full track lap in dry track conditions.{{cite web |url=http://tekniikanmaailma.fi/autot/vertailut/tm-vertailu-scandinavian-sports-car-of-the-year-2009 |title=Scandinavian Sports Car of the Year 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2011 |year=2009 |work=tekniikanmaailma.fi |language=fi}} In May 2009, ''[[Car and Driver]]'' technical editor Aaron Robinson wrote a review based on the first extended test-drive of a production Tesla Roadster. Robinson had the car for nearly a week at his home. He complained of "design anomalies, daily annoyances, absurd ergonomics, and ridiculous economics " and stated he never got to see if the car could go 240 miles on a single charge because the torturous seating forced him to stop driving the car. He also complained of Tesla increasing the car prices on those who had already made deposits and charging extra for previously free necessary components.[http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/car/09q2/2009_tesla_roadster-road_test 2009 Tesla Roadster – Road Test], ''Car and Driver'', May 2009. Retrieved August 23, 2009. In February 2009, automotive critic Dan Neil of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called the production Tesla Roadster "a superb piece of machinery: stiff, well sorted, highly focused, dead-sexy and eerily quick". Neil said he had the car for 24 hours but "caned it like the Taliban caned Gillette salesmen and it never even blinked".Neil, Dan. [http://articles.latimes.com/2009/feb/06/business/fi-neil6 Tesla Roadster packs power in a flash of electricity], ''Los Angeles Times'', February 6, 2009. Retrieved August 23, 2009. In February 2009, ''[[Road & Track]]'' tested another production vehicle and conducted the first independently verified metered testing of the Roadster. Engineering editor Dennis Simanitis said the testing confirmed what he called "extravagant claims", that the Roadster had a 4.0 s {{convert|0|to|60|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}} acceleration and a {{convert|200|mi|order=flip|adj=on}} range. They said the Roadster felt like "an over-ballasted [[Lotus Elise]]", but the weight was well-distributed, so the car remained responsive. "Fit and finish of our Tesla were exemplary", which ''Road & Track'' thought fit the target market. Overall, they considered it a "delight" to drive.{{cite magazine | url=http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=10&article_id=7297&page_number=2 | title=World Exclusive: First Complete Test of the 2009 Tesla Roadster | magazine=Road & Track | accessdate=December 21, 2008 | date=February 2009}} Testing a pre-production car in early 2008, ''Road & Track'' said "The Tesla feels composed and competent at speed with great turn-in and transitioning response", though they recommended against it as a "primary grocery-getter".{{cite magazine |url=http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=2&article_id=6393 |title=First Drive: 2008 Tesla Roadster |magazine=Road & Track |date=March 2008 |accessdate=March 21, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306115842/http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=2&article_id=6393 |archive-date=March 6, 2008 |url-status=dead }} In January 2009, automotive critic Warren Brown of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called the production Roadster "a head-turner, jaw-dropper. It is sexy as all get-out". He described the feeling behind the wheel as, "Wheeeeeee! Drive a Tesla, even if you have to fly to Tesla's Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters, to get your hands on one for a day. ... If this is the future of the automobile, I want it".Brown, Warren. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/23/AR2009012301591.html A Jaw-Dropping Ride, Batteries Included], ''Washington Post'', January 25, 2009. Retrieved August 23, 2009. In a review of a Roadster prototype before the cars were in serial production, ''[[Motor Trend]]'' gave a generally favorable review in March 2008, stating that, it was "undeniably, unbelievably efficient" and would be "profoundly humbling to just about any rumbling Ferrari or Porsche that makes the mistake of pulling up next to a silent, {{convert|105|mpgus|abbr=on|order=flip}} Tesla Roadster at a stoplight"; however, they detected a "nasty drive-train buck" during the test drive of an early Roadster with the older, two-speed transmission.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/alternative/112_0803_2008_tesla_roadster/index.html |title=First Drive: 2008 Tesla Roadster |magazine=Motor Trend |accessdate=March 21, 2008}} In a July 8, 2007, review of a prototype Roadster, [[Jay Leno]] wrote, "If you like sports cars and you want to be green, this is the only way to go. The Tesla is a car that you can live with, drive and enjoy as a sports car. I had a brief drive in the car and it was quite impressive. This is an electric car that is fun to drive".{{cite news |url=http://driving.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/driving/new_car_reviews/article2036260.ece?OTC-HPtoppuff&ATTR=tesla |title=Tesla Roadster – The most fun you can have without fuel |first=Jay |last=Leno |newspaper=The Sunday Times |date=July 8, 2007 |location=London}} In a November 27, 2006, review of a prototype Roadster in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', Paul Boutin wrote, "A week ago, I went for a spin in the fastest, most fun car I've ever ridden in—and that includes the Aston Martin I tried to buy once. I was so excited, in fact, that I decided to take a few days to calm down before writing about it. Well, my waiting period is over, I'm thinking rationally, and I'm still unbelievably stoked about the Tesla".{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2154425/ |title=It's Electric! The Tesla Roadster—a hotshot sports car that runs on batteries |first=Paul |last=Boutin |publisher=www.Slate.com |date=November 27, 2006}} === ''Top Gear'' controversy === In the third quarter of 2008, [[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|''Top Gear'']]'s [[Jeremy Clarkson]] reviewed two production Roadsters with the v1.5 transmission and described the driving experience with the exclamations "God Almighty! Wave goodbye to the world of dial-up, and say hello to the world of broadband motoring!" and "This car is biblically quick!" when comparing the acceleration versus the car the Roadster was based on, a [[Lotus Elise]]. Clarkson also noted, however, that the handling of the car was not as sharp as that of the Elise: "through the corners things are less rosy". {{ cite news | last= Clarkson | first= Jeremy | title= Tesla Roadster | newspaper= The Sunday Times | date= January 11, 2009 | url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/driving/jeremy_clarkson/article5483422.ece | accessdate= August 29, 2009 }} [[The Stig]] recorded a time of 1:27.2 on a moist track, faster than a [[Nissan 370Z]] on a dry track but slower than a [[Porsche 911]] C2S also on a damp track, and also slower than the [[Lotus Exige]], Exige S and [[Lotus Evora|Evora]]. {{cite news | title= Top Gear Track, Great Britain | work= FastestLaps | url= http://www.fastestlaps.com/track1.html | accessdate= August 29, 2009 }} The segment also claimed that the car's batteries would run flat after {{convert|55|mi|abbr=on|order=flip}} of heavy use on a track {{cite news | first= Chuck | last= Squatriglia | title= Judge Tosses Tesla's Case Against Top Gear | work= Wired | date= February 23, 2012 | url= https://www.wired.com/autopia/2012/02/tesla-vs-top-gear/ }} and showed the car being pushed off the track. {{cite web | title= Top Gear row: Tesla loses appeal over Jeremy Clarkson review | first= Josh | last= Halliday | work= the Guardian | url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/mar/05/top-gear-tesla-jeremy-clarkson }} Tesla spokesperson responded with statements in blogs and to mainstream news organizations that the cars provided to ''Top Gear'' never had less than 20% charge and never experienced brake failure. {{cite web | last= Squatriglia | first= Chuck | title= Tesla Cries Foul On Top Gear's Test | website= Wired.com | date= December 16, 2008 | url= https://www.wired.com/autopia/2008/12/tesla-cries-fou/ | accessdate= August 30, 2009 }} In addition, neither car provided to ''Top Gear'' needed to be pushed off the track at any point. {{cite web |title = "Tesla Roadster Reviewed by Jeremy Clarkson Didn't Run Out of Juice as He Claimed" Green Car Advisor |publisher = Blogs.edmunds.com |date = January 15, 2009 |url = http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2008/12/tesla-roadster-reviewed-by-jeremy-clarkson-didnt-run-out-of-juice-as-he-claimed.html |accessdate = August 30, 2009 |url-status = dead |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090326082224/http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2008/12/tesla-roadster-reviewed-by-jeremy-clarkson-didnt-run-out-of-juice-as-he-claimed.html |archivedate = March 26, 2009 }} Clarkson also showed a [[wind turbine]] with stationary rotor blades and complained that it would take countless hours to refuel the car using such a source of electricity, although the car can be charged from a 240 V 70 A outlet in as little as 3.5 hours. {{cite web | title= Tesla clears up some of Clarkson's claims during Tesla Roadster test drive | publisher= egmCarTech | date= December 16, 2008 | url= http://www.egmcartech.com/2008/12/16/tesla-clears-up-some-of-clarksons-calims-during-tesla-roadster-test-drive/ | accessdate= May 5, 2009 }} After numerous blogs and several large news organizations began following the controversy, {{cite news | last= Chang | first= Richard S. | title= Was 'Top Gear' Test of the Tesla Misleading? | work= The New York Times | date= December 30, 2008 | url= http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/30/was-top-gears-test-of-tesla-roadster-misleading/ | accessdate= August 30, 2009 }} the BBC issued a statement saying "the tested Tesla was filmed being pushed into the shed in order to show what would happen if the Roadster had run out of charge. ''Top Gear'' stands by the findings in this film and is content that it offers a fair representation of the Tesla's performance on the day it was tested", without addressing the other alleged misrepresentations that Tesla highlighted to the media. {{cite web | last= Taylor | first= Alun | title= BBC: Top Gear Tesla didn't run out of juice | publisher= Register Hardware | date= December 22, 2008 | url= http://www.reghardware.co.uk/2008/12/22/bbc_top_gear_tesla/ | accessdate= May 5, 2009 }} After several weeks of increasing pressure and inquiries from the BBC, Clarkson wrote a blog entry for ''[[The Times]]'', acknowledging that "Inevitably, the film we had shot was a bit of a mess. There was a handful of shots of a silver car. Some of a grey car". "But as a device for moving you and your things around, it is about as much use as a bag of muddy spinach". In the months that followed Clarkson's acknowledgment, the original episode—including the misstatements—reran on BBC America and elsewhere without any editing, though the BBC is still looking into ''Top Gear''{{'}}s journalism standards, according to British media reports. {{cite news | title= Jeremy Clarkson sparks new BBC row over Top Gear electric supercar test 'failure' | work= Mail Online | location= London | date= April 20, 2014 | url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1101836/Jeremy-Clarkson-sparks-new-BBC-row-Top-Gear-electric-supercar-test-failure.html }} On March 29, 2011, Tesla sued the programme over [[Defamation|libel]] and [[malicious falsehood]], while simultaneously launching the website TeslaVsTopGear.com. The current position of Tesla is found on its web page. {{cite web | title= tesla vs Top Gear | publisher= www.teslamotors.com | date= February 11, 2013 | url= http://www.teslamotors.com/teslavstopgear | accessdate= February 11, 2013 }} In a blogpost, producer [[Andy Wilman]] has referred to Tesla's allegations as a "crusade" and contested the truth value of Tesla's statements. {{cite web | last= Wilman | first= Andy | title= Transmission – BBC Top Gear Tesla vs Top Gear: Andy Wilman on our current legal action | publisher= Transmission.blogs.topgear.com | date= April 2, 2011 | url= http://transmission.blogs.topgear.com/2011/04/02/tesla-vs-top-gear-andy-wilman-on-our-current-legal-action/ | accessdate= April 18, 2011 }} On October 19, 2011, the [[High Court]] in London rejected Tesla's libel claim. {{cite news | title= Tesla losing Top Gear court challenge | newspaper= The Independent | date= October 21, 2011 | url= http://www.iol.co.za/motoring/industry-news/tesla-losing-top-gear-court-challenge-1.1162112 | accessdate= October 21, 2011 }} Tesla appealed High Court's decision to the Court of Appeal, where a three-judge panel of Lords Justice upheld the lower court's decision, and ordered Tesla to pay the BBC's legal costs of £100,000. {{cite news | newspaper= The Guardian | date= May 5, 2013 | title= Top Gear row: Tesla loses appeal over Jeremy Clarkson review | url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/mar/05/top-gear-tesla-jeremy-clarkson | accessdate= November 4, 2013 }} == Sales == Tesla delivered approximately 2,450 Roadsters worldwide between February 2008 and December 2012. Featuring new options and enhanced features, the 2012 Tesla Roadster was sold in limited numbers only in mainland Europe, Asia and Australia, and as of July 2012, less than 140 units were available for sale in Europe and Asia before the remaining inventory would be sold out. Tesla's US exemption for not having special two-stage passenger airbags expired for cars made after the end of 2011 so the last Roadsters were not sold in the American market for [[government regulation|regulatory]] reasons. The U.S. was the leading market with about 1,800 Roadsters sold.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/top-6-plug-in-car-adopting-countries/7/|title=Top 6 Plug-In Vehicle Adopting Countries|last=Cobb|first=Jeff|date=January 16, 2014|publisher=HybridCars.com|accessdate=August 29, 2016}} ''Around 1,800 Tesla Roadsters and 1,600 Fisker Karmas had been sold in the U.S. by the end of 2013.'' There were fewer than 50 right-hand-drive models of the Tesla Roadster produced and hand built in the UK. [[File:TSLA S1 zoom in.jpg|thumb|Roadster with California's Clean Air Vehicle stickers (at the extremes of the bumper) that allows access to [[HOV lanes]] with solo driver]] === United States === The Roadster had a three-year, {{convert|36000|mi|km|abbr=on|order=flip|adj=on}} warranty. Tesla also offered an extended powertrain warranty and a battery replacement warranty. In July 2009, Tesla announced that US consumers could finance the Roadster through [[Bank of America]]. Financing was available for up to 75% of the total vehicle purchase price.{{cite web|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1568|title=Press Releases|publisher=Tesla Motors|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718112150/http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=1568|archivedate=July 18, 2009|url-status=dead|accessdate=August 30, 2009}} Tesla sold Roadsters directly to customers. It sold them online, in 13 showrooms and over the phone in North America and Europe. Tesla does not operate through franchise dealerships but operates company-owned stores. The company said that it took its retail cues from Apple, Starbucks and other non-automotive retailers.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/06/05/seven-new-tesla-stores-will-open-soon-one-roadster-makes-it-to|title=Seven new Tesla stores will open soon; one Roadster makes it to Yosemite|website=Autoblog.com}} [[File:Tesla Roadster Japanese display.jpg|thumb|Roadster charging in a Japanese showroom]] === Outside the United States === The company has been shipping cars to European customers since mid-2009. Tesla sold out of its EU special-edition vehicle, which had a 2010 model-year production run of 250 cars.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/721ce1de-0059-11dd-825a-000077b07658.html|title=Tesla to sell electric cars in Europe|date=April 2, 2008|work=Financial Times|accessdate=June 9, 2009}} A total of 575 units have been sold in Europe through October 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.france-mobilite-electrique.org/IMG/pdf/12_EUROPE_18.pdf|title=Inmatriculations VP et VUL Europe 18 à fin Oct. (2010–2012) 2012|last=Aschard|first=Justin|date=November 30, 2012|publisher=France Mobilité Électrique|language=French|trans-title=Registrations of passenger cars and utility vehicles in Europe 18 through October 2012 (2010–2012)|accessdate=December 5, 2012}} Tesla first overseas showroom opened in London in 2009, with right-hand-drive models promised for early 2010. Showrooms in Munich and Monaco were also added in 2009, followed by Zurich and Copenhagen in 2010 and Milan in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.omniauto.it/magazine/14826/tesla-roadster-apre-a-milano-showroom|title=Tesla apre a Milano|date=December 15, 2003|publisher=Omniauto.it|accessdate=June 21, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alvolante.it/news/elon_musk_tesla-407946|title=A tu per tu con Elon Musk, l’uomo-Tesla|publisher=Alvolante.it|accessdate=June 21, 2011}} Reservations for the 2010 Roadster were available for a €3,000 refundable reservation fee.{{cite news|url=http://www6.lexisnexis.com/publisher/EndUser?Action=UserDisplayFullDocument&orgId=101846&topicId=104970025&docId=l:840211257|title=The Green Mean Machine|last=Prigg|first=Mark|date=August 21, 2008|newspaper=The Evening Standard|accessdate=August 22, 2008|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/buy/resyourcar.php|title=Tesla Motors|date=July 6, 2007|publisher=Tesla Motors|accessdate=June 9, 2009}} From 2009 to 2014, Hansjoerg von Gemmingen of Karlsruhe, Germany drove his Tesla Roadster {{convert|400000|km|abbr=on|adj=on}}, this being the mileage world record for an all-electric vehicle{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/auto/aktuell/200-000-kilometer-mit-dem-elektroauto-tesla-roadster-a-831761.html|title=200,000 Kilometer im Tesla Roadster|last=Grünweg|first=Tom|date=May 8, 2012|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=June 30, 2012|language=German|trans-title=200,000 km in the Tesla Roadster}}{{cite news|last1=Nils Victor|first1=Sorge|title=Manager Magazin|url=http://www.manager-magazin.de/lifestyle/auto/interview-mit-tesla-roadster-vielfahrer-hansjoerg-von-gemmingen-a-996916.html|accessdate=December 28, 2017|date=October 16, 2014}} and reached {{convert|520000|km|abbr=on|adj=on}} in 2017. He also drove another {{convert|200000|km|abbr=on|adj=on}} in an Tesla Model S and voiced his plan to become the first man to travel a million kilometres in an electric vehicle.{{cite news |url=http://unterwegs-auf-der-autobahn.de/der-marathon-kilometer-mann |title=Der Marathon-Kilometer-Mann |trans-title=The Marathon Kilometer Man |work=Unterwegs auf der Autobahn |language=German |location=Germany |date=November 10, 2017 |access-date=January 28, 2018}} Kevin Yu, the director of Tesla Motors Asia Pacific, said Roadsters in Japan had additional yearly taxes for exceeding the width limit of [[Vehicle size class#Japan|normal sized]] cars. === Controversy === In 2009, Roadster reservation holders who had already placed deposits up to US$50,000 to lock in their orders were informed that their orders had been unlocked and that they had to re-option their ordered vehicles on the threat of losing their spot on the orders list. Tesla then raised the prices of several options, and a new Tesla Roadster with the same set of features that had previously been standard became US$6,700 more expensive than before.{{cite news|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/01/20/tesla-raises-prices-on-roadster-options-sparks-controversy-ang/|title=Tesla raises prices on Roadster options, sparks controversy, anger among early adopters|last=Korzeniewski|first=Jeremy|date=January 20, 2009|work=Autoblog|access-date=April 18, 2017}} For example, the high performance charger that was previously claimed to be standard on all vehicles was changed to be an optional feature costing US$3,000, and the previously claimed standard forged alloy wheels became a US$2,300 upgrade.{{cite news|url=http://www.saxton.org/tom_saxton/2009/01/tesla-price-increase.html|title=Tesla Increases Prices on Locked-In Orders|last=Saxton|first=Tom|date=January 15, 2009|access-date=April 18, 2017}} One person who pre-ordered a Tesla Roadster complained: {{quote|"I am [pre-ordered owner] number 395. I am not a rich person dabbling in a plaything. I thought I was actually doing some good by supporting a company that was moving us to a more sustainable future. I put $50,000 of my own money down on this car in May of 2007. I withstood the delays. I held in there when it almost seemed the company was going bankrupt. Now, after locking in my options, they pull this on me."{{cite news |title=Bad PR: Tesla Forces Pre-Ordered Roadster Owners to Pay More |url=https://forcechange.com/1881/bad-pr-tesla-forces-pre-ordered-roadster-owners-to-pay-more/ |work=ForceChange |date=2009-01-17 |access-date=2017-04-18}} }} == Awards == The world distance record of {{convert|501|km|abbr=on}} for a production electric car on a single charge was set by a Roadster on October 27, 2009, during the Global Green Challenge in outback Australia, in which it averaged a speed of {{convert|25|mph|abbr=on|order=flip}}.{{cite news |author=tsport100 |url= http://electric-vehicles-cars-bikes.blogspot.com/2011/01/new-world-record-tesla-roadster-goes.html |title=New World Record: Tesla Roadster Goes 347.2 Miles On One Charge |work=Electric Vehicle News |date=January 5, 2011 |accessdate=April 18, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.globalgreenchallenge.com.au/assets/media/event/TESLA%20WORLD%20RECORD%20IN%20GLOBAL%20GREEN%20CHALLENGE.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180827075230/http://www.globalgreenchallenge.com.au/assets/media/event/TESLA%20WORLD%20RECORD%20IN%20GLOBAL%20GREEN%20CHALLENGE.doc |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 27, 2018 |title=Internode Electric Tesla sets world distance record in 2009 Global Green Challenge |publisher=Global Green Challenge |accessdate=November 3, 2009 }} In March 2010, a Tesla Roadster became the first electric vehicle to win the Monte Carlo Alternative Energy Rally and the first to win any Federation Internationale de l'Automobile-sanctioned championship when a Roadster driven by former Formula One driver [[Érik Comas]] beat 96 competitors for range, efficiency and performance in the three-day, nearly {{convert|1,000|km|mi|adj=on}} challenge.{{cite press release|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-sweeps-monte-carlo-alternative-energy-rally|title=Tesla Sweeps Monte Carlo Alternative Energy Rally|publisher=Tesla Motors|date=March 29, 2010|accessdate=October 9, 2010|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120911065827/http://www.teslamotors.com/about/press/releases/tesla-sweeps-monte-carlo-alternative-energy-rally|archive-date=September 11, 2012|url-status=live}} * [[INDEX: Award]] 2007{{cite web | url=http://www.indexaward.dk/2007/default.asp?id=709&Article=847&Folder=847 | title=INDEX Award 2007 }} * ''[[BusinessWeek]]'': Best Product ''[[duPont|duPont REGISTRY]]''{{cite web |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2008/10/09/dupont-registrys-11-best-of-cars-set-horsepower-price-record/ |title=duPont Registry's 11 "Best of" cars set horsepower, price records |accessdate=March 20, 2008 |last=Ramsey |first=Jonathon |date=October 9, 2008 |work=[[Autoblog.com|Autoblog]] |publisher=[[Weblogs, Inc.]] }} == Space launch == {{main|Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster}} Elon Musk announced that his personal Tesla Roadster would be launched into space, serving as [[dummy payload]] on [[Falcon Heavy Test Flight|the maiden flight of]] the [[SpaceX]] [[Falcon Heavy]] rocket.{{cite news|last1=Berger|first1=Eric|title=SpaceX will attempt to launch a red Tesla to the red planet [Updated]|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/12/with-bowie-playing-on-the-radio-elon-musk-plans-to-launch-his-tesla-to-mars/|accessdate=December 7, 2017|work=Ars Technica}} The launch on February 6, 2018 was successful; the vehicle was placed into a [[heliocentric orbit]] that will take it into the vicinity of [[Mars]]'s orbital path.{{cite web|last1=Plait|first1=Phil|title=Elon Musk: On the Roadster to Mars|url=http://www.syfy.com/syfywire/elon-musk-on-the-roadster-to-mars|website=Syfy|accessdate=December 8, 2017|date=December 2, 2017}} == See also == {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Category:Tesla, Inc. vehicles|Roadster]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2007]]

{{hatnote|For Tesla's first sports car, see [[Tesla Roadster (2008)]].}} {{short description|Second sports car from Tesla, Inc. (scheduled for delivery during 2020)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2019}} {{Infobox electric vehicle | name = Tesla Roadster | image = File:NextGenTeslaRoadster (cropped).jpg | manufacturer = [[Tesla, Inc.]] | aka = | model_years = Late 2020 - Early 2021 [To be commenced] | designer = [[Franz von Holzhausen]] | class = [[Sports car]] / [[Grand Tourer]] ([[S-segment|S]]) | body_style = 2-door [[coupe]] | layout = Triple motor, [[all-wheel drive]] | platform = | motor = 3 electric motors (one front, two rear) | powerout = | battery = {{convert|200|kWh|MJ|abbr=on|0}} | electric_range = {{convert|1000|km|mi|-1|abbr=in}} | charging = {{unbulleted list | '''Offboard charger''' | Supercharger V3 at >350 kW DC }} | transmission = | predecessor = [[Tesla Roadster (2008)]] }} The '''Tesla Roadster''' is a concept [[electric car|all-electric]] [[battery electric vehicle|battery-powered]] four-seater [[sports car]] made by [[Tesla, Inc.]]{{cite news|url=https://electrek.co/2016/05/16/tesla-next-gen-roadster-faster-bigger/|title=Tesla official describes the next generation Roadster as different, faster and bigger|first=Fred |last= Lambert |date=May 16, 2016|publisher=electrek |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621140707/https://electrek.co/2016/05/16/tesla-next-gen-roadster-faster-bigger/|archivedate=June 21, 2017 }} Tesla has said it will be capable of {{cvt|0|to|60|mph|km/h|order=flip|sigfig=1}} in 2.1 seconds,Acceleration times:
  • 2.1s: standing start {{convert|0|-|100|km/h|mph|0|order=flip}}, without rollout allowance.
  • 1.9s: rolling start ~{{convert|6|-|60|mph|km/h|0}}, with 1-foot [[rollout (drag racing)|rollout]] allowance
{{cite twitter|number=1144241444435238913|title=2.1 sec 0-60 mph is base model before adding rocket thruster option|date=2019-06-27|first=Elon|last=Musk|user=elonmusk|authorlink=Elon Musk}} or an optional 1.9 seconds if you opt for their SpaceX package, which is [[List of fastest production cars by acceleration|quicker]] than any [[Street-legal vehicle|street legal]] [[production car]] to date at its announcement in November 2017.{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-truck/new-200000-tesla-roadster-speeds-in-front-of-electric-big-rig-truck-idUSKBN1DG1LW |title= New $200,000 Tesla Roadster speeds in front of electric big-rig truck |first= Alexandria |last= Sage |date= November 16, 2017 |agency= Reuters |url-status= live |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171117090831/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-truck/new-200000-tesla-roadster-speeds-in-front-of-electric-big-rig-truck-idUSKBN1DG1LW |archivedate= November 17, 2017}} The Roadster is the successor to Tesla's first production car, which was the [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|2008 Roadster]]. Tesla CEO [[Elon Musk]] has said that Roadster sales will begin after the release of the revised Model S, which itself is expected in late 2020.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-tweets-tesla-roadster-might-not-need-key-2019-11|title=Elon Musk says the Tesla 2020 Roadster 'maybe won't need a key at all'|last=Holmes|first=Aaron|website=Business Insider|access-date=2020-03-29}} Musk has said that higher-performance [[Trim level (automobile)|trim levels]] will be available beyond the base specifications, including a SpaceX package with about 10 [[cold gas thruster]]s.{{cite tweet |first=Elon |last=Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1005577738332172289 |title=SpaceX option package for new Tesla Roadster will include ~10 small rocket thrusters arranged seamlessly around car. These rocket engines dramatically improve acceleration, top speed, braking & cornering. Maybe they will even allow a Tesla to fly … |date=June 9, 2018|access-date=March 25, 2019}} ==Overview== === History === In 2011, at the end of the production run of the original [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]], Elon Musk suggested that a new version of the Roadster, without the Lotus chassis, would return to production by 2014.{{cite news |url= https://www.theverge.com/2011/10/31/2527364/tesla-roadster-resume-production-available-2014 |title= Tesla Roadster to return in 2014 |first= Jaime |last= Keene |date= October 31, 2011 |website= [[The Verge]] |url-status= live |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171117124448/https://www.theverge.com/2011/10/31/2527364/tesla-roadster-resume-production-available-2014 |archivedate= November 17, 2017}} The new Roadster was first teased in 2014.{{cite news|url=https://electrek.co/2017/06/13/tesla-roadster-next-gen-elon-musk-maximum-plaid/|title=Tesla Roadster next-gen: Elon Musk considers target under 2-second for 'Maximum Plaid'|first=Fred |last= Lambert|date=June 13, 2017|website=electrek|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117175503/https://electrek.co/2017/06/13/tesla-roadster-next-gen-elon-musk-maximum-plaid/|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }} At the time, it was also referred to as the ''Tesla Model R''.{{cite web |url= https://insideevs.com/2020-tesla-selling-5-electric-models-simultaneously/ |title= By 2020, Tesla Could Be Selling 5 Electric Models Simultaneously |author= Eric Loveday |date= September 3, 2014 |publisher= Inside EVs }} In 2015, Elon Musk suggested a new Roadster in 2019, capable of faster [[acceleration]].{{cite web |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/three-dog-day |first=Elon |last=Musk |title=Three Dog Day |publisher=[[Tesla, Inc.]] |date=July 17, 2015 |accessdate=August 30, 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://hothardware.com/news/tesla-launching-all-new-maximum-plaid-roadster-within-four-years |title=Tesla Motors Will Launch All-New 'Maximum Plaid' Roadster Within Four Years |first=Brandon |last=Hill |website=HotHardware |date=July 18, 2015 |accessdate=August 31, 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://mashable.com/2015/07/17/new-tesla-roadster/ |title=Tesla will launch a new roadster in 4 years (with nod to 'Spaceballs') |first=Chris |last=Perkins |website=Mashable |date=July 18, 2015 |accessdate=August 31, 2015}} A tweet by Elon Musk in December 2016 reconfirmed a second Roadster was in the works, but still "some years away".{{cite news |url=http://www.motortrend.com/news/elon-musk-confirms-new-roadster/|title=New Tesla Roadster Planned, Says Elon Musk |first=Jonathon |last=Klein |magazine=[[Motor Trend]] |location=US |date=December 28, 2016 |access-date=June 2, 2017}}{{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |number=812440156531662848 |title=@jelleprins Some years away, but yes |first=Elon |last=Musk |date=December 23, 2016 |access-date=June 1, 2017}} The second Roadster was designed by [[Franz von Holzhausen]].{{cite news |url= http://autoweek.com/article/car-news/tesla-roadster-sounds-incredible-it |title= Tesla Roadster Sounds Incredible But Will It Be That Good? |first= Mark |last=Vaughn |date= November 17, 2017 |magazine= [[AutoWeek]] |url-status= live |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171117175637/http://autoweek.com/article/car-news/tesla-roadster-sounds-incredible-it |archivedate= November 17, 2017}} The 2020 version of the Roadster was shown in a surprise moment at the end of the [[Tesla Semi]] event on November 16, 2017—during which a Roadster was driven out of the back of one of the semi-truck trailers to the song "[[Sabotage (song)|Sabotage]]".{{cite magazine|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/new-tesla-roadster|title=The new Tesla Roadster is Formula One car fast|magazine=[[British GQ]] |first=Jason |last=Barlow |authorlink=Jason Barlow|date=November 17, 2017|accessdate=November 21, 2017|quote=Beastie Boys classic "[[Sabotage (song)|Sabotage]]" was playing as the Roadster was disgorged from the Semi's trailer in front of a whooping audience.}} Musk explained the concept as: "The point of doing this is to give a hardcore smackdown to gasoline cars. Driving a gasoline sports car is going to feel like a steam engine with a side of quiche."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/17/tesla-roadster-electric-supercar-elon-musk-fast|title=Tesla Roadster: nine things we know about the 'smackdown to gasoline cars'|first=Samuel|last=Gibbs|date=November 17, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117132834/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/17/tesla-roadster-electric-supercar-elon-musk-fast|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }} The car will retail for upward of $200,000;{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2017/11/17/for-200000-tesla-will-sell-you-the-worlds-fastest-consumer-car/|title=For $200,000, Tesla will sell you the 'world's fastest' consumer car |first=Hamza |last=Shaban|date=November 17, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] }} test rides were given at the event for those who immediately paid the first $5,000 of a $50,000 deposit to pre-order the vehicle.{{Cite news|url=https://www.drive.com.au/motor-news/tesla-unveils-new-roadster-116378|title=Tesla unveils new Roadster|last=Maclean|first=Andrew|date=November 17, 2017 |website=Drive |access-date=November 18, 2017 |language=en-US|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119165455/https://www.drive.com.au/motor-news/tesla-unveils-new-roadster-116378 |archivedate=November 19, 2017}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.newsfactor.com/story.xhtml?story_id=106686 |title=Surprise! Tesla Announces New Roadster Amid Electric Truck Reveal |website=NewsFactor |language=en |access-date=November 18, 2017 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119165455/https://www.newsfactor.com/story.xhtml?story_id=106686 |archivedate=November 19, 2017 }}{{Cite web|url=http://autospies.com/news/All-new-Tesla-Roadster-STEALS-The-SEMI-s-Show-Musk-Plants-A-Flag-In-The-Ground-To-END-ICE-Vehicles-For-Good-94795/ |title=All-new Tesla Roadster STEALS The SEMI's Show — Musk Plants A Flag In The Ground To END ICE Vehicles For Good |website=AutoSpies Auto News |language=en|access-date=November 18, 2017|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171118073628/http://www.autospies.com/news/All-new-Tesla-Roadster-STEALS-The-SEMI-s-Show-Musk-Plants-A-Flag-In-The-Ground-To-END-ICE-Vehicles-For-Good-94795/|archivedate=November 18, 2017}} Additional information followed after the teaser, such as the various world-record speeds Tesla said it will break.{{cite news|url=https://electrek.co/2015/07/17/teslas-insanely-fast-model-s-just-got-faster-ludicrously-faster/|title=Tesla's insanely fast Model S just got faster, ludicrously faster |first=Jon |last= Jivan |date=July 17, 2015|website=electrek |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117174943/https://electrek.co/2015/07/17/teslas-insanely-fast-model-s-just-got-faster-ludicrously-faster/|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/7/17/8994649/new-tesla-roadster-four-years|title=It's official: Tesla is launching a new Roadster in four years|last=Ziegler|first=Chris|date=July 17, 2015|website=[[The Verge]]|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117175500/https://www.theverge.com/2015/7/17/8994649/new-tesla-roadster-four-years|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.autoexpress.co.uk/car-news/99251/2019-tesla-roadster-elon-musk-hints-at-two-second-0-60-target|title=2019 Tesla Roadster: Elon Musk hints at two second 0-60 target |first=James |last= Brodie |date=June 16, 2017 |website=Auto Express |url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170922054030/http://www.autoexpress.co.uk/car-news/99251/2019-tesla-roadster-elon-musk-hints-at-two-second-0-60-target|archivedate=September 22, 2017 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/2019-tesla-roadster-performance-specs-news-range/|title=Tesla's next Roadster will be one of the quickest cars in the world |first=Ronan |last= Glon|date=December 28, 2016 |website=Digital Trends |url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621140720/https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/2019-tesla-roadster-performance-specs-news-range/|archivedate=June 21, 2017 }} In June 2018, Elon Musk revealed a potential feature called "SpaceX option package" for the Roadster.{{cite news |url=https://www.autoblog.com/2018/06/09/tesla-roadster-spacex-option-package-performance/ |title=SpaceX option package for 2020 Tesla Roadster could add more performance |first=Jonathon |last=Ramsey |work=Auto Blog |location=US |date=June 9, 2018 |access-date=July 14, 2018}} This would add around ten [[cold gas thruster]]s to the car to improve maneuverability; it would comprise an electric pump to recharge an air tank used to provide [[compressed air]] flowing through [[propelling nozzle]]s to generate a cold jet thrust. The air tanks, based on "composite overwrapped pressure vessel" (COPV) also used in the [[Falcon 9]] and [[Falcon Heavy]] rockets, would replace the back seats. The thrusters would be used to improve cornering, acceleration, top speed, and braking.{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2018/06/10/tesla-roadster-elon-musk-thruster-backseat/ |title=Elon Musk is serious about adding thrusters to the new Tesla Roadster, the option will replace the back seats |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date= June 10, 2018 |publisher=Electrek |access-date=June 12, 2018}}{{cite news |url= http://fortune.com/2018/06/10/musk-tesla-roadster-spacex-rocket-thrusters/ |title= Elon Musk Says Tesla’s Next Roadster Will Feature Actual SpaceX Rocket Thrusters |first=David Z. |last=Morris |publisher=Fortune Magazine |date=June 10, 2018 |access-date=June 12, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/elon-musk-tesla-roadster-thrusters-very-serious/ |title=Elon Musk is 100 percent serious about Roadster thrusters |first=Andrew |last=Krok |publisher=CNET |work=Roadshow |date=June 11, 2018 |access-date=June 12, 2018}} Working pressure would be {{convert|10000|psi|bar|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}.{{cite interview|first=Elon|last=Musk|authorlink=Elon Musk|interviewer=[[Joe Rogan]]|title=Elon Musk|work=[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]|date=September 7, 2018|accessdate=September 8, 2018|url=http://podcasts.joerogan.net/podcasts/elon-musk|issue=1169|format=offset: 1.14:46‒1.15:25|quote=The next generation Roadster, … where you put rocket thrusters on it … ultra high compressed air … cold gas thrusters … electric pump … pump it up to like 10,000 psi … could make it fly}} === Pre-order marketing === [[Pre-order]]s of the Roadster began in 2017, with a US$50,000 deposit required. Tesla owners taking part in the referral promotion program began accumulating discounts toward the purchase of a Roadster based on the number of referrals. Those reaching 55 confirmed referrals obtained a 100% rebate toward a future Roadster purchase.{{cite news|url=https://jalopnik.com/tesla-is-offering-people-a-free-next-generation-roadste-1796866266|title=Tesla Is Offering People A Free Next Generation Roadster (If You Sell 50 Cars For Them) |first=Justin T. |last= Westbrook|date=July 12, 2017 |website=[[Jalopnik]] |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117174844/https://jalopnik.com/tesla-is-offering-people-a-free-next-generation-roadste-1796866266|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }}{{cite news|url=https://electrek.co/2017/09/28/tesla-referral-program-solar-panels-1000-credit-cars/|title=Tesla updates its referral program to include solar panels, new prizes, removing $1,000 credit on cars|first=Fred |last= Lambert|date=September 28, 2017|publisher=electrek|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117175442/https://electrek.co/2017/09/28/tesla-referral-program-solar-panels-1000-credit-cars/|archivedate=November 17, 2017 }} === Price === The base model was expected to sell for US $200,000 but the first 1,000 to be produced, known as the Founder's Series, will be priced at $250,000. Full payment would be required to pre-order the latter vehicle. == Design == [[File:Inside the new Tesla Roadster.jpg|thumb|Second generation Tesla Roadster interior]] The second-generation Tesla Roadster is a [[2+2 (car body style)|2+2]] [[coupé]]{{cite news |url=https://jalopnik.com/the-new-tesla-roadster-isn-t-actually-a-roadster-1820545274 |title=The New Tesla Roadster Isn’t Actually A Roadster |first=Tom |last=McParland |work=Jalopnik |location=US |date=November 17, 2017 |access-date=March 23, 2019}} with a removable [[automobile roof|glass roof]]. It was designed by [[Franz von Holzhausen]], who formerly worked at [[Mazda]] and [[Volkswagen]]. The Roadster has a 2+2 seating arrangements, with smaller rear seats for two passengers. The Roadster has three electric motors, one in front and two at the rear, allowing for [[all-wheel drive]], and [[torque vectoring]] during cornering. Tesla said that the vehicle had a {{cvt|200|kWh}} battery, twice the capacity of the largest battery in an existing Tesla car (in the [[Tesla Model S|Tesla Model S Performance or Long Range Plus]]), and the Roadster a {{convert|620|mi|km|-1|abbr=in|order=flip}} range on one charge at [[controlled-access highway|highway speed]]s. Tesla stated that the torque at wheels was {{Convert|10000|Nm|lbft|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. The rear wheels are larger than the front wheels.{{cite news|url=https://electrek.co/2017/11/20/teslas-next-gen-roadster-technical-analysis/|title=Tesla's Next-Gen Roadster: A (speculative) technical look at the car that will "smack down" gasoline powered cars|date=November 20, 2017|accessdate=November 22, 2017|website=Electrek |first=Jameson |last=Dow |quote=tires on the prototype are Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2 325/30ZR21 (104Y) rear and 295/35ZR20 front. These have a "Y" speed rating, which means they have a maximum speed of "over (300kmph)." They are the same tires used on the Porsche 918 Spyder (which has a /340kmph top speed).}} == Performance == [[File:Tesla Roadster 2.0 (47619421652).jpg|thumb|Second generation Tesla Roadster (2019)]] The following claims have been made by Musk for the prototype Roadster's acceleration: * {{Convert|0|–|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 1.9 seconds (without specifying if this includes a 1-foot [[rollout (drag racing)|rollout]] or not, or whether thrusters are used or not){{Cite tweet |user=elonmusk |last=Musk |first=Elon |number=931407490889084928 |title=0 to 100 km/h in 1.9 |date=November 16, 2017 |access-date=November 25, 2017}} * {{Convert|0|–|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on|order=flip}} in 2.1 seconds for the base model before adding rocket thruster option (without specifying if this includes a 1-foot [[rollout (drag racing)|rollout]] or not){{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |last=Musk |first=Elon |number=1144241444435238913 |title=2.1 sec 0-60 mph is base model before adding rocket thruster option |date=June 27, 2019}} Its claimed {{convert|0|to|1/4|miles|m|-1|order=flip|abbr=in}} time will be under 9 seconds, with a top speed above {{convert|400|km/h|abbr=on|}}. If the production Roadster achieves these performance numbers, it will outperform the [[supercar]]s of 2019 and would set new [[List of fastest production cars by acceleration|production car records]], none of which had yet done better than {{Convert|0|–|100|km/h|abbr=on|}} in 2.0 seconds or 9.0 seconds in the 1/4 mile.{{Cite news |url=https://jalopnik.com/heres-what-a-battery-researcher-told-us-about-the-tesla-1820558723 |title=Here's What A Battery Researcher Told Us About The Tesla Roadster's Crazy Performance Claims |last=Tracy |first=David |website=[[Jalopnik]] |access-date=November 18, 2017 |language=en-US |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171118090127/https://jalopnik.com/heres-what-a-battery-researcher-told-us-about-the-tesla-1820558723 |archivedate=November 18, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://nerdist.com/elon-musk-tesla-semi-roadster/ |title=Elon Musk Unveils Tesla Semi, Roadster in 'Smackdown to Gasoline Cars' |website=Nerdist |date=November 17, 2017 |access-date=November 18, 2017 |language=en |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119075700/https://nerdist.com/elon-musk-tesla-semi-roadster/ |archivedate=November 19, 2017}} Referring to the performance, Musk stated, "this is what we are achieving in the prototype", he also indicated the performance may improve in the production model and that the stated numbers refer to the anticipated "base model." {{notelist|group=note}} ==Analysis== Research completed by [[Bloomberg L.P.]] indicates that the estimate as to range per charge is optimistic, based on comments from Salim Morsy, electric vehicle analyst at Bloomberg New Energy Finance. In an article titled ''Tesla's Newest Promises Break the Laws of Batteries'', Morsy indicated that the claimed battery capacity would require batteries that would be too large for the Roadster's small frame. "I really don't think the car you saw last week had the full 200 kilowatt hours in it. I don't think it's physically possible to do that right now."{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-24/tesla-s-newest-promises-break-the-laws-of-batteries |title=Tesla's Newest Promises Break the Laws of Batteries |first1=Tom |last1=Randall |first2=John |last2=Lippert |work=Bloomberg |date=November 24, 2017 |access-date=June 12, 2018}} Morsy's analysis directly contradicts Musk, who stated "this is what we are achieving in the prototype". Venkat Viswanathan, a [[mechanical engineering]] professor at [[Carnegie Mellon University]],{{cite web |url=https://www.meche.engineering.cmu.edu/faculty/viswanathan.html |title=Venkat Viswanathan |publisher=Carnegie Mellon University |access-date=June 12, 2018}} told ''[[Jalopnik]]'' that the 1.9 second figure for {{cvt|0-60|mph|km/h|0|order=flip}} seemed reasonable given the estimated battery weight of {{cvt|833|kg|lb|0}}. He added that the feasibility of the acceleration claim assumed suitable tires would be available for the required traction.{{cite web |url=https://jalopnik.com/heres-what-a-battery-researcher-told-us-about-the-tesla-1820558723 |title=Here's What A Battery Researcher Told Us About The Tesla Roadster's Crazy Performance Claims |first=David |last=Tracy |work=Jalopnik |date=November 17, 2017 |access-date=June 12, 2018}} Series 4, episode 12 of ''[[Jay Leno's Garage]]'' broadcast on August 23, 2018 featured [[Jay Leno]] inside the Tesla Roadster prototype along with its designer [[Franz von Holzhausen]].{{cite news|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2018/08/20/new-tesla-roadster-featured-on-jay-lenos-garage-august-23/|title=Tesla's next-gen Roadster unleashes Jay Leno's inner child in "Jay Leno's Garage" segment|first=Steve|last=Hanley|work=[[CleanTechnica]]|date=October 23, 2019|accessdate=October 23, 2019}} ==See also== * [[NIO EP9]] * [[Rimac Concept One]] * [[Rimac C Two]] (Concept Two) * [[Mercedes-Benz EQ|Mercedes-Benz ''EQ A'']] * [[Aspark Owl]] * [[Pininfarina Battista]] * [[Lotus Evija]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Tesla Roadster (2020)}} *{{Official website}} {{Tesla Motors}} [[Category:Battery electric cars in development]] [[Category:Electric sports cars]] [[Category:Rocket cars]] [[Category:Roadsters]] [[Category:Tesla, Inc. vehicles|Roadster 2020]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2017]]
