{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}} {{short description|Tesla electric compact crossover utility vehicle released in March 2020}} {{Infobox electric vehicle | name = Tesla Model Y | image = Tesla Model Y front passenger side view.jpg | image_size = | caption = | manufacturer = [[Tesla, Inc.]] | aka = | production = 2020–present | assembly = {{Plainlist| *United States: [[Fremont, California|Fremont]], California ([[Tesla Factory]]) *China: [[Shanghai]] ([[Giga Shanghai]]) *Germany: [[Berlin]] ([[Giga Berlin]]) }} | designer = | class = [[Compact car|Compact]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] | body_style = 5-door [[Mini sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | layout = * [[Rear-engine, rear-wheel drive layout|Rear-motor, rear-wheel drive]] * Dual-motor [[all-wheel drive]] (''AWD'' models) | platform = | related = {{plainlist| * [[Tesla Model 3]] * [[Tesla Model X]] }} | motor = | powerout = | battery = | electric_range = {{Plainlist| *{{convert|230|miles|0|abbr=out}} Standard Range (EPA-rated) *{{convert|316|miles|0|abbr=out}} Long Range AWD (EPA-rated) *{{convert|315|miles|0|abbr=out}} Long Range Performance (EPA-rated) }} | charging = | transmission = | propulsion = | wheelbase = {{convert|113.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|187|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|75.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|64|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{unbulleted list | Long Range {{abbr|AWD|all-wheel drive}}: {{cvt|4416|lb}}{{cite web |url=https://teslamodelywiki.com/tesla-model-y-specifications/#Tesla_Model_Y_Dimensions |title=Model Y Wiki |access-date=March 11, 2020}} }} | successor = | sp = us }} The '''Tesla Model Y''' is an [[battery electric vehicle|electric]] [[Compact car|compact]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover utility vehicle]] (CUV) by [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla, Inc]]. Tesla unveiled it in March 2019 {{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/03/14/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-unveil/ |title=Tesla unveils Model Y electric SUV with 300 miles range and 7-seats|last=Lambert|first=Fred |date=2019-03-15|website=[[Electrek]]|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190315055454/https://electrek.co/2019/03/14/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-unveil/|archive-date=2019-03-15|url-status=live}} , started production at its [[Tesla Factory|Fremont plant]] in January 2020{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a30705862/tesla-production-results-q4-model-y/ |title=Tesla Beats Expectations, Declares a Profit, and Has Started Model Y Production |last=Baldwin |first=Roberto |date=2020-01-29| website=Car and Driver |publisher=Hearst |language=en-US |access-date=2020-02-27 }} and started deliveries on March 13, 2020. It is the second vehicle based on the [[Tesla Model 3|Model 3]] sedan platform.{{cite news |url=https://mashable.com/2016/01/28/tesla-model-3-variants/|title=Tesla is working on multiple variations of the Model 3|author=Nick Jaynes|date=29 January 2016|access-date=15 March 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205323/https://mashable.com/2016/01/28/tesla-model-3-variants/|archive-date=30 March 2019|publisher=[[Mashable]]}} Model Y will offer optional third-row seats for a seven-passenger seating capacity.{{cite magazine |url= https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-first-ride/ |title= Tesla Model Y First Ride: A Compact Crossover For Canyon Roads |author= Miguel Cortina |date= 15 March 2019 |magazine= Motor Trend |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190320084459/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-first-ride/ |archive-date= 20 March 2019 |url-status= live }} {{Cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2019/12/02/tesla-model-y-third-row-seats/ |title=Tesla Model Y: rare glimpse at third-row seats |last=Lambert|first=Fred |date=2019-12-02|website=Electrek |language=en |access-date=2020-02-27}} {{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/Model3Owners/status/1201513627292966913 |title=I took better pictures of the third row seats... sheesh |last=Online|first=Tesla Owners |date=2019-12-02|website=Twitter |language=en |access-date=2019-12-04}} There are four powertrains for the Model Y: Standard Range, Long Range, Long Range with Dual-Motor All-Wheel Drive, and Performance. The Long Range AWD model and the Performance model are currently being delivered and the Standard Range model is expected in "early 2021".{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modely/design|title=Design Your Model Y {{!}} Tesla|website=www.tesla.com|language=en|access-date=2020-03-27}} The Model Y fills a smaller size segment from its bigger sibling, the mid-sized [[Tesla Model X]].{{cite news |url= https://electrek.co/2017/08/02/tesla-model-y-coming-sooner/ |title= Tesla Model Y is coming to market sooner using Model 3 architecture, says Elon Musk |date= 2 August 2017 |author= Fred Lambert |publisher= electrek |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205317/https://electrek.co/2017/08/02/tesla-model-y-coming-sooner/ |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} ==History== In 2013, Tesla Motors filed for a trademark on "Model Y".{{Cite news |url= http://www.techtimes.com/articles/148939/20160411/if-ford-did-not-block-trademark-for-model-e-tesla-would-have-completed-a-word-after-model-s-model-x.htm |title= If Ford Did Not Block Trademark For Model E, Tesla Would Have Completed A Word After Model S, Model X |date= 11 April 2016 |author= Santiago Tiongco |work= Tech Times |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205509/https://www.techtimes.com/articles/148939/20160411/if-ford-did-not-block-trademark-for-model-e-tesla-would-have-completed-a-word-after-model-s-model-x.htm |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} In 2015, [[Elon Musk]] teased a Model 3-based Model Y with falcon-wing doors.{{cite news |url= https://arstechnica.com/cars/2015/10/tesla-model-y-with-falcon-wing-doors-hinted-at-by-elon-musk/ |title= Elon Musk hints at Tesla Model Y with falcon-wing doors |author= Sebastian Anthony |date= 7 October 2015 |work= [[Ars Technica]] |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330193150/https://arstechnica.com/cars/2015/10/tesla-model-y-with-falcon-wing-doors-hinted-at-by-elon-musk/ |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} In 2017, the Model Y's silhouette was teased to Tesla shareholders at the annual general meeting in June.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jun/07/tesla-teases-new-model-y-car-cheaper-model-3-production-elon-musk |title= Tesla teases new Model Y car as cheaper Model 3 nears production |author= Samuel Gibbs |date= 7 June 2017 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330181733/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jun/07/tesla-teases-new-model-y-car-cheaper-model-3-production-elon-musk |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} Elon Musk also announced that the Model Y would be produced in a new factory, as it was not likely that the [[Tesla Factory|Fremont plant]] would have room to accommodate another production line.{{cite news |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-signals-new-factory-for-model-y-suv-1496797117 |title= Tesla CEO Elon Musk Signals New Factory for Model Y SUV |author= Tim Higgins |date= 6 June 2017 |newspaper= Wall Street Journal |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190316150723/https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-signals-new-factory-for-model-y-suv-1496797117 |archive-date= 16 March 2019 |url-status= live }} In June 2018, a new silhouette was revealed by CEO Musk. With the new image, it was stated that the Model Y would be formally announced in March 2019.{{cite news |url= http://fortune.com/2018/06/06/elon-musk-tesla-model-y-image/ |title= Elon Musk Shares a New Image of the Tesla Model Y |author= LISA MARIE SEGARRA |date= 6 June 2018 |work= [[Fortune Magazine]] |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330193202/http://fortune.com/2018/06/06/elon-musk-tesla-model-y-image/ |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} The Model Y announcement had been planned for 2018, however production problems with the Model 3 resulted in it being pushed to 2019.{{cite web |url= https://electrek.co/2018/10/22/tesla-model-y/ |title= Tesla Model Y: what to expect? |author= Fred Lambert |date= 22 October 2018 |publisher= Electrek |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205319/https://electrek.co/2018/10/22/tesla-model-y/ |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} In October 2018, Elon Musk revealed that he has approved the finalized design for the first production version of the Model Y, however production would not start until 2020.{{cite news |url= https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/24/18020936/teslas-model-y-crossover-prototype-production |title= Tesla’s Model Y crossover is ready for production, Elon Musk says |author= Sean O'Kane |date= 24 October 2018 |work= [[The Verge]] |access-date= 15 March 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205340/https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/24/18020936/teslas-model-y-crossover-prototype-production |archive-date= 30 March 2019 |url-status= live }} On 3 March 2019, Elon Musk published multiple tweets, announcing the unveiling event and confirming some specifications.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102332778492772352 |title=Model Y unveil event on March 14 at LA Design Studio|last=Musk|first=Elon |date=2019-03-03|website=@elonmusk|language=en|access-date=2019-03-04|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190303235845/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102332778492772352 |archive-date=2019-03-03|url-status=live}} Musk confirmed the vehicle will use standard doors, as opposed to the falcon-wing doors used on the Model X.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102340302663180288 |title=Normal|last=Musk|first=Elon |date=2019-03-03|website=@elonmusk|language=en|access-date=2019-03-04|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190407170743/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102340302663180288 |archive-date=2019-04-07|url-status=live}} On 14 March 2019, Elon Musk debuted the Tesla Model Y at an event at Tesla's design studio in Hawthorne, CA, where specifications were announced and the vehicle was shown. Test drives of multiple Model Y vehicles were also offered to attendees after the presentation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-test-ride-video/ |title=Tesla Model Y test ride: first impressions of Tesla's latest 7-seat SUV (VIDEO)|last=Alvarez|first=Simon |date=2019-03-15|website=TESLARATI|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-15|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205313/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-test-ride-video/ |archive-date=2019-03-30|url-status=live}} Due to its larger size, the Y consumes more energy than the 3, and thus has shorter range. The Fremont Factory was changed to accommodate production of the Y.{{cite web |last1=Field |first1=Kyle |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20190821223314/https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/08/streamlining-manufacturing-of-the-tesla-model-3-for-the-model-y/ |archivedate=2019-08-21 |url-status=live |title=Streamlining Manufacturing Of The Tesla Model 3 For The Model Y |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/08/streamlining-manufacturing-of-the-tesla-model-3-for-the-model-y/ |website=CleanTechnica |date=8 June 2019 |quote=the Model Y is notably larger than the Model 3 and has a larger frontal surface area as a result. Combined with its 8–10% heavier build, that will result in a lower efficiency than the 3}} In November 2019, Tesla announced that the Tesla Model Y would be the first vehicle to be assembled at the first European Gigafactory, [[Giga Berlin]].{{cite news |url=http://electrek.co/2019/11/12/tesla-gigafactory-4-berlin-germany/ |title=Elon Musk: Tesla is going to build Giga Berlin |work=Electrek |date=12 November 2019 |access-date=13 November 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191112210609/https://electrek.co/2019/11/12/tesla-gigafactory-4-berlin-germany/ |archive-date=12 November 2019 |url-status=live }}{{cite AV media |people= |date=12 November 2019 |title=Die Verleihung des Goldenen Lenkrads 2019: Das sind die besten Autos des Jahres! |trans-title= |medium= |language= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8iEEVbhkR0&t=2490s |access-date= |archive-url= |archive-date= |format= |time= |location= |publisher=AUTO BILD |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} Tesla reported, during quarter 4, 2019 earnings report on January 29, 2020, that Model Y production has already started in the Fremont factory, that one can now place an order for their premium versions with all-wheel drive, and that delivery of Model Y will begin in Q1 2020.{{Cite web|url=https://ir.tesla.com/static-files/b3cf7f5e-546a-4a65-9888-c928b914b529 |title=Q4 and FY2019 Update|last=|first= |date=|website=Tesla |url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date= |access-date=2020-02-27}} On March 13, 2020 Tesla made their first deliveries of the Model Y, along with publishing its owner's manual.{{cite news|url= https://electrek.co/2020/03/13/tesla-model-y-specs-we-finally-know-how-big-it-is/ |website= electrek.co |title= Tesla Model Y specs: we finally know how big it is |first= Jameson |last= Dow |date= 2020-03-13 |access-date= 2020-03-14}} == Specifications == {| class="wikitable" |+Specifications {{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modely|title=Model Y |website=www.tesla.com |publisher=Tesla|language=en|access-date=2019-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190315040054/https://www.tesla.com/modely |archive-date=2019-03-15 |url-status=live}}{{cite web |title=Tesla Model Y Complete Measurement With Interior Info |url=https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/update-tesla-model-y-compete-measurement-with-interior-info |website=TESMANIAN |language=en}} !Battery !Standard Range ! colspan="4" |Long Range |- !'''Powertrain''' !RWD !RWD !AWD !Performance !Performance with Performance Upgrade |- !Base price (US market) |$39,000 |$48,000 |$52,990 |$60,990 |$60,990 |- !Range ([[FTP-75|EPA]]) |{{convert|230|mi|abbr=out|0}}{{cite web |url=https://www.tesla.com/modely |title=Model Y |publisher=Tesla |location=US |access-date=2019-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190315053008/https://www.tesla.com/modely |archive-date=2019-03-15 |url-status=live }}
|{{convert|300|mi|abbr=out|0}} |{{convert|316|mi|abbr=out|0}} |{{convert|315|mi|abbr=out|0}}
|{{convert|280|mi|abbr=out|0}}
|- !Range ([[FTP-75|WLTP]]) |{{convert|242|mi|abbr=out|0}} {{cn|date=December 2019}} |{{convert|336|mi|abbr=out|0}} {{cn|date=December 2019}} |{{convert|314|mi|abbr=out|0}} {{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/modely |title=Model Y |website=Tesla|language=en-GB|access-date=2020-02-10 }} |{{convert|298|mi|abbr=out|0}} |- !Acceleration
{{cvt|0|–|60|mph}} |5.9 seconds advertised |5.5 seconds advertised |4.8 seconds advertised |3.5 seconds advertised |3.5 seconds advertised |- !Top Speed |{{cvt|120|mph|km/h|0}} |{{cvt|130|mph|km/h|0}} |{{cvt|135|mph|km/h|0}} |{{cvt|145|mph|km/h|0}} |{{cvt|155|mph|km/h|0}} |- !US Projected Deliveries |Spring 2021{{cite news |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-first-look-model-3-of-suvs/ |title=Tesla Model Y First Look: The Model 3 of SUVs Is Here |last=Cortina |first=Miguel |date=15 March 2019 |work=[[Motor Trend]] |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191116000913/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-first-look-model-3-of-suvs |archive-date=16 November 2019 |access-date=3 December 2019 }} |Not yet scheduled for production.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/support/model-y-ordering-faq|title=Model Y Ordering FAQ|date=2019-03-14|website=www.tesla.com|language=en|access-date=2020-03-26}} | colspan="3" |March 2020 |- !Drag coefficient | colspan="5" | 0.23{{Citation|title=Model Y Unveil|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tb_Wn6K0uVs|language=en|access-date=2020-02-11}} |- !Luggage | colspan="5" | {{convert|68|cuft|L|0|abbr=on}} max volume with rear seats down and entire trunk + front trunk (frunk){{Cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/sites/default/files/model_y_owners_manual_north_america_en.pdf|title=Model Y Owner's Manual|last=|first=|date=|website=Tesla|page=187|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}} |} The Model Y is the first Tesla car to use a heat pump instead of electric resistance for interior cabin heating.{{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2020/03/23/tesla-model-y-heat-pump-elon-musk-best-engineering/|title=Elon Musk: Tesla Model Y heat pump is some of the best engineering I’ve seen in a while|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=2020-03-24|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-25}} (The [[Nissan Leaf]], [[BMW i3|BMW i3 EV]], [[Jaguar I-Pace]], [[Audi e-tron (2018)|Audi e-tron]], and [[Kia Niro]] have heat pumps.{{Cite web|url=https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1124387_can-heat-pumps-solve-cold-weather-range-loss-for-evs|title=Can heat pumps solve cold-weather range loss for EVs?|website=Green Car Reports|language=en|access-date=2020-03-25}}) In cold weather, the Model Y heat pump can be up to 300% more efficient than other Tesla cars' use of electric resistance heating.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-model-y-heat-pump-range|title=Tesla Model Y Heat Pump: Deep Dive and Closer Look|last=TESMANIAN|website=TESMANIAN|language=en|access-date=2020-03-25}} Because of this, in cold weather the Model Y should lose a smaller percentage of range than is lost by other Tesla cars.{{Cite web|url=https://thedriven.io/2020/03/18/model-y-has-heat-pump-to-solve-issue-of-range-in-cold-weather/|title=Model Y has heat pump to solve issue of range in cold weather|last=Schmidt|first=Bridie|date=2020-03-18|website=The Driven|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-25}} Electric cars can lose up to 40% of their range in cold weather ({{Convert|20|F|C|abbr=}}) when heating the interior cabin.{{Cite web|url=https://thedriven.io/2020/03/18/model-y-has-heat-pump-to-solve-issue-of-range-in-cold-weather/|title=Model Y has heat pump to solve issue of range in cold weather|last=Schmidt|first=Bridie|date=2020-03-18|website=The Driven|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-25}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/cold-weather-saps-electric-car-batteries-2019-02-07|title=Tesla and other electric car batteries lose 40% of their range in extremely cold weather: AAA|last=Press|first=Associated|website=MarketWatch|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-25}} ==Production== [[File:Rear driver side view.jpg|thumb|A Model Y in a parking lot]] Tesla originally announced plans at the unveil to assemble the Model Y at [[Giga Nevada]] (in Sparks, Nevada), along with the battery and drivetrain for the vehicles, unlike the Model 3, where drivetrains and batteries are assembled at Giga Nevada, with final assembly completed at the [[Tesla Factory]] in [[Fremont, California]]. Two months later, in May 2019, Tesla confirmed that they instead plan to shuffle production lines at the Tesla Fremont Factory to make space for Model Y production.{{cite web|last1=Kolodny|first1=Lora|title=Tesla is rejiggering its Fremont factory to build the Model Y SUV and a Model S refresh|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/29/tesla-fremont-factory-prepping-for-model-y-production-model-s-refresh.html|website=CNBC|date=29 May 2019|access-date=June 3, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190602063953/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/29/tesla-fremont-factory-prepping-for-model-y-production-model-s-refresh.html|archive-date=2 June 2019|url-status=live}} Later, Model Y will also be assembled at [[Giga Shanghai]] in China{{cite magazine|last1=Capparella|first1=Joey|title=The Tesla Model Y Is the All-Electric Brand's Entry into the Compact-Crossover Fray|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a26828716/tesla-model-y-photos-info/|work=[[Car and Driver]]|date=15 March 2019|access-date=March 14, 2019|magazine=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403044043/https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a26828716/tesla-model-y-photos-info/|archive-date=3 April 2019|url-status=live}} and [[Giga Berlin]] in Germany. US deliveries started in March 2020 for the Long Range AWD version and the Performance version. Deliveries will start in early 2021 for the Standard Range version. After initial rollout, Tesla is expected to begin shipping cars to the Canadian and Mexican markets, and [[Left- and right-hand traffic|left-hand drive]] European markets thereafter.{{cn|date=December 2019}} Once Giga Shanghai is operational, Model Y vehicles for Asian markets will be available.{{cite magazine |last1= García |first1= Gerardo |title= Tesla Model Y: Precios, versiones y equipamiento en México|url=https://www.motorpasion.com.mx/industria/tesla-model-yy-precios-versiones-equipamiento-mexico|date=March 15, 2019|access-date=March 15, 2019}} ==See also== * [[List of production battery electric vehicles]] *[[Tesla Supercharger]] {{-}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * {{Official website}} {{Tesla Motors}} [[Category:Tesla, Inc. vehicles|Model Y]] [[Category:Battery electric cars currently in production]] [[CATEGORY: Compact sport utility vehicles]] [[CATEGORY: Crossover sport utility vehicles]] [[CATEGORY: Electric sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2019]]

revision.comment: [[User:Monkbot/task_14: repair improper use of publisher params in cs1 templates|Task 14]]: cs1 template fixes: misused |publisher= (0×/6×);
